F: A little carbonation, wish it had more. Not offensive or harsh. 4.0

O: Easy to drink, a nice treat. I'll buy more of these if I can find them individually. 4.0

A- thin head typical of a pumpkin, moderate copper color

S-A bit muddled. Metallic overtones, malted barley, pumpkin bread

T-Much, MUCH better than the aroma had me prepared for. Vanilla, nutmeg, clove, canned pumpkin pie mix. Extremely pleasant. Not super complex but sweet and solid. It’s a fall day of raking leaves in a glass.

M- Pops, pleasant on the tongue, brings out the spice.

O- smell had me worried but it’s an extremely solid pumpkin beer. Not as complex as Pumpking, or my personal favorite, Alewerks pumpkin beer, but it is a readily available and delicious pumpkin offering.

I guess I'm in the minority here..I enjoyed this beer...

Sweet pumpkin pie flavors abound and I'm ok with that..

I wish the ABV was a little higher but other than that...this is a nice pumpkin ale and I like it more than others....
If all pumpkin beer had gone away forever I would not miss the horrible taste.

A- light orange and clove color. minimal head.

S- strong on the clove. no malt

F- clove and and pumpkin pie..not bad but its over dominating.

M- clove and chewy. feels like eating mushy pumpkin pie

O- ok but wouldnt get more.

Solid black appearance with a very thin tan head.
Medium light carbonation with an above average body with a creamy thick feel.
Aroma is a nice combination of chocolate hazelnut candy, black coffee,roasted malt,sweet vanilla, and a mildly boozy bourbon.
Taste is very similar to aroma,mildly sweet,boozy heat, with an almost dry bitter finish like bakers chocolate aftertaste.
Overall its an excellent beer.

9/24/22 On tap at Marilyn's in Morgantown.
Oh, what beautiful decadence! With the hazelnut..... Oh my, Leah is in heaven!

Nearly black with a thin tan head. Fairly strong nutty aroma with chocolate & coffee. Mild initial sweetness gradually intensifies to strong sweetness. Excellent combination of flavors: hazelnut & chocolate up front with coffee, roasted malt , vanilla, bourbon, barrel flavors & a little hopiness. It was a little thinner than expected, plenty of carbonation & lots of stomach heat. Overall: delicious!

the hazelnut smells and tastes almost too bold to be natural, like if this is real hazelnuts, its a whole lot of them, and infused somehow other than just resting in an ambient temperature barrel, at least it seems that way to me, but that said, its also not out of balance, and the nut seems to ground and balance some of the natural sweetness, it also makes both the chocolate and coffee pop, especially the coffee, and even though this is a small doses thing because of how strong and strongly flavored it is, its also delicious. desserty without being diabetic. the nose on this black shiny beast is nut forward, light smoke and dark roast from the coffee, plenty of bitterness there, along with dark chocolate character playing in the same space and quite a lot of oak. the bourbon is there with a little sweetness and alcohol warmth, both of which are exacerbated as it sits and comes up to temperature, the whiskey profile really flatters both the hazelnut and the coffee, big irish coffee vibes here. vanilla notes in the flavor, lots of nuance to the nut, more of a milk chocolate vibe after a few sips, but in the end its the coffee that pushes through all the dark malts and other stuff to be the dominant flavor, i taste bitter not quite perfectly fresh dark roasty drip coffee on my palate longer than any other element. its smooth the whole way, never too alcoholic, and really quite decadent. i think the hazelnut might be slightly overdone here, but it definitely brings new proportions to this iconic base beer. i always get nervous when breweries play with their legendary recipes like this one, but so far these variants have been fun and well executed. i dont need this much added flavor, but its good. cool to find this on tap too!

Bottled on 1/26/2022. Poured out of a 12 oz. bottle into my snifter glass, this beer pours a very dark brown, almost black color with a dark tan head that's about an inch thick when first poured that settles to an extremely thick ring lining the inside of the glass at the beer's surface along with a thick layer of surface foam and some pretty good lacing. Aromas of roasted malts, coffee, chocolate, and notes of hazelnut. Also an earthy and herbal hop note. The flavors are pretty much the same, with roasted malts, somewhat bitter espresso and somewhat sweet chocolate notes, toasted hazelnut, and an earthy and herbal hop note that rounds it all out. The hop flavor seems fairly dank, which I was not expecting, and it is a nice touch. The hazelnut note is also quite enjoyable and well integrated into this beer. The roast level on the malts is just a bit too intense for what I prefer, to the point where it comes across on my palate as being slightly too acrid. Actually, this note seems to get more intense as the beer warms up. Not a good thing, as it really overpowers the rest of the flavors in an unpleasant way. Are all the bottles of this batch like this, or did I just get a bad bottle? Has a crisp, smooth, slightly oily, slightly gritty, medium to full bodied mouthfeel that really coats the inside of my mouth.

Eric

Look - Fantastic looking, black and thick with a thick tan head and sticky lacing
Smell - so much hazelnut followed by chocolate coffee and barrel
Taste - creamy hazelnut coffee chocolate and barrel. Taste like a coffee with hazelnut creamer with a slight about of chocolate and a tad of wood.
Feel - medium full body slight creamy medium light carb, could use a little more body but still great
Overall - really enjoyed this iteration.

12oz bottle poured into a snifter

A- pours jet black in color with a one-finger foamy khaki head that has great retention and eventually leaves some lacing behind

S- fresh, herbal & earthy espresso up front with an equal part of bold hazelnut to match. The hazelnut and fresh coffee really compliment each other. Undertones of the barrel add oaky bourbon, caramel and coconut, with the base beer adding dark chocolate, charred malt, black licorice, brown sugar and burnt marshmallow. Fantastic aroma

T- bold herbal and earthy espresso up front is quickly complimented by a strong nutty hazelnut note up front. Mid-palate brings out dark charred malt, dark chocolate, caramel, brown sugar, molasses, anise and a hint of cola. The finish brings out the barrel, adding a touch of bourbon, oak, vanilla and coconut. Lingers of herbal coffee and hazelnuts

M- medium-heavy body with moderate carbonation leads to a creamy and velvety mouthfeel that continues into a silky, warming finish

O- the hazelnuts really make the coffee pop on this variant. Everything is bold, but well balanced. A slow sipper and one of my favorite KBS variants

KBS - Hazelnut pours black, with a small, tan head. Aroma is filled with hazelnut. Flavor has sweet hazelnut flavor, bourbon, barrel, smokey and malty cereal. Good body and feel. Overall, fantastic stout, creamy hazelnut flavors blend in very very well.

Poured a very dark blackish-brown with a light tan head. Smells of coffee, chocolate, bourbon, and charred oak. Taste was a coffee and chocolate combination with a nice bump from the alcohol. Really Good!!

I am trying this beer off the tapper at The Daily Growler in Powell, Ohio as part of a six sample flight. It poured an opaque dark with tan ring head that is not leaving much lace. The scent has bold hazelnut flare. The taste was nicely balanced and easy to drink with hazelnut, chocolate, espresso, and vanilla notes. The mouthfeel was medium in body and had smooth carbonation. Overall it is a solid beer .

Bought in Munster IN, poured from the 12oz bottle into a pint glass. The beer is a pure dark brown colour with a bit of cola like carbonation bubbles at the bottom when held to light. Head is dark tan, frothy, and built up to 2 fingers with a hard pour, settling down to a half finger for a while.

Smell is decadent. Nutty bittersweet chocolate, caramel, brown sugar, chocolate ice cream, Nutella on toast. Slight roasted flavor covered up again by nutty chocolate.

Taste: starts off with a bit of milk chocolate, accompanied by toastiness and a light nutty balancing note. Middle has a lot more of the hazelnut, roasted. Finishes with a hint of alcohol burn and a lingering burned sugar sweetness.

Overall, a fantastic dessert beer. Not as balanced as some others in the collection, but this variant would make a welcome addition to the regular line up. Drinkable and not cloying, but still obviously dessert. Nice.

L - Black with a dark tan head that dissipates somewhat quickly leaving behind some lacing
S - Tons of dark chocolate, hazelnut, roasted coffee and dark malts, as well as some caramel - this is a fantastic smelling beer
T - Follows the nose: dark chocolate and hazelnut intermixed with roasted coffee (adding some bitterness to balance the sweet) and dark malts along with slight hints of bourbon and caramel
F - Medium bodied with light carbonation. Smooth, but could be a little heavier
O - Flavors are straightforward but well done, another great addition to the KBS series

12oz bottled 1-25-22, opened 7-16-22.
3 finger chocolate milk frothy head with excellent retention for a big BBA beer. Thick, clingy lacing early. Dark body with no light visible. Rich nose of charred wood, hazelnut, coffee, milk chocolate, it's all there in a luxurious nose. Flavor is as advertised - big hazelnut, bitter coffee, light bourbon. Medium-plus body with moderate carbonation, silky mouthfeel, and mild booziness...very well integrated. Outstanding.

Black in color with no light penetration. There’s a quarter inch of creamy brown on top. Moderate, soapy lacing is present. The aroma is of hazelnuts, coffee chocolate, and bourbon. I’m tasting hazelnuts, coffee, bourbon, and chocolate. The mouth is sticky, chewy, and thick.

Purchased as a single bottle from The Blue Door for $7.50. Poured into a proper snifter glass.

L - Pours a viscous, deep brown hue; almost black. Serious legs on this one. One-finger sticky dark tan head.
S - Strong on the hazelnut, for sure! Notes of Cadbury milk chocolate, and brown sugar.
T - Matches nose on the front. Followed by notes of lightly-roasted coffee, burnt toffee, and a slight almond nuttiness. Strong, but covered somewhat by a sticky hazelnut syrup note. On the sweeter side, but definitely balanced out by a nice roasted tone throughout.
F - Full-bodied, with little carbonation (if any). Something to be sipped. Strong. Sticky.
O - Finally got my hands on a bottle of this! It's about as much as I had expected. Super heavy on the hazelnut and chocolate notes. Definitely a dessert beer. Highly recommend.

Bottled 2/2/22; drank 6/21/22 @ the Yarchives.

Black/brown appearance.

An even pour yielded a nice dark tan head; decent lace.

Hazelnut & chocolate syrup notes in the nose.

Medium thick mouthfeel.

Chocolate syrup & hazelnut flavors; artificial tasting & too sweet.

Not one I'll return to.

The deepest of dark brown liquid swirls into your glass topped by a thin dark tan head. The body is substantial and smooth at once. Fantastic evolution of flavors follows your first sip. Hazelnut dances with chocolate on your palate, with subtle bourbon and coffee flavor in support. Absolutely luscious KBS variant.

A very hazelnut variant of KBS.
Pours dark brown with a thin tan head. Aroma is hazelnut and chocolate. Taste follows with hazelnut forward and chocolate and roasted malts just behind. Feel is smooth and good, mostly smooth with some spikes. Overall it's a tasty KBS variant.

Well. Wanted to try this but put it off didn't want to spend the $27 or $8 per single at my local big box for what I imagined would be average, at best. So grabbed the one for under $6 at my favorite, returning home from the shore, local. And, wow. Aroma hazelnut all day. Tastes barrel bomb, chocolate and even some coffee as you go. So hard to find any coffee in a beer anymore, so this was a real treat. Saw it priced at $21 earlier this week, wish would've grabbed it.

Appearance: Pours a completely clear, medium but bright orange color with a strong white head. SRM of 10-12. (4.00)

Aroma: Moderate aromas of bread malts, toasted bread malts, some light, smooth caramel underneath. (4.00)

Flavor: Moderate flavors of smooth bread malt, caramel malt. A relatively dry finish.

Feel: A full mouthfeel, but a relatively lighter body and finishes dry. Strong carbonation.

Compared to Revolution Oktoberfest 9/14/22: Pours similar, stronger aromas. More

Compared to Great Lakes Oktoberfest 9/14/22: Pours slightly lighter, stronger aromas. More smooth caramel malt. Flatter, less bread, yeast, carbonation, and honey. Winner: Great Lakes

Overall: A pretty standard Oktoberfest here. Standard bready flavors, smooth caramel malt, Lower carbonation and yeast, but it finishes dry. Nothing out of the ordinary. (Rating: 3.70)

Bottle. White head. Clear golden color.

Biscuit and toasted crackers. Bready malts. Grassy and zesty hops. Faint bitterness. Has a touch of honey. Slightly reminds me of a Maibock. Very smooth, easy drinking, and too style.

Attractive clear bronze body under an average size off white head, Baked bread aroma with light notes of floral hops. Taste starts sweet without being cloying and allowing only modest bitterness. Malts dominate through to the aftertaste. Finishes smooth over light carbonation. Well made and enjoyable.

There is a date that barely appears on the shoulder of the bottle. It seems like it is lightly etched in the glass. It is hard to read when there is beer in the bottle, but after it is poured out it is easier to see: "BOTTLED 07-28-22 4663"

Appearance: The body is a medium-to-dark shade of golden brown. It has very good clarity. The head is short with a slightly off-white color. The head slowly recedes leaving no lacing and only a thin film of bubbles with a small ring around the glass. The color of the beer is very nice.

Aroma: There isn't much aroma but there is a very faint scent of wet leaves.

Taste: Up front there is a mixture of coffee, bread crust, and toffee. Towards the middle these flavors intensify and the bread crust flavor expands the greatest on the palate. Towards the back of the palate there is a very light spicy and herbal character which gives the beer just a bit of bite at the end. The aftertaste is very pleasant with a light tea quality and it lends itself very good drinkability.

Mouthfeel: The body is just at the threshold between light and medium, where it has a presence on the palate but moves on and off the tongue very quickly without much traction. The beer is very drinkability and it has a mild earthy bitterness. It is a very pleasant beer to drink.

Overall: The beer doesn't have much aroma, but that is quickly forgotten when the flavor kicks in. The beer delivers a wonderful complement of flavors and the beer is still light enough that it remains very drinkable. It is an easy beer to have one and just move on to another one. Although the highlight of the beer would be the fantastic drinkability, another element that is very enjoyable is the bread crust flavor which has just a very light touch of sweetness that is balanced by an earthy quality. I would recommend it because although the beer doesn't have much aroma it still tastes great. I would buy it again.

Poured into shaker pint. Not much head, surprisingly. Amber color, medium.

Light sweet malt nose.

Taste follows. Sweet toasted caramel malt and a hint of spice. No surprises.

Feel however is verrrrry smooth. Little carb on this one.

Classically Märzen. A ton of beers like this, but that's true of most styles.

12oz bottle, no date, served in a pilsner glass.

Appearance: Clear copper-amber. Thin white head that died back to a persistent ring with an occasional island of lacing.

Smell: Toasted malt, a little bit of noble hops, and a little bit of apple as well.

Taste: Rich toasted malt, noble hop bitterness for balance, crisp. Very nice in its simplicity.

Mouthfeel: Good carbonation, nice thickness, slick.

Overall / Drinkability: Very very drinkable. Went down really fast as a Marzen should. Simple, but deeply flavorful. Went well with mac and cheese and would pair well with a wide range of foods. I could easily have another one.
Looks, tastes, and feels like a marzen. I like it! Easy drinker!
Single bottle from Party Source

Pours a beautiful clear golden/amber with a smallish and short-lived white cap. Minimal spotty lacing. Aroma is bready with caramel and malt. Flavor is sweet and bready, minimally hoppy. Feel is medium bodied and lightly carbonated. Overall, a nice (American) Oktoberfest beer.

Munsterfest from 3 Floyds. 12 oz bottle from Shangy’s, Emmaus, PA, from 18/09/21. $ 2.64 (including tax) ($ 0.220/oz). Stored at room temperature in store and at 40 degrees after purchase. Reviewed 15/03/22. Note that I use DD/MM/YY protocol.
Etched on shoulder “BOTTLED 08-02-21”. Served at 41.1 degrees in a hand washed and dried Jester King snifter. Final temperature 47.3 degrees.
Appearance – 3.5
First pour – Deep Gold (SRM 6), clear.
Body – Pale Amber (SRM 9), opaque. When rear-lite, translucent, and chill haze apparent.
Head – Average (Maximum 1.3 cm, aggressive center pour), floral white, creamy with average retention, diminishing to a 0.3 to 0.4 cm undulating crown and thin partial cap.
Lacing – Poor – just a few random lumps of bubbles.
Aroma – 3.5 – Weak malty/caramel/toffee/fruit, no hops, no yeast.
Flavor – 3.25 – A bit sweet with some fruity/malty taste, maybe some caramel or toffee, weak hops, no flavors of yeast. No ethanol (6% ABV, as marked on container) taste or aroma, no gastric warming. No dimethylsulfide or diacetyl. Ends slightly bitter.
Palate – 3 – Thin, watery, soft carbonation.
Final impression and summation: 3.25 Meh. Another mediocre Festbier.

A - Pours a deep amber with a small creamy white head. Light clingy lacing.

S - Aroma is caramel, toasted biscuit, yeasty bread and floral hops.

T - The taste is caramel, toasted biscuit, white bread and floral hops.

M - Medium body with medium carbonation. Creamy with a nice crisp finish.

O - Solid Marzen.

Brief Review:

O: Been about 7 years since I’ve had this one, back again with the new Michigan distro. I forgot how much on the sweet and malty side this beer is, was expecting more of a hoppy crispness. But I do like this, pretty good balance and very drinkable as a good Oktoberfest should be.

Recommendation: Maybe not a classic rendering by most standards, but this is a nice-drinking Oktoberfest for the season.

Picked up a 12 oz bottle at Half Time Distributors in Poughkeepsie NY. Poured into a pint glass, this beer shows a beautiful copper color, almost crystal clear. The head is slightly off-white, medium size with average to slightly better than average retention. lacing is minimal. Aroma is fairly faint, malty and a little spicy/toffee. Taste is better, I have had more impressive Marzens, but this one is pretty good. Malty, slightly floral with some toffee and spices with a bit of underlying bitterness. Mouthfeel is fairly light but not watery. Three Floyds often nails a style better, but this one is pretty good!!!

Pours a nice amber color. Semi clear. The head is 1 finger, it is decent lasting, but has minimal lacing on the glass.
The nose is pretty light, actually. I get a faint malt/caramel aroma, but nothing too strong.
Taste - This beer has a good deal of caramel in it, and it kicks in on the back. Up front is a buttery, bread, biscuit flavor.
The body is somewhat creamy feeling. A bit bubbly. Smooth.
Not bad. Glad I bought it to try.

Pours clear, light copper in color with one quarter inch head. Taste is fresh brown bread and dry wheat bread. Medium body and carbonation, slightly sweet. Solid Marzen but it is missing something. Decent but I prefer the German classics.

Beautifully clear deep amber just shy of acorn brown with a tall khaki foam head slowly collapsing in fits and starts to a lumpy, sparse blanket.

Exceptionally malty, toasty, and fairly bitter, there's even unexpected hints of phenolic spice. This is certainly a unique Oktoberfest, somewhat like pumpernickel verging into gingerbread, but not quite.

No, it's not a holiday beer. It's not a pumpkin spice beer. But iT's NoT nOrMaL.

It's bolder than your average marzen, in several directions.

Disclaimer. Not my favorite style. But its a lager! Octs always seem to sweet. And they are high abv often. This has some of a aforementioned. But bbn leens full lager and is refreshing ice cold. Low carbonation which is ideal for this style. Paring with indian food and it should work.

Before I start, let me say this beer makes me happy. First of all, all these American o-fests have done what Americanized versions always do, and that is take the basic profiles of a style and turn all the flavors up wayyyy too high and nothing is as drinkable or balanced anymore. On that note...

Munsterfest is everything I want in an ofest. A poundable lager with malty and warm flavors, a whispy head, and beautiful color. You have to pour this vigorously to get the foamy head and lacing.. it might be ever-so-slightly under-carb’d, but that actually lends to the drinkability AND the flavors of this ofest. It has a little red ale in the nose, slightly metallic but not too off-putting, so at first, before the sip, I wasn’t sure. TheN this glorious ofest elixir hit my tongue, and wowza!!!!!

This beer tastes great. Cold, warm, no matter, but i think its better colder than some other versions of this style. Thats not necessarily a bad thing tho.. it slight lack of carbonation and the silkiness that makes it unique. Its very smooth and creamy in the taste despite the low carb and thinner body.. its a thin oil slick of ofest greatness. You have the big flavor spins like Sams or Great Lakes, and I love them both in their own way, but if i wanna pound a great ofest in massive seasion manner, give me Munsterfest. Im putting behind a classic like Ayinger, but for an American ofest, its originality, poundability, and viscosity, make it a bright shining star!!! This beer is fan-freaking-tastic, and more than any ofest in years, has me going back for more and more.. that night.. each week.. until they are available no more..
Pours a light copper color with a finger of head. The nose is grainy and herbal. The flavor profile has some caramel and some nuttiness. The finish is clean and the body is spot on for the style.

On tap at The Sheffield in Brighton, NY.

This one pours a golden vibrant yellow color, with a small head, and lots of lacing.

This smells like biscuity and not too sweet malt, peppery hops, dough, and some grassiness.

This is two lager kings working together – of course it’s gonna be excellent. It’s got a real tight malt character to it – slightly doughy, toasty, and biscuity, with a light but well balanced grassy and slightly peppery hop character.

This is light bodied, super crisp and well attenuated, with a fantastic drinkability.

It’s hard to find much flaw here – East Coast lager excellence paired with Rocky Mountain lager excellence. What could go wrong?

Pours a clear, rich golden color with a gorgeous fluffy white head that lasts, falling to a quarter inch cap with tenacious cling to the glass.

Sweet and toasty hits the nose first. It's a honey-like sweetness. The hops are floral and herbaceous with a slight grassiness and a very faint spiciness.

The taste opens slightly sweet with a bready malt flavor. Then there's a bunch of kids in this pool. The malt carries through, but there is a fairly strong hop note that leans more floral than the nose suggests. There's still some herbal grassiness, but not very pronounced. The sweetness starts to lean towards honey or maybe light brown sugar, and in the aftertaste it is almost a caramel flavor. There's just a hint of orange that I still don't notice in the smell, and the finish leaves a little peppery tingle behind that gets a little more pronounced on repeat sips. Everything rides on that malt backbone, though. It does have that flavor I am beginning to associate with decoction brewing but can't quite nail down - I suspect there's some browning reactions in that cooking process that bolster the toasted maltiness.

Light bodied, moderately carbonated, and the self-replenishing head lends it a slight foamy feel. Mildly bitter, fairly crisp, highly drinkable at 5.7%. Very nicely balanced on all the attributes.

Wow...not disappointed in this one at all. Worthy.

16oz can poured into a Sam Adams glass

A- pours a golden-straw color with just a hint of haze, two finger pillowy white head has great retention long after the pour

S- cracker malts, honey, floral and spicy hops, hint of grass, cracked pepper

T- slightly sweet and malty up front with notes of doughy bread and honey, followed by some toasted grains. Mid-palate brings out a solid base of spicy and peppery floral hops. The finish gives a perfect balance of bready malt and spicy floral hops, that stick around on the linger

M- light body with moderate carbonation leads to a foamy mouthfeel that continues into a crisp finish, high drinkability

O- full flavored with that remarkable balance that you expect from the style, well done

There is no date on the can. The pour is golden yellow with a nice & steady flow of carbonation. The taste is honey, lemon drop, & grains. I don't see a date on the can anywhere. Furthermore, this is darn impressive lager, do yourself a grab a can of this stuff. Cheers! B

Canned 7/1/22

Man, I haven’t had a Dortmunder in a long ass time. Now I find one that’s a collaboration between 2 of the kings of the American Lager brewing scene, Jack’s Abby and Bierstadt! Let’s see what happens when these 2 put their brains together for a rather obscure style

Pours a cloudy deep gold with 3 fingers of soapy white head that slowly fades to a thin cap and leaves decent lacing

It’s wonderfully toasty and sweet in the nose, but there’s still a nice bite to it. I’m picking up on aromas of toasted grain, sweet honey, bready malt, herbal hops, orange zest, and light pepper

It leans a bit more into the sweeter aspect in taste which I don’t prefer but it’s still quite good. On the front end of the sip I’m tasting bready malt, honey, herbal hops, dark toast, white pepper, toffee, and light orange rind. The swallow brings notes of toasted grain, sweet honey, bready malt, floral hops, white pepper, and light brown sugar

A light medium body pairs with gentle carbonation, resulting in a crisp and refreshing beer. Finishes mostly dry with a slight hop bite

This is good stuff. Again, a little sweeter than I would’ve liked, but a solid summer beer
This years batch taste a little different.
Uninspiring when compared to Gold Standard Spaten. Malt flavor weak, beer clean taste. Hope fine but just No Oompah!

Pours a solid golden amber color with finger or two foamy head. Smells of a toasty caramel scented malt. Tastes the same with smoothness similar to a Irish red but slightly different. An absolute fall classic and is loved by most. There is a reason this is a common draft amongst establishments in the fall. Boston does it well with this Sam Adams seasonal.

Poured from a 12 oz bottle into a pint shaker and had to pour in stages as the head was so aggressive. The color was beautiful copper with the manilla colored head, looks enticing.
The aroma was ideal for a Märzen style, the malts and caramel and touch of spice, oh, this smelled good.
The taste was okay, a letdown after the hard sell- the aforementioned malts were there but rather undefined. It was curious after the aroma was so spot on and the taste just dropped off. Weird.
The feel was excellent, no worries there.
Smooth and so easy to drink.
OA, very strange, parts of this excel but somehow the flavors can’t back the rest up.

Did I just get a bad batch or do I need a tastebud transplant?

It doesn't even smell or taste like beer. I can't even tell you how it tastes as I can't find the words to do so.

I was drinking Bell's Octoberfest last week. Enjoyed it very much.

Thought I would save a few dollars this week, but ending up throwing away $12.99 for Samuel Adams.

Ugh.

I returned to SA Octoberfest after about 10 years away, and I can't say that the time has done it any favors. I remember a good quality Marzen with a nice flavor profile that, yes, sometimes had its off years, but on the whole was a steady performer in the American O-fest scene.

The only constant from the beer I remember is the great look, a beautiful dark amber. The rest just seems muddled. For me, the taste is a bit off, with a flat malt expression that doesn't have much character or depth, and too much bitterness on the finish. Maybe they've increased the hop bill to meet current tastes? Well it doesn't suite my palate. While nicely medium bodied, it has an unfortunate tendency to syrup-coat your mouth after the swallow.

Would I choose this over a lot of other standard party/bbq offerings? Absolutely. But with so many great, small craft options these days, it might be another 10 years before I buy SA Octoberfest again.

Had on tap (alledgedly tapped yesterday) at Hoffbrau Bar and Grill in Westminster, CO

On arrival a fine one finger head was present that relatively quickly dissipated to a ring around the rim and very light covering. Carbonation is lazy and fine in a reddish brown amber body. No lacing.

Aroma has some nice lightly estery Germans tyle lager yeast with a very low hopping rate. A nice nutty roasted malt is peeking its head through pretty aggressively.

Taste is similar to the aroma with a low hopping rate, and a surprisingly flavorful but pleasant German style lager yeast that plays a big role here. Once the fermentation character passes a big wave of nutty roasted malts takes over.

Feel is insanely drinkable with a medium body for easy drinking but a bit more body for that oktoberfest. Very soft and smooth. Not the sweetest but the malts are mouthcoating. On the medium finish it starts drying out a bit.

Overall this is a very nice malty oktoberfest. Flavorful and it tastes German. Very light hops as per style, but it doesn't go great with hoppy amber lagers as I just found out.

Created an account just to say that I agree with the review posted by ABeingWhoDrinksBeer in Dec 2021.

Overly malty and enough sweetness to ruin the brew. I also get a hint of chocolate, which doesn't work for me in a beer.

Looks good, but that's about it.

Unfortunately, the Pacific Northwest is awash in IPAs, which makes it hard for someone like me who's not a huge IPA fan to find a decent craft beer that isn't an IPA. I spotted this in Costco and figured, "I like Sam Adams, how bad could this be?" and proceeded to buy a case of 36 (!) bottles.

I sure hope one of my buddies like this... I can't bring myself to dump it down the drain.
Equal to the great lakes Oktoberfest

An ok entry level Oktoberfest style beer.
It's missing the malt complexity of a true German beer of this style, but overall it's not bad. There's better by far.
I mean, it's just regular Sam Adams but somehow worse

Bought pint of draft at a minor league ball game, so I paid way too much for a beer. Rich golden, reddish, tan color with off white foam that diminished after a few minutes. Pleasant aroma and taste was malt leading with a smooth finish. Enjoyable brew, would buy a 6 pk for a better deal.
I saw this at the store today and had to buy the 12 pack. Excellent beer—good head, medium carbonations, malty with hints of sweetness and slightly bitter.

No can date, just a code
Pours a frothy bubbly almost 2 finger head with moderate retention, fair sticky lacing, mostly clear light golden tan color

Nose rich malt, grainy-sweet malt, straw, a bit of dough, very light toasty note, fair floral herbal hop

Taste brings lots of rich malt up front, grainy-sweet pilsner malt, straw, a bit of corn, grainy and doughy bread, little cereal, mild malt depth maybe single decoction, fair herbal grassy hop with lower bitterness up front, dry finish with a med hop bitterness getting a bit spicy

Mouth is med to fuller bod, med frothy carb

Overall not bad, not as good as many of the other true German Festbiers but better than most American fake versions

poured from a 500mL can into a tall Kapuziner Weißbier glass. pours a clear straw gold with a firm three finger foam head. stale bread malt aromas on the nose. get a little bit of that in the taste but it’s a bit smoother and cleaner than the nose. full mouthfeel. not a lot of carb so it drinks on the heavier side. overall, a damn good festbier.
The pour is honey colored with a fair amount of carbonation. The taste is white bread, saltine crackers, & mild hop bitterness. Cheers! B

Undecipherable canning date; drank 9/11/22 @ the Yarchives.

See-through orange/yellow appearance.

A rough pour yielded a HUGE eggshell head; frothy, tree-rung lace.

Fresh corn, mild dry grass & faint raw wheat notes in the nose.

Creamy medium mouthfeel.

Fresh corn & faint caramel flavors up front; mild wheat & faint grassiness on the finish.

Easy to drink, flavorful...I'd have another!

(500 ml can, L 211910; purchased single off shelf at Total Wine... poured into my tall Tonewood lager glass, similar to a Rastal Monaco)

L: brilliantly-clear, gold liquid; tight, jagged, dense off-white foam cresting perfectly over the lip of the glass... long recede of head, with the result not as spectular as hoped: scant, chunky lace streaks, thin broken cap

S: bready and minerally with a spicy hop accent; almost a bit meaty too?... sulfury fermentation... hint of underripe pear (juice)... good-to-excellent overall potency, just some gamey nuances... floral, herbal hop edge eventually pushes forward

T: bread crust, subtle note of graham cracker up front; herbal, leafy hop bite and a granola-like grain flavor in the aftertaste... delicate apple note in the middle... latent musty clove/bubblegum note builds

F: light-bodied, but with a noticeable silky swell; the aft is relatively airy and with little residual viscosity... mellow amount of carbonation lingers

O: I do enjoy this style of festbier and this one, despite its 'earthy' yeast aroma, turned out to be more than satisfactory; I'd have another, but probably get bored midway through that second round... if anything, I guess it's missing some dimension and unique character (2014)

Picked up a four-pint pack. Canning date of 08/01/2022 -- very fresh!

Pours a crystal clear copper in color with hints of gold and a frothy finger-thick head atop that fades fairly quickly. A bit of lacing on the glass, some slides some clings. Carbonation looks average. Exactly as expected in appearance -- slightly darker than a helles hinting at a bit more flavor complexity and a bit less drinkability.

Aroma is bready malts, perhaps some rye, roasted corn, yeast, tea and lots of grassy, lemony hops. Seems to be pretty balanced on the nose, perhaps slightly hop forward. A bit earthy with a hint of alcohol and spice.

Taste follows the aroma well, if a bit more malty than expected. Roasted, rye malts up front with a spicy, hoppiness coming in towards the middle and into the swallow. Finishes with a spicy, lemon hoppiness and roasted maltiness on the tongue. A bit earthy overall and a tad sweet, but balanced out nicely by the roastiness of the malts and a hint of bitterness from the hops.

Medium bodied, this one drinks smooth with a hint of chewiness and light, zesty carbonation. Quite drinkable, but has a viscousness that tells me I probably shouldn't drink more than a few pints of this.

Another great brew from Tucher. This reminds me a lot of their helles. It's basically a stronger, more flavorful version of the same thing, which is exactly what I'd expect from their festbier. It's probably a bit sweet for my tastes overall, but I very much appreciate the quality of this. It's an excellent treat for autumn, it definitely feels like a brew of occasion. I continued to be impressed by Tucher. Prost!

Picked up,a can of this beer at a recently opened Total Wine nearby. A Fest beer I have not had before.

Poured into a tulip glass. Clear, bright yellow color with nice foamy white head and decent curtain lacing. Nice sweet bread smell and taste. A bit fruity and nicely bitter with a dry finish. Decent Octoberfest type beer.

Clear pale gold body under a large white head that left good lacing. Bready aroma carrying along a bit of sweetness. Sweetness also a factor in the taste. Spicy hops are low profile while the grainy malts provide texture. Smooth, clean, medium bodied moderately carbonated mouthfeel. A good example where 'fest' is not always a 'marzen'.
500ml can from HomeBrewStuff. Clear golden, ample white head, lively carbonation. Malty aroma, sweet. Taste is bready, malty, sweet. Pretty simple combo brought together by a nice full, creamy body.

Poured from a can into a pint glass
Appearance – The beer pours a clear golden-amber color with a small head of white foam. The head has fades quite quickly, leaving very little lace on the sides of the glass.
Smell – The aroma is quite heavy of a grainy and bready smell mixed with aromas of caramel and some harvest fruits. Along with these smells comes a little bit of hay and yeast as well as a bit of herb and earthiness.
Taste – The taste starts out with a crisp grainy and cracker malt flavor that has notes of caramel and toffee sweetness. There is a little bit of yeast and pear, with both of these getting lighter as the taste advances. At the same time, as the taste advances, light herbal and earthy flavors join in, all while the graininess gets a bit more potent. Toward the end of the flavor transitions comes some straw and a bit more toffee/caramel, leaving one with a rather pleasant and crisp taste to linger on the tongue.
Mouthfeel – The body of the brew is medium in thickness and creaminess with a carbonation level that is average. For the style and the flavors, the feel is spot on and makes for a very nice drinker.
Overall – A nice easy drinking and flavorful marzen. For the $1.99 I paid for an imperial pint, you certainly can’t go wrong.

Can into pint glass. Pours a crystal-clear honey-gold color with a nice off-white head. Initial impression is bready malts, honey, and a touch of hops to offset the maltiness a little. Mouthfeel is medium - bordering on chewy. Finish is clean and refreshing, with lingering breadiness. Overall, a very drinkable Festbier - maybe a little heavy for sessioning, but I could easily drink a couple of these.

16 fl oz can from a ~$10 USD 4-pack.

5.8% ABV.

A bit too doughy in its yeast profile for me, distracting from the Munich malt honeyed sweetness. Too bready to be a beer I'd quaff by the litre (and quaffing by the litre is sort of the point of a festbier).

Still a nice brew, but not amongst the best German expressions of the style. This is currently rated #1 in the Festbier category, which I think is over-effusive, but it's drinkable and enjoyable, no doubt.

B- / WORTHY

500 ml Can
Consumed on: 14 July, 2022
Glass: 0.5 L Fest Mug
Serving Temp: 48.4 F


Look:
Golden yellow with a 2-finger frothy and pillowy white head. The head fades to about a half finger of bubbly foam. Lacing is good.

Smell:
Quite malty. Very bready and even doughy. There is a very light touch of honey and also lemon. Light touch of grass - both cut and uncut.

Taste:
Dialed down a notch or two from the nose but still quite good. Ant still malty. The malts come across as fresh baked bread and soft pretzels. The lemon note can be picked up in the background. There is a mild bitterness from the hops but it is just enough to cut into the malts and balance things out. The sip finishes very slightly dry. Very refreshing.

Feel:
Crisp and mostly clean. A tad chewy. Body is medium-light.

Overall:
A quite enjoyable and easy drinking Festbier. Nicely done. I could drink this all day long. This definitely earns its #3 rating (at the time of this review) and just might be my favorite Festbier to date.

Pours a light golden color with a nice head and lacing
Aroma has caramel, malt and hop hints
The taste follows the nose with a well balanced caramel, malt and hop flavor
A medium light bodied well carbonated beer
A great Festbier

Excellent Festbier!
Spot on top notch.

pours a crystal clear gold body with a white froth head that has moderate retention and leaves specs of thin sudsy lacing behind as it settles to a thin slightly murky cap with small halo

aroma is crystal clear malty caramel, layered with a pizza dough like fluff and mild pretzel

taste is plenty malty but not quite as complex as the aroma, although a slight hop bitterness hits towards the end to balance it

mouthfeel is high carbonation and medium-light body that runs somewhat watery but manages chewy and finishes crisp and dry with a lightly malty and earthy hopped aftertaste

overall:
the malt layers are very interesting, standing out pretty nicely, and the hopped finish is a great transition

Poured from the can into a Libbey style pilsner glass.

Beaming brass yellow, with exceptional glass and mirror like clarity in the body, with light reams of carbonation. Head is bright white and fluffy looking, with a big four fingers and thick creamy retention and staying power. Just an all around bold and beautiful looking lager.

Real exceptional aroma. Big dough malts, and baked bread flavors, hints of light brown crust and exotic fresh milled grain. Kicks in a little pasty and sticky sensing, not the most clean but real solid and impressive nose.

Palate is real nice. Soft bodied moutfeel, light but like Spring water like consistency. A nice mid palate of toffee crispness that pushes all the right buttons. Finishes a bit dry grain, almost flour like, but much more flavors of caramel and soft toffee continue as the beer warms and drinking keeps flowing.

Real good festbier, will have to remember this one next time I see it.

a festbier from germany, thought i had previously tried most of them, so i was stoked to find this, been loving the style again this year and was eager to try an old world example of it, but this was a little disappointing, and while freshness may be part of the issue, this underwhelmed even aside from that, past mineral forward to almost metallic, thin, and pretty simple flavored by the lager yeast and some bittering hops, less malty than most, even as a festbier compared with a marzen lager, i can see a lot of potential for this, but it didnt hit for me the way i hoped it would, grabbed a four pack for all day drinking and ended up only having one can and moving on to some wet hop stuff, will circle back later this week, but it didnt take me where i wanted to go. i love the cans, label and size, and i love the price. the pour is pretty, clear and airy white headed, looks like a nice german helles, maybe a shade richer. the nose is light oxidation, aluminum, nutty european malt, and bread yeast to me, even lightly doughy, pretty minimal overall, noble hops there too, but its all relatively unexciting. the flavor follows, some grassiness from the hops, a tea note late, very dry throughout and not as flavorful on the grain side as it smells. the yeast its primary, along with the mineral profile, and overall it is missing something for me, maybe the crispness of a good helles, maybe the richness of a proper marzen, which i know this isnt, but its sort of in this middle ground or no mans land where its not quite defined. drinkable for sure, fizzy and lively in texture and quite light, but this just tastes a bit cheap to me, tired from its long journey here, and not a standout in the style unfortunately...

edit: upon further review, aka two more cans of this, i may have been a little too harsh on it, sure its a little thinner and lacks malt richness, but its not as metallic as i called it after the first one, more mineral forward to me now, and with pizza it was spot on. the freshness is still an apparent issue but the quality is higher than maybe i gave it credit for the first time around. bumping up a few scores now, context seems to be everything with this one...

Poured from a 16 oz can purchased from the Dorset store; no birth date. Pours light light brown with two fingers of foamy head that slowly recedes. Sweet biscuity malt with very light hop backbone. Very good.

16.9 oz can that, with its 2-3 cm head filled my .5+L glass to the brim.
While fine looking with its sparkling golden body that has high clarity, the flavor is more mediocre. The aroma also is better than the flavor. It carries a nicely balanced mix of malts and spicy- grassy hops.

500ml can into a pint glass. Dating hard to understand, but feel confident it is this years release.

Looking very good in the glass. Clear pale golden yellow body. Initial full white head shrinks to a collar and covering, scattered lacing.

Strong malty aroma, not an overly sweet smell.

On tasting, good malty taste, not too sweet. Well balanced, not so much with bitterness, though there is a hint of that, but by a strength and depth of flavor.

Mouth above medium, finish a little sweetness comes through, as does the abv.

Overall, really enjoying my foray into Festbiers this fall. And this is one of the better ones.

500 ml. can stamped L 114710

Clear gold with two fingers varied white head, full curtain lacing and cap.
Strong bready, honeyed, toasty malt aromas.
Cracker, light malt, pepper, light floral hop, apple flavors.
Smooth balanced malt and supporting hops. Dry finish. Good carbonation.
Very good helles style Festbier.

500ml can poured into a dimpled mug.

A two finger white head caps the clear, rich gold pour. The very persistent head is comprised of both tight and loose soapy foam and leaves good lacing. The aroma is moderate strength, spicy hop over light toasted malt and some mineral notes. Taste is semi-dry and balanced slightly to hop front to back, bitterness is low but a mild bitterness does ring out in the brief aftertaste. Malt flavor is clean toasted malt while the hop flavor opens spicy and transitions to more floral with hints of citrus as the mug warms. Mouthfeel starts medium-light and crisp before smoothing to a heavier creamy finish. This is a great Oktoberfest though I find it a little sharp and the flavor profile to be more like a Marzen than a Festbier.

Golden amber body; excellent carbonation; thick and spongy white head, dense and rocky. Fine toasted malt nose.; a bit of earthy spiciness. Sublimely and subtly malty; toasted grain again. faint honey; low-key malt sweetness; low to moderate hop bitterness. Medium body; crisp and warm on the palate; nice touch of dryness at the finish.

This is a wonderful festbier, warm and nicely malty with just the right touch of hop bitterness to round things out.

Poured at 48 °F; data on can bottom: L 114710

A clear golden yellow color with a full head and nice white lacing. The nose is honey and grainy bread. It tastes of crackers, floral hoppiness, and pepper on the way out. This is so light and crisp. YUM! I could drink a few of these. Makes me want to eat.

This one pours a light orange-ish color, clear, with a small head, and lots of lacing.

This one smells like grassy hops, honey, breadiness, and a bit of spice.

This has a light nice nuttiness and bready malt character, with a touch of grassy hop spice to it. I'd want a touch more crisp bite on the back end for the style, but it's still well done in this area of the Oktoberfest world.

This is light bodied, clean, crisp, and very drinkable, with a nice smooth finish.

This is a very nice pale take on the style.

From the bottom of the can: "L 114710 10:10/02"

Appearance: The beer has a nice amber colored body with hints of burnished gold. Dark shadows with a very slight haze are visible through the body. The head is white and forms a solid disc of foam which become somewhat rocky as it fades. It had average retention and leaves a short white cap on top of the beer at all times. There are nice blotches of camouflage patterned lacing.

Aroma: There isn't a ton of aroma here; a mild cereal grain character giving off the impression of sweetness.

Taste: Up front there is a light bit of bread dough flavor. As it rolls along the sides of the palate towards the middle it picks up a light bit of spice. Mild alcohol note on the center of the tongue that is more noticeable at first but fades away while drinking the beer and between palate cleansing. Stale cracker character comes through a bit. A very mild herbal character towards the end of each sip but mostly absent of flavor at the finish and in the aftertaste.

Mouthfeel: It feels balanced on the edge of light and upper-light bodied depending on the sip. Very mellow bitterness. It is a very easy beer to drink.

Overall: This feels like a pretty average, lighter Festbier. It wouldn't be the first beer I would pick up for its aroma or flavor but it would be a decent beer to clank under a tent while dancing on benches or singing songs. It's not something I would buy again to drink at my house but I could drink it if that was what was being served at a tent.

A: The beer is jet black in color. It poured with a quarter finger high tan the that quickly settled down, leaving a thin collar of beige bubbles around the edge of the glass.
S: Light to moderate aromas of chocolate and peanut butter are present in the nose.
T: The taste follows the smell, but has a bit stronger flavors of chocolate and peanut butter. There is a slight amount of bitterness.
M: It feels medium-bodied on the palate and has moderate amount of carbonation.
O: This beer is like a liquid version of a chocolate peanut butter cup, except that it isn't as sweet as the candy.

Serving type: can

I wasn’t quite sure what I’d expect out of this beer, but it tastes and smells exactly like a Reeces Peanutbutter cup. Works perfectly as a dessert beer. It’s not for every occasion m. Maybe a bit heavy but that’s expected.

Brewery Ommegang "All Hallows Treat"
16 fl. oz. can "BEST BY 010723 LOT070722 13:49T1". Sampled on 091022.
$

Notes via stream of consciousness: So what do we have here? It's an Imperial chocolate peanut butter stout at 7.6% alcohol by volume. It doesn't say anything about ingredients on the label so it might just be flavoring. The body is an opaque brown-black and reveals only a glimmer of mahogany brown at the base of the glass when held to the light. The head is a finger's width of tan foam. In the nose I'm getting a lot of peanut and a little bit of milk chocolate. On to the taste... the nuttiness remains but it's no longer dominant. The chocolate that wraps around it is like a combination of milk chocolate and darker chocolate. They're clearly from a flavoring agent but that's fine by me as there are no weird or unusual notes to it. There's a light fruitiness to it as well but that's about it. It's not really roasty, and there's not a lot of bitterness to it. It's sweet but it's not overly sweet, and although you could easily serve this on it's own as a dessert beer or use it as an ingredient in something, you can just as easily enjoy it on its own. How quickly you'll work through it depends on how much you like the sweetness. For me the second half of the glass will definitely be a sipper. Thankfully they didn't add any lactose to it! In the mouth it's medium bodied and smooth with a moderate, fine-bubbled carbonation. On that note, the head died down quicker than I'd have liked but it did leave some nice lacing about the glass so there's that. I think that this is a very nice beer that's fairly accessible. It's not too big nor is it too small, as in lacking flavor, and thus I think it should work for just about everyone. It is a bit one-sided though, but I guess it kind of has to be, right? I mean, they are going for a peanut butter cup thing, right? That's what the label implied to me. I generally buy a few special beers to enjoy on Halloween while the trick or treaters come and go, usually pumpkin beers, and this will make a nice change of pace.
Review #8,245

Bought a single 16oz can $4.99 Village Bottle Shop
144 days before best by date
Snell of peanut butter is strong
Dark black color
Medium-heavy mouthfeel, some creaminess
Medium-low carbonation
Taste of peanut butter, chocolate, black coffee, some bitterness aftertaste, hides alcohol well
Overall an ok beer for the style. I was expecting a strong richer chocolate flavor from this.

Bought a pack of this so I'll definitely be able to revisit it. I hope my opinion changes because so far this is lowkey bad. There's not really a chocolate presence and smelled kind of astringent. The peanut butter is that typical peanut flour taste. Basically just seems like an off version of Left Hands PB Milk Stout which I also think could be better. It's also kind of fruity sweet? Idk. I hope I like it more as I get through it.


2nd can was a smidge better, not fantastic but none of that astringent smell or anything else super weird. Definitely liking it better.

Mercifully, these days, a pint can's contents can be emptied into a clear glass Imperial pint mug. Points should automatically be upgraded over the sea of starchy white foam "heads" brought by almost all modern "IPAs".There's a nice biege head on top of a liquid that's just a little lighter than the typical black coffee brown of a standard stout. The aroma is mostly dark chocolate and roasted peanuts. First off, this drinks less viscose than many stouts and much thinner than the dessert variety. That doesn't have to be a negative. One of the nice things about this brew is the subtleness of the peanut and chocolate flavor additions. They don’t totally override the Belgian Ale aspect, which keeps this in balance with the sweetness that usually accompanies this mixture. In a close decision, this is less sweet enough and has other characteristics that it shouldn't just be a categorized a dessert beer. There are other flavored stouts that deliver this combination of flavors, but they're usually heavy handed in doing so. This is a very pleasant option.

Delicious stuff, this. Glad I picked it up. Fairly dark copper color. Lots of bready malts and caramel sweetness throughout the sip and finish, which is neither dry nor cloying. Really enjoyable example and one I'll seek out again for certain.
A little dark for a Festbier, but still a fantastic brew!
12oz bottle f on Brewers Haven. Clear amber pour, creamy, fluffy white head, thick lacing. Malty, bready aroma. Taste is malty, sweet and finishes with a light peppery snap. ' Tis the season...

Semi clear dark amber appearance.
Around medium carbonation with a slightly thin body.
Aroma is malty dough,dark bread,yeasty, cereal, and grain.
Tqste is very similar to aroma with a mild sweetness balanced with some hop bite.
Overall a very good beer that I would have again.

I took review notes on this in late August, but completely forgot to add a review -- keep this in mind with the best by date of 5-11-23 on the bottles. 12 ounce bottle poured into my tall Becher.

L -- Clear, brassy gold with a meager, but resilient, off-white head.

S -- Slightly doughy bread notes with light herbal spiciness back.

T -- Light caramel up front that folds into a light bread crust character. Finishes with herbal hop spiciness and bitterness through the aftertaste.

F -- Mouthfeel is soft to syrupy with a medium body.

O -- The bread crust character is nice in this beer, but the herbal and bitter hops dominate the palate. Definitely drinkable, but a little lackluster as a Festbier (or Märzen). At least there's little caramel and no roastiness.

Best by May of 2023, 11.2 oz bottle; Attractive deep amber color with whitish head that lingered for duration as thin film, left moderate lacing. Carbonation on the higher side of the scale. I was expecting a lighter style of beer, but nonetheless taste was malt leaning with quick on set of bitterness aftertaste in the aftertaste. Quality brew, had better had and worse.

This here Bitburger Festbier is, according to their website, available, in the U.S., from August until? So, get it when it's available gettin'.
Tasty as all get out, too.
PROST!

Good marzen, i was confused when i saw festbier, then i saw over 6 % abv, which i wouldnt want in a golden lager. to my relief it poured a dark amber, confirmed marzen. and boy is it a malt bomb. almost british like with german malting techniques... not much noble hop presence i wouldve guessed something like fuggle hops if blind tasting. still a good strong dark lager, although heavy on malt flavor, warming wouldnt hurt this very much. might let it develop some further depth. but im not too keen on letting my beers 'bring up to room temp' . again, british like... not my preference. would recommend though. got mollywhopped in a heads up vs. Von Trapp Oktoberfest Lager. That'll tend to happen though as one goes through the offerings of the particular style. V.T. and VT the state, have quality lager production locked.

From an 11.2oz bottle dated best before 5/5/23 into a pint glass.

Pours a murky brownish orange with about a finger and a half of off-white head. Excellent retention and lacing.

Smells of sweet bread a little bit of earth and a touch of caramel.

Taste is bready but sweet-caramel and maybe some honey.

Full bodied mouthfeel for the style. Medium carbonation. Bitter-sweet aftertaste.

There's a lot to this beer. A well made festbier.
Solid beer, but isn't what I would recognize as a festbier, and for the money I'd much rather have Weihenstephan.

1.5 x 330 ml Bottles
Best By: 05-18-2022
Consumed on: 14 July, 2022
Glass: 0.5 L Fest Mug
Serving Temp: low to mid 50s F


Look:
Cloudy and opaque but bright copper. I can distinguish the shadows of my fingers through the glass but not much else. Initial 3-finger creamy off-white head slowly dissipates to a thin but consistent cover. Very good lacing.

Smell:
Toasted (but lightly so) whole wheat bread and biscuits. Light notes of toffee or caramel along with a medium-dark honey. Also faint notes of grass.

Taste:
Wheat bread with toffee and a surprising but actually light spiciness. Very nice. A mild bitterness carries through the sip which finishes dry. The 6.2% ABV is not noticeable at all.

Feel:
Smooth and crisp. Body is medium with a step to the lighter side.

Overall:
This beer isn't your average Festbier/Wiesnbier. As others have stated, it is actually a light Märzen. Or perhaps a cross between a Märzen and a Festbier with more of the Märzen in the mix. And it works. This is a really nice Oktoberfest beer. It drinks well and would pair with German fest food nicely. Bitburger must have learned something from their Oktoberfest collaboration with Sierra Nevada in 2019. Well done, Bitburger! Well done!

Note: When I poured this beer, I noticed some sediment in the bottom of the bottle so I did the 'Hefeweizen Swirl' to get it back into solution in the beer.

12 fl oz brown glass bottle:

Caramel. Nutbread. Pale malt. A bit of amber malt or Vienna. Hints of raisin.

Fairly well attenuated, but not mind blowingly balanced.

B- / WORTHY

For how cheap it is you'd think it was an upscale adjunct lager, lo' and behold it is a good Festbier for Oktoberfest. Not a strict marzen, not a run of the mill bavarian but spot on for the clean crisp taste of a fest bier. Smooth, good brewing water, good malts and good mouth feel. I give it a 4.25. The look I scored 4 because it was not as dark as your standard red lager, but it was not yellow like a 2-row barley crap we have in america. White head, and good aroma made the smell a 4. Taste was well worth the price, i would give this another go and lookforward to Festbeer season. I am stocking up this time.

Pours dark ruddy amber (SRM 12-13). This is much darker than expected and, surprisingly, is it not clear. One inch of creamy pancake batter has an antique white to almond color and is short lived, leaving small patches of lace on a Spaten dimpled mug.

Initially, the aroma is bright. It quickly turns to wheat bread, with toasted grains and light spiciness. With minimal warming, peanut husks come into focus.

While modest, the bitterness and spice are far stronger than expected. Malts still dominate, with mild sweetness. Light toasted grain is similar to cream of wheat. A long, lightly bitter finish is rather grainy. Peanuts show up, again with warmth. With more warmth comes the clear flavor of soft pretzels.

This one has a medium body and a rough texture. Alcohol is as expected, as is the soft carbonation. There is a light astringency throughout.

Bitburger's Festbier is a fine beverage. Still, it is a letdown, if only because I had expected more. It will pair well with soft pretzels and bratwurst, more likely sweet mustard than spicy.
Upfront a breaded taste. Backend is slightly bitter, but good. Would have again.

L: Pours a slightly hazy orangeish copper. Slightly off white head that fades to a ring of bubbles.

S: Malt forward, a bit of spice

T: Follows the nose. Slight bitterness at the end.

F: Medium bodied with medium carbonation. Slightly astringent finish.

O: Pretty good seasonal

I got a 6pck of this beer from my local meijer store. It poured a hazy amber with white head that is leaving a spotty lace. The scent had subtle malt notes with bittering hop highlights. The taste was nicely balanced and easy to drink with light crisp caramel malt base with a bittering hop finish. The mouthfeel was lighter in body with good carbonation. Overall it is a solid great beer.

I'm shocked that this is the #1 rated Festbier. This looks and tastes like a Märzen. If you can still find them, pour a Paulaner or Weihenstephaner Festbier in one glass and the Bitburger in another.

It's apples and oranges. This beer is tasty. But if you're hankering for a Wiesn style Octoberfest beer, this one isn't going to scratch you where it itches.

My scoring ignores the incorrect designation of this beer as a Wiesen. I don't know what the folks at Bitburger were thinking.

Clear light amber, with just over one finger of white head, that leaves a thin ring and a few spots of lacing.

Smell is some sweet toasted grain, biscuity malt , slight floral aroma, and occasional hints of caramel and toffee.

Taste is mostly light toffee and caramel, with some lingering moderate noble hop spiciness coming in later. Moderately bitter. Seems more like a marzen.

Feel is light-medium, initially lightly slick, then with moderate finely-sharp carbonation tingle. Leaves the tongue feeling lightly coated.

Overall, pretty good. Comes across more as a light marzen, rather than a festbier/wiesnbier. Once the mind was adjusted to that, I enjoyed it. Though not in my top-tier favorites, I expect that I'll get at least a 6er next Oktoberfest season.

330ml bottle into a pint glass. Best by 5/19/22, so thiscyears release.

Looks decent in the glass. Mid golden body that's a bit cloudy. Small white head shrinks to a ring and covering, not much lacing.

Nice malty aroma.

On tasting, was initially surprised by the strength of the caramel malt. However, this one quickly grew on me. There is a light spice note, it's on the dry side, but collectively one of those beers where you reach for the next mouthful quicker than you probably should.

Mouth above medium, finish initially sweet then dry with a a light spice left laying on the tongue.

Overall, another festbier that will go on next years want list.

L - Hazy copper with a tan head that dissipates somewhat slowly leaving behind some lacing - a solid amount of sediment (might just be a bad batch)
S - Malty with some caramel notes along with some hop notes and spices
T - Bready malt forward and throughout with caramel notes throughout along with some hop and spice notes. Some earthy notes as well
F - Light to medium bodied with a moderate amount of carbonation
O - A pretty good festbier, but there are other German brew out there that are better

The European 11.2 bottle poured into the 20oz. weizen glass. This is an orange tinted brew, slightly hazy, high end carbonation, that can be admired while held up to the light. There is a one finger head of white foam that does not want to disappear!
The aroma is very noticeable from a distance. The bread malts are what I am picking up, nice and sweet!
The flavor follows the nose, sweet fresh bread with a light bitter finish, cutting the sweetness perfectly. There is a touch of dryness at the end of the sip along with some pepper spice.
The carbonation adds a little tingle to the sip. The mouthfeel is medium+. I enjoyed this brew and would never turn one down. October is waning and my fest beers are almost gone. This one surprised me, it may be a tad more full than other fest beers. That is a bonus for me as I like the heavy brews!

Poured from a bottle into a pint glass. Pours orange red with a fluffy white head. Smells of bright fruit and darker roasted grain, nice balance. Tastes of darker roasted grain with very nice bright fruit, very full and bright. Beer is light bodied and easy drinking, good carbonation. Overall, a very good beer.

Slightly cloudy light copper with a healthy white head. Smell is a little subdued, mostly floral hops with some toasted malts.
Surprisingly hop forward for the style which perfectly compliments the sweeter caramel malts. This makes the beer dangerously drinkable. I’ve been on a journey as far as this style goes, I’ve had 30+ to date. So far this is my favorite. The mouthfeel is medium light. If you like Oktoberfest/Marzen styles this is outstanding.

Had on tap at Lucero's Tavern IV

On arrival, a 2 finger slightly fizzy head was present and slowly became rocky, but had a surprisingly good head retention, and formed lacing. Body is a brownish amber with lively fine carbonation.

I don't know if this is a shitty keg or what, but the aroma reminds me of pale super cheap bullshit malt liquor from Anhueser Busch. Super funky and really not clean at all. Aroma is reminiscent of gym socks with a vague hint of dark malt... maybe.

Taste is unfortunately similar to the aroma. This is like having sex in a canoe unfortunately, with a light malty heaviness that is easily confused for the funk that is present. This might even taste a bit skunky stupidly. I expected better.

Feel is slightly drying with a medium quick finish making all the bad parts of this beer not as bad, but a quick finish and high drinkability can't make up for the overall low quality in this beer. Decent feel but it's hard to feel good when you're smelling this.

Overall I'm not sure if this is just an old keg or if my bias against Dos Equis is justified, but this might be the worst Vienna Lager I've had in my life. I'd much rather have Victoria, or even Modelo Negra. Why does this exist? To be a light beer for people who don't want to bee seen drinking light beers?
This beer is delicious! Anybody that says it is very plain and watered down is a fucking idiot! It has more flavor than any of the other major beer manufactures on the market!

Found in the fridge as a six-pack of 12oz bottles. Poured into a chardonnay glass.

L - Amber and clear, with a one-finger off-white head. Great lacing.
S - Cracker and toffee. Toast and caramel.
T - Matches nose exactly. Not too much else.
F - Light-bodied, with mild carbonation. More dry than what I would've imagined.
O - Disappointing, but objectively not bad. Not for me, but I can see the appeal. Worth a try.

Had most recently at Papito's Grill, Ridgeland, Mississippi, on draft into large ("Jumbo") mug.

Pours up deep amber with clarity and a lovely, 1-finger off-white head, with good retention, leaving nice sketchy lace down the mug. Initial off-putting aroma of sweet corn, but then a little caramel malt takes over, and continues. Begins sweet but clean (mild carbonation), then mild caramel malt, and some nice mild (stone?) fruit, before a creamy, slightly-drying but mostly not-there finish.

Much better than I expected, pouring up beautifully, with the only thing truly wrong being the initial sweet corn aroma, and less so a rather weak but creamy finish.

L: Pours a amber red color with a khaki tan head and some lacing on the glass.

S: Notes of chocolate and caramel, a mostly malt.

T: Light bittersweet chocolate, with some toasted bread and a touch of malt. Nicely drinkable

F: Smooth and drinkable.

O: Overall, this is a nice drinkable mass produced beer.
Its very plain, and feels watered down. Drinkable nonetheless.

Clear Jurassic amber with a moderate khaki foam head settling to a thick level blanket with a collar that leaves some thin drooping legs.

A firm carbonation delivers faintly toasty bread and hints of almond that go down swimmingly after a full day of hiking. A touch of tobacco comes out on the exhale after the just dry finish.

Ambar is really subtle and totally chuggable with no detectable off-notes, making for an overall better beer than their lager.

I never had the OG Ambar so I have no idea how this Especial is different. Well, this is not a Vienna Lager, at least that is clear. Obviously it tries to be a Dark Lager - it does remind you of that by the way it smells, looks and tastes. It does taste okay in the first monent but then BAM! it all starts fading away. A few minutes into the beer and it starts tasting and feeling like bitter water. And most of the time the arona was more like bread, no beer or hops, just bread.
Funny beer, I like Dos Equis for what it is, a cerveza. Maybe I should try the “real” ambar next - because this one wasn’t really cutting it.
Very great taste and inexpensive beer!
A generic Mexican lager.

Best By date : June 2022. Labeled "Ambar Especial" . Assume this is the same beer, as it's got the same abv, & blurb on the bottom of the label .

Clear , slightly orangey chestnut-brown, with slight, quickly-dissipating light tan head.

Smell is slight toffee and caramel, with a bit of fresh biscuity malt aroma when swirled. Not bad, just not much there.

Taste is light toasted nuts, and slight bread crust. A bit of tang, and weak amaretto flavor shows up as it warms to 50F(+/-) . Again, not bad, just not much there.

Feel is light, smooth, and slightly watery just before the light, very,very fine carbonation kicks in. Drying finish, that lingers afterward.

Overall, not bad, and no off-flavors, just kind of weak. Inoffensive enough to enjoy, if no other decent options available, especially in hot weather. Certainly better than its corn-laden brethren in the Light Industrial Lager vein. I'd rather have Yuengling or Negra Modelo though. ymmv

Poured into a Seattle Beer Week pint glass. Pour a medium to dark coppery amber with fine, two finger white head with great retention and thick lacing. Aroma of grainy and bready malt, light grassy hops, a little bit minerally. Flavor starts with pale and lightly caramel malt with some evidence of corn, light grassy hops; finishes with light grassy hops and thin malt. Medium bodied with light creaminess. I actually picked this up when finding it singled, thinking it was the regular lager, which I hadn't reviewed. (It is now named "Ambar Especial"). It looks and tastes better than I remember the regular Dos Equis, which was a mediocre adjunct lager. It looks great in the glass, aroma is OK and the taste starts pretty decent, but thins out quickly into a finish that is satisfactory but tastes almost watered down. Expectations were low, and this is pedestrian brewing, but I have to say I'd prefer this in a pinch over the thin grassy regular lager. Nothing special, but I would grab one at a restaurant if nothing else was appealing.
Mexican restaurant, Port Charlotte, teied something new. One of the few beers that I didn't want to finish.

12 ounce bottle in an Imperial style pint glass. It’s best by date is January 20, 2022 so i expect that it’s fresh.

Nice looking pour, deep golden amber color with a 1f dense linen colored cap that drops to a film and leaves soapy lacing.

Smell of sweet risen dough and roasted grain. There are caramel and grassy aromas, too.

Flavors of caramel malts and light grassy grain. No unpleasant aftertaste.

It’s light and smooth. A little bit sweet. Good carbonation, clean finish, lingering caramel.

I needed a Vienna style lager for a recipe that I cooked today so this is what I found. I drank it for fun and it’s better than I expected.
This wasn't bad, im not sure if I had Ambar or Ambar especial(new formula) though. Either way I guess it was solidly okay, If that makes sense

330 ml bottle, from Vaaland, Bryne. ABV is 4.5%. Copper to amber colour, moderate white head. Moderate aroma, some fruit, grass and caramel. The flavour is at least more malty than the Especial, a little fruit and caramel again, but is otherwise rather bland and boring, with minimal hops.
The only Mexican Beer that I enjoy and always the one ordered when out to eat. Not at all bitter, easy drinker. Perfect for an afternoon in the sun.

A: The beer is nearly clear yellow in color and has a light amount of visible carbonation. It poured with a quarter finger high white head that died down, leaving a collar of lacing down the lower edges of the glass and t thin film of bubbles covering the surface.
S: Moderate aromas of grapefruit, orange and pine resin are present in the nose along with notes of pineapple.
T: The taste follows the smell, except that the flavors of pine resin are a bit stronger and there are also notes of caramel and hints of mango. The hops contribute a moderate amount of bitterness.
M: It feels medium-bodied and crisp on the palate with a moderate amount of carbonation.
O: The aromas and flavors from the hops are both very prominent and complex in this IPA. It is a nice one to sip and savor.

Serving type: can

This is my kind of IPA. I seem to enjoy all of the Lawson's IPAs I try. This reminds me of Hopzilla but I haven't had that in a while. The 7%$ ABV is ideal in my opinion and the flavor and balance is great. yb

Pours a relatively clear orange-tinted gold. Solid effervescence. Two-plus fingers of off-white head. Great retention, uneven dissipation and sudsy lacing.

Orange citrus, white pepper and light skunky weed in the nose.

The taste follows closely with syrupy orange, pineapple and light stank and some moderate bitterness.

Soft, medium bodied feel with soft carbonation.

Reminds me of a baby version of Triple Sunshine. Very enjoyable.

Consumed 8/19/22

Medium gold with orange hues, hazy but not turbid, pours with a medium sized off-white head, retains a few wisps and a small collar
An aggressive mix of a lot of hops, lots of citrus, orange and grapefruit juice, rind, orange marmalade, floral citrus, herbaceous and green hops, touch of resin, some dank notes, some stone fruit, over-ripe tropical fruit, something that smells like a cross between cherry skin and leather, pale malts, caramel malts, biscuit, above-average bitterness, more alcohol heat than I would expect for 7% but it works with the flavor profile
Medium body, smooth if not a little oily, medium carbonation

Lawson's really missed an opportunity to name this Liquid Hopcelot for the small demographic that would find the name amusing. Like Liquid Ocelot and many plot elements of Metal Gear Solid 4, I do not quite grasp what is happening with this beer. It's aggressive and hoppy, but it drinks like an out-of-focus picture. It kind of tastes like a blend of every IPA in Lawson's lineup. Pretty good.

16 oz. Can
CANNED ON: 07/19/22

Poured into a Tree House glass a very nice hazy pale yellow color, very nice carbonation, with a very nice thick/creamy two-finger off-white head, which also leaves some very nice sticky lacing behind. The nose is hoppy, malty, with a pretty nice citrus complex (orange, tangerine, grapefruit, pineapple, mango, peach, papaya, guava), pretty nice diesel like. The taste is pretty nice hoppy, malty, with a pretty nice citrus complex (orange, tangerine, grapefruit, pineapple, mango, peach, papaya, guava), pretty nice diesel like. Medium body, ABV hidden very nicely, with a nice little dry/bitter finish. Overall, this is a pretty tasty beer. Orange Julius! Addictive! MilkShake!
LOVE

Pours clear gold color with a billowing 2 finger thick off-white colored foamy head that dissipated very slowly and left nice foamy lacing coating the glass. Smells of caramel, lemon zest, biscuit, grapefruit, peppery spices, dry citrus hops, orange peel and piney notes. Smells more like a west coast IPA than a NE-IPA. Tastes like it smells with the malty sweetness kicking things off and then a combo of biscuit, grapefruit, caramel, lemon zest, peppery spices, graham cracker, dry citrus hops, orange peel, tangerine and piney notes. It's light, crisp and refreshing, with mild carbonation and no sign of the 7% ABV. I was hoping it would be juicier in the NE-IPA style since it's from Vermont, but this is still a high quality IPA.

Canned on: 07-05-22

A - Light medium gold color with nice clarity, low carbonation, and dense bright white lacing.

S - Spicy citrus and tropical fruit, peppery fruit rind, and resiny pine.

T - Spicy citrus from start to finish, period. Citrus, spicy tropical fruit rind, peppery spice, and resiny pine bitterness underneath. Nice balanced finish.

M - Medium body with soft prickly carbonation and predominantly dry finish on the tongue.

O - Dig the spicy personality of this beer.

Pours a golden straw color with a finger of head. The nose has earthy and dank hoppiness with some citrus in the background. The flavor is odd for an IPA (not in a bad way) - hearty maltiness with grassy and herbal qualities. The finish has decent bitterness.
When I can't get Heady Topper, Hopcelot is a worthy substitute -- and in the spirit of HT, I drink it from the can. It's bright, hoppy, and refreshing. Drink it cold and fresh if you can. Stellar!

Half fingers worth of crisp off white colored froth... Modest retention... Color is a vibrant gold with an orangish hue... Huge tropical fruit nose... Oranges, mangoes and assorted other citrus... The palate takes on a more earthy and distinctly piney character... Mouthfeel is medium bodied with distinctive and spry carbonation... Interesting and enjoyable brew with lots of unique characteristics...

Lawson's Finest Liquids "Hopcelot"
16 fl. oz. can "CANNED ON: 07/05/22 FINEST FRESHEST" and sampled on 07/23/2022
$19.19/4-pk @ Javies Beverage, Phila., PA

Notes via stream of consciousness: It's poured a just slightly hazy golden body beneath a full head of white foam. The aroma clearly shows that there are some "dank" hops in play, but it's also earthy, herbal, floral, and piney. Interesting. It smells kind of like a damp forest. On to the taste... I didn't get the malt in the aroma but it's certainly here. It's sweetish and grainy, and I'm guessing that it's probably Pilsner malt. There's a grassiness to it that suggests Pilsner malt but it's pretty strong so it's got to be coming from hops too. That could be throwing me off on the malt although that richer graininess is still there. The hops remain earthy, herbal, floral and piney but there's also some fruitiness to it. I'm thinking gooseberry, white grape, passionfruit, nectarine, sweet berries, apple, pear, a bit of citrus, some apricot, and a touch of plum. My guesses for hop varieties would be Nelson Sauvin, Mosaic, and Simcoe although this beer uses 8 different hops so there have to be more. Ahh, you know what else might be in here? Summit hops.
