The mix of flavors takes the taste to the end and leave one with a sweeter lightly toasted taste to linger on the tongue.
Mouthfeel – The body of the brew is average in thickness and creaminess with a carbonation level that is on the average side as well. For the sweeter malt flavors of the brew the feel is good and makes for a nice easy sipper.
Overall – A rather nice very easy drinking Oktoberfest.
It's smooth, very mildly sweet, crisp, refreshing. I tried it warm and cold since it is a German beer and cold is significantly better. There's no butter taste to this beer.

Poured from 12oz can into a mug. Canned 7/21/21.

Appearance: good golden-orange hue with a tiny touch of haze and a thin layer of fizzy white foam. The color is outstanding but the head dissipated too quickly.

Smell: richly malty with notes of dark bread and molasses. Perhaps a tad sweet, but still, very nice.

Taste: bready, a bit toasty, and a bit biscuity. There's a light but balanced bitterness; the overall effect seems very autumnal to me (as one might expect). I'm not usually a fan of the biscuity character in malt, but here it adds an appropriate dimension to a beer of this style.

Mouthfeel: medium body with a decent level of carbonation and creaminess.

Overall: a good example of the style, I think. Not sure what caused the head to die so quickly, but other than that, it's a good quaff.

From the bottom of the can: "CANNED ON 07/30/21 5511"

Appearance: The body of the beer is a medium shade of copper towards the middle and a lighter shade of amber at the edge. It has moderate clarity with some light haze. It has a short white head that fades out to a medium white ring and a film on the surface.

Aroma: There are notes of cherry and a light oak character mixed with crushed acorn and walnut.

Taste: Cherry comes through with a light bit of caramel up front. In the middle there is a light roasted nut character with a hint of toasted bread. The back of the mouth has more of the same nuttiness that the middle does. Aftertaste has a light caramel sweetness.

Mouthfeel: It feels medium-light on the palate and watery. Very light toasted bitterness. It doesn't cling well to the palate or have much of an impact on it. It has a light bit of slickness which feels off for the style.

Overall: It feels like the average attempt at an Oktoberfestbier but it lacks texture, complexity, cohesiveness, and it doesn't look the greatest in a glass. It's drinkable and I probably wouldn't turn one down for free but it isn't something I'd likely buy again or recommend.

12 oz can. Pours amber with tall, long-lasting, fluffy white head and soda-like carbonation. Aroma is of grassy hops and caramel malt. Body is full and crisp. Grassy hops and caramel malt nicely balanced on the palate, hint of spices. Finish is long and dry. Nice brew.

Pours a clear beautiful golden color however with not much head or lacing not good on that. Smell is baked bread malts some fruits and hops ..not feeling this one. taste is better grainy fruity malty with some hops nice malt back bone . Mouth feel had a mettalic taste it had low carbonation. Wow tough to finish from such an esteemed brewer , not even close to style a mess IMO

Canned on 07/08/21 and consumed mid-August 2021. Pumped when I see any new Oktoberfest and since it’s from AleSmith, I didn’t even hesitate grabbing a 6er from the shelf. Gorgeous amber color. Drinks so well, perfectly executed. Deliciously grainy, bready, and finished with caramel malt. Stellar!

Pours a beautiful clear amber orange with a rather short lived smallish cream colored head. Aroma is bready and caramel malts. Flavor follows the nose sweet roasted caramel malt, some European hop, and rye bread. Feel is medium bodied, and adequately carbonated. Overall a fantastic beer albeit at a premium cost.

Type: 12-oz. can
Reviewed as: Marzen / Oktoberfest
Glass: Gordon Biersch .5L Stein
Price: $1.67
From: From: Trader Joe’s in College Area (San Diego), Calif.
Purchased: Sept. 25, 2020
Consumed: Oct. 1, 2020
Misc.: Canned on Sept. 3, 2020

Grabbed a can of this, a bunch of other stuff and a 6-pack of something else on a recent trip to Trader Joe’s. AleSmith does almost everything well (except hoppy beers to me, but everything else), so I was looking to try this. Was actually surprised that I hadn’t reviewed this before, let alone checked into it on Beer Advocate. Back of the can read, “This German-style Marzen Lager is our take on a classic Oktoberfest offering. AleSchmidt Oktoberfest is characterized by a clean, elegant, and toasty malt character. Prost!”

Poured a dark amber clear color with 3-to-4 fingers of khaki white rocky-to-frothy head, which dissipated quickly. Lots of bubble streams coming up from the bottom of the glass. Bad watery, spotty lacing. Average retention. (Sight - 3.25)

Smelled Outback bread, honey, wheat, sweet grain, mixed nuts, toasted malts, chewy caramel, toasted biscuit and graham cracker. Not quite as good from the can but got some earthier malts with some leathery toffee notes. (Smell - 4.00)

Tasted a little better than the nose but followed for the most part. A very clean beer. Got Outback bread, honey, wheat, sweet grain, toasted malts, chewy caramel, mixed nuts, Wheat Thins, toasted biscuit, leathery toffee, hints of tobacco and graham cracker. (Taste - 4.25)

Medium body. Creamy texture. Average carbonation. Long, toasty finish. (Feel - 4.25)

This was an excellent Oktoberfest beer, something I would expect from AleSmith. (Overall - 4.25)

4.13 | 92 | A-

Lovely coppery amber color with a handsome pile of foam in the Leute Bokbier glass. Quite malty and fragrant with roasted grain. Odd gummy flavor that seems to be a feature of some of these Märzen style beers. Hint of apples, even candy apple as the malt is quite sweet.

Plenty of raw flavors and the grainy finish. I don't rate this with my favorite Oktoberfest favorites. There is a bitterish metallic aftertaste that I don't find very appealing. Still it's well made and quite quaffable. From the 12 oz can.

12 oz can poured into a pint glass. The AleSchmidt pours a clear copper with a thin cap of foam. Decent bubble formation from the bottom of the glass but retention is lighter than hoped for.

Nose is slightly malt forward for the color yet not so much as for most American versions of the style. I think festbier is quite different than Marzen in style. This one is squarely in the middle. Offering some complex malts but without the easy and quick blast of gringo marzen/oktoberfest beers with a 2row base and a sloppy caramel malt boost. And that I appreciate. Still I'm not picking up the pils/munich I seek either. Does offer a decent finish but the muddled malt notes trounce the cleaner malt and hop notes this dude seeks. Better than many. Go to Munich for festbier
A good German beer, but I prefer something more bready. So for extra characters, this is a good German beer that is delightful to drink but not worth the cost.

Poured from a stovepipe can into a spieglau IPA glass.

On the pour nearly 4 fingers of fine white head formed that peeks out over top of the glass. Body is lightly hazy woth some hop sediment and is an orange brass hue. Some lacing is left.

Aroma is quite tropical and fruity woth a bit of darkness on the back. Quite a bit of citrus on this one and maybe even some guava. Like a better voodoo ranger, but not game changing.

Taste follows the aroma, and stays quite clean and fruity, but there is a definite sweetness and alcohol that gives away the abv. The hop bitterness creeps in as the sweetness fades, making this relatively balanced although the sweet and bitter don't happen at the same time.

Feel is big but still refreshingly hoppy and bright. The finish is long and quite full bodied, and as the sweetness fades it almost feels like it slowly coats your tongue. This one's pretty fun to drink but there are some heavy feelings that make me knock a few points.

Overall this is pretty good and also pretty predictable. Clean and hoppy with big tropical and fruity vibes as well as a solid dose of dank and bitterness. A bit heavy but solid quality.
I don't like it at all.

Look: Gold, decent head

Smell: Citrus! Oranges and pineapple mainly, smells amazing

Taste: Oh my, this is the best IPA ive ever tasted. Its delicious

Feel: Very little aftertaste for this one, which I think is good for an IPA

Overall: This is an amazing IPA, try it!

Really tasty, well balanced, nice mixture of pine, bitterness. Outstanding West Coast style IPA. Packs a wallop at 8.2 ABV, but you don't really taste the booze. Only drawback is sometimes has a slightly sweet hint late in the drink.

For a widely distributed IPA, ‘The Dust’ is remarkably decent. It’s an everyday quaff that ya don’t feel cheap about offering to a friend.
Bits of just-right all around: hoppy and piney, citrusy and crisp, nice carbonation, refreshing, not too strong. Maybe a little weak in the feel catagory.
Had it on Draft, in bottles too.
I like.,.,

It's West Coast all the way, but with an herbal funk which tames down the typical piney notes that I get from something like Two Bells. Really excellent palate with just a hint of tropical fruit. Hard to believe the high ABV as it drinks like a session ale. Exceptional.

Damn, that's a good IPA. Hop forward, not too bitter but definitely bitter enough. Pours gold with light lacing. Smell is super citrusy - pineapple, orange and coriander. And it packs a punch in the abv department without being boozy.
Pours a cloudy gold, (it's getting dark), white head some nice lacing. Boogar machine detects some citrus and melon, as do the taste buds. Solid malty backbone balances this nicely. Tasty stuff.

A nice IPA from an unlikely city - Seattle. During a contract there, I tasted all of their IPAs - and didn't like a one. But I missed this particular IPA.

A cloudy golden pour with a nice frothy white head. The hop smell and taste is robust with grapefruit notes. The 8.2% ABV doesn't come across at all. It feels like a nice session IPA at 6%. Enjoy!

Pour is golden amber, a little cloudy. Smells a little floral and pine spice. Taste has a good mix of malt & hops that I would say dominate. It has a bit of bitterness, piney resin spice and a little fruity flavor too. Solid brew!
One of the best IPAs I've ever had, and a go-to supermarket beer.
Solid
This is a VERY Citra-forward DIPA so if you don't like Citra, steer clear. Having said that, it's delicious. Crisp and refreshing considering it clocks in at 8.2%.

Draft in a 16oz shaker glass at a pizza place. Color is a bit dark, looks like a typical hazy, but a bit darker. Smell is a light, citrus hoppy. Taste is fresh, lemon is up front with other citrus flavors on the back side of the taste. The malts are in the back which tends to smooth out any hop bitterness with just a touch of sweetness. The mouth feel is a bit thin, in particular with the abv level. Overall was a bit surprised with this beer.

Poured from a 4 months old bottle. Slightly hazy, as a good IPA should be, IMO. Good head and lacing.
I love how unpretentious this beer is, just good old hops and a lot of malt flavor to back that up. It's bitter, and the hop oils coat and stay in your tongue for a while; but this is not a bad thing. Besides, by the time you realize this is happening, you don't care anymore from that 8.2 ABV.
One of the best beers I've had.
Excellent ipa avaliable at a wide range of retailers

Having a bottle of this on a lazy day of avoiding the cold outside has proven to be a great idea. I knew my controversial plan was the right one when the morning sun shone thru my newly poured beer, highlighting the big head and sticky lace, and slightly hazy yet golden elixir of life. The crispy hops bite has shown itself as being a reasonable substitute for coffee on such a glorious morning. And I even think I might have seen an alien.

And, as an important and prominent member of beeradvocate.com, I'd like to mention to our new alien overlords that I can help round up others to toil in the underground sugar mines.

Cheers to Elysian!

2022 poured cool to a smalll snifter. Dark deep brown with a fast-burning half-finger tan head. Nose is mild, mostly oaky wood char and some light leather. Flavor is a prominent wet bourbon wood followed by a, somewhat oxymoronically, crisp malt base. That is, it is deep and dark, but the carbonation and whatever hop profile used keeps it from delving into the ominous flavor profile. Mouthfeel is medium and slightly brisk, with a fair amount of drying on the back. The 12.7% ABV does not hide at all, but is never a hot distraction.

Bottled on: 4-25-22

A - Pitch black pour with a soliud layer of creamy caramel colored foam.

S - Chocolate char, oak, Bourbon, and some light vanilla on the nose.

T - Big chocolate roast with some char, Bourbon, vanilla, and oak. There's a big lingering oak/Bourbon presence after the sip with a little bit of chocolate char in the mix. (There's a tad bit of cherry poking through as well.)

M - Medium body with a little bit of thinness around the edges and some alcohol warming in the back of the throat on the first few sips.

O - Needs a little more chocolate roast and less Bourbon presence.

Poured from a bottle into a snifter
Appearance – The beer ours a deep brown, nearly black color with a one finger head of brown foam. The thickness of the brew can be seen when swirling the beer in the glass. Thick sticky fingers of beer cling to the sides of the glass upon swirling, with the slowly receding to the bottom of the snifter. The head that was present upon pouring fades rather fast, leaving a light level of lace on the sides of the glass.
Smell – The aroma is massive of a rich roasted and toasted malt smell that is accompanied by tons of chocolate and sweet caramel and molasses. Along with these aromas comes a nice bourbon and woody smell that has notes of leather and smoke mixed within. Other sweeter smells of prune and plum as well as a good showing of vanilla.
Taste – The taste starts out with a semi sweet cocoa and heavily roasted and toasted malt flavor. The sweet upfront is mainly of the brown sugar and molasses nature but has a little bit of a dark fruit flavor of raisin and prune. There is a nice presence of a smooth vanilla flavor as well, that compliments the sweet rather nicely. Right from the start, the bourbon and oak can be appreciated as well, both of which get stronger as the taste advances forward on the tongue. Along with the bourbon getting stronger, so too comes a bit of bitter coffee and some char flavors. At the end the bourbon, oak, and char surge and are accompanied by a bit of leather, leaving one with a nice rich, not too sweet, but nice and warming taste to linger on the tongue.
Mouthfeel – The body of the brew is thick and creamy with a carbonation level that is low. For the mix of dark, roast, booze, and sweet the feel is great and makes for one nice pleasant sipper.
Overall – A rather nice bourbon barrel aged stout. Rather balanced, as it is not too heavy in any one of its flavor attributes. Overall, very nice.

Its quite odd to see a barrel-aged series beer from Avery to be so light, ordinary and normal. Simply an Imperial Stout aged for only six months in those barrels, this mere 12.7% stout shows quite the restraint.

Very dark brown and flirting with blackness, Imperialis kicks off with a light tan skirt of froth. With a roasty, toasty, spicy and cola-like scent, the beer's aromatics hinge on chocolate, booze soaked oak, dark fruit, vanilla and caramel. Similarly in taste, its early impressions are robust and sweet with caramel, vanilla, toasted coconut, chocolate and dry molasses.

The spices quickly take over the sweetness as the dark ale embarks upon the middle palate. Malt dominance dries to a coffee, cocoa and cola nut character for a taste that backs off of the heavy and robust char of espresso or campfire. Moderately bitter in a late and woodsy impression, the oak tannins and booze flavors leave a late taste of vanilla, cola, roasted red grape and lacquer on the tongue.

Full bodied but not as heavy as those that we have become accustomed, there's a relaxed sense of drinkability that comes with the slightly lackluster stout. Finishing nutty, spicy and with a long Kona-like coffee flavor, the ale is basically a beer's version of affogato in a glass.

bottled 4/25/22. drank 8/13/22
Pour is black with about a finger of khaki head. decent retention. fades to a little cap on the glass. Some lacing.
Nose is cocoa, oak, vanilla,
Taste follows. chocolate, vanilla, coffee, fudge, subtle bourbon becomes more pronounced as the beer warms, a bit of roasted malt. light alcohol heat. Hint of dark stone fruit? Cherry?

Not my favorite Avery stout, but a good bargain and about what I expected for the price. The nearly black color and brown foam is quite enticing. The taste is mostly oaken bourbon and vanilla and cherry, with roasted malts and char, ethanol, slight sweetness, and a hint of chocolate. Its a bit boozy and has some rough edges. Addition of something like cherries or chocolate would probably take this over the top, but as is it is quite nice and grows on you as you drink it.

Deep, dark brown body, opaque; thick and densely spongy head, light khaki color; thick, sticky sheets of foam curtain the glass. Rich, dark chocolate and cocoa aroma; very light char note. Rich dark malt flavor; baker's and milk chocolate plus cocoa; bold whiskey presence; low bitterness; moderate alcohol phenol presence; very light oak note. Heavy mouthfeel yet soft and velvety on the palate; huge boozy heat offsets the residual sugars.

This is a very likeable barrel aged imperial stout. The base beer is righteous while the bourbon barrel character cuts through like a healthy neat shot of your favorite straight whiskey. Maybe a little hot on the palate, but I'm thinking some judicious bottle aging will mellow this one out for the better.

Pouring temperature: 51 °F; bottling data: APR 25 2022

Poured at fridge temp into my SBG glass, it's a cola-esque light/deep brown and settles into dark black..like every good stout.
Smell and taste is delicious cacao, coffee, perfect barrel to base taste ratio, vanilla,oak, dark fruit and dark malts. All this comes together very well and i hope they do more of these 20 dollar 4 packs.
I love this beer . I'll keep buying this over and over.
This is a single i got for 5 dollars, still have 2 from the 4 pack i purchased last week.

Another winner from Avery

Brown in color with a murky complexion. There’s a fingernail of brown around the rim and covering a quarter of the top. The aroma is of orange peel, bourbon, raisins, and vanilla. I’m tasting bourbon, vanilla, and orange. The mouth is dry, somewhat dense, and a bit boozy.

Bottled 7/7/21, enjoyed 9/13/22 - Although it has a fairly high ABV, not sure this is meant to be cellared. So consider the aging if you read this.
Poured copper, bright reddish copper with very active carbonation but little head and no lacing.
Aroma was almost lost on my damaged nose completely, very mild. A bit of malts gets through and an indiscernible sweetness rather after the sniff. Hmmm.
The taste was very good actually, the sweetness found its way to the front, a bit of vanilla, touch of cherries and a hint of orange. All wrapped up in bourbon. At least to start with, after a few minutes it settles down and the rest of the flavors are back. I think I need to get a new one and try it fresh.
The feel was rather viscous, but well suited for a BA bourbon based malt beverage (okay, beer)
Tasty, quite tasty.

Poured a seethru copper body with minimal head. Aroma is mild with notes of caramel, toffee and biscuit. Fuller-bodied beer that is dry, slightly bready, has a nominal toffee sweetness with a hint of cherry and hides the ABV well. Pretty easy to drink with no bitterness...not much else to say as it seems to just a be a "regular beer".

Day was when I would hunt down any Founders barrel aged release, but those days are years gone. Experimental sounding 12 oz. bottle up & split with the wife.

The pour is more copper than copper, with about as much life. The nose is vaguely sweet & unremarkable.

Highball Drifter is surprisingly tame. Delicate oranges shake hands with gentle bitters & a low level of bourbon. Sweetness winds throughout with a touch of vanilla on the finish. Alcohol sneaks up on one. Glad I split this itty bitty bottle.

This is a beer that tastes like it was brewed not to offend. Anyone. Ever. Decent enough.

Highball Drifter from Founders. Purchased from Franklin Beer Company, Franklin, PA, 12/08/22 for $ 14.50(Including tax)/four-pack of 12 oz bottles ($ 0.30/oz). On room-temperature shelf at store and stored at 37 degrees at home. Reviewed 26/08/22. Note that I use DD/MM/YY protocol.
Stamped “BOTTLED ON 06.09.22” on the rear label. Served at 51.9 degrees in a hand washed and dried Jester King Snifter. Final temperature 58.8 degrees.
Appearance – 3.
First pour – Medium Amber (SRM 12), CLEAR.
Body – Brown (SRM 20), opaque. Under direct light, same. When rear-lite, ruby and clear.
Head – Average (Maximum two cm, aggressive center pour), wheat, high density, short retention, receding to a 0.5 to 2.5 mm ring of tiny bubbles constantly being renewed by effervescence (No crown per se) and a small island for a cap.
Lacing – None.
Aroma – 3.25 – Not much, just a weak fruitiness. No malt, no hops, no yeast.
Flavor – 4.5 – Begins slightly sweet and generally citrus fruity, no malt, no hops, no yeast. No ethanol (11 % ABV as marked on label) aroma or taste. No distinct cherry or orange; instead, a mulled yet flavorful blend. Bourbon is not distinct but ties all the flavors together. Moderate lower gastric warming. No dimethylsulfide or diacetyl.
Palate – 3.5 – Medium, slightly thicker than water, lively carbonation.
Final impression and summation: 4.5 This far, this is probably my favorite from the Bottle Shop series, although I’ve never had a highball. The flavor is well-blended and tasty, with enough linalool (and hidden ethanol) to sedate. I’m headed to my local distributor later to pick up a case!

Pours a deep ruby with minimal head and lacing.

A bit of bourbon and oak and something sweet on the nose.

The taste is loaded with bourbon and orange. It's very sweet with cherry and oak. on the finish. The orange flavor really pops. You can taste the 11% abv also.

The mouthfeel is low carbonation the medium body.

I love an old fashioned with lots of citrus, so I'm really enjoying this. If you hate bourbon cocktails or orange, it's probably not for you.
Malty, orangey, somewhat sweet with added notes of caramel and molasses. Pretty smooth.

The orange flavor is going to divide folks on this one; it is strong and unlike anything I’ve had in a beer before. It looks like a strong ale, dark ruby-brown in color with nice beige foam and lacing. It tastes like a super sweet strong ale with added orange and whiskey barrel. Notes of orange, cherry, caramel, yeasty malts, ethanol, raisin, plumb, vanilla, oak, with slight hints of cola, nutmeg, coriander, tobacco. I can’t decide if this is a great new experiment or a cloying and artificial tasting drain pour. I’m confused by this more than anything.

Pours a clear brown with a ruby tint. Thin off-white short-lived head that leaves nice leggings when swirled. Aroma is oak, vanilla, caramel, bourbon and a hint of orange. Flavor follows the nose, plus now I'm getting the cherry. Sipper drinks much like an English style barleywine which is one of my favorite styles. Feel is medium bodied, without much carbonation. Overall, I love this beer.

A moderate pour into a pint glass yielded a fine one inch head, which replenished enough for the glass to lace nicely during consumption. I detected only bourbon and vanilla on the nose, which left me unprepared for taste explosion! chocolate, vanilla, bourbon, caramel, sea salt, and scotch with a toasted bread note developing on the nose. The taste is boozy and more complex than I expected, the mouthfeel is lovely... I cannot find fault with this brew! Yeah, two ice cubes and two cherries in a highball glass, why not! Founders has accomplished the cocktail feel they sought! I'm loving it!

12 oz bottle, born on 7/7/21, poured into a Founders snifter at 55 degrees F:
L - brown and somewhat translucent with a hazelnut head that lingered
S - caramel, dark fruit
T - drinks like a barleywine, caramel and toffee with dark fruits
F - silky and thick with minimal carbonation
O - very nice, not what I was expecting
Bottle from Canton St March 2022

From the growler in a snifter via Country Fresh Market Beechmont. This solid
brew pours a red tinged brown with a nice head of white foam that settles to a thick ring,
thin clumping layer, and shows light lacing. Nose of cherry, bourbon, orange, and
vanilla with rich caramel and brown sugar notes. Flavors hit the mark with
brown sugar and caramel mellowed by orange, cherry, vanilla, bourbon, light
oak, and golden raisin with a hint of cranberry. Nice mouth feel; medium body,
smooth, warming, light verging on medium light carbonation, and a medium dry
finish.

Overall----solid!

Cheers

Look: Resembles a red ale liquid. Dense off white head that somewhat quickly dissipates to a 1/4 inch ring around the glass with wispy clouds in the center. Nice finger lace in the sides.
Smell and Taste: Hints of tart cherries and orange zest countered by sweet maltiness.
Feel: First I will say at 11% ABV I knew its would feel good LOL. Feel blend of crispness and smoothness.
Overall: Excelent. Rack up another win for Founders.
This really is solidly good. It’s got the smell of a fine liquor and tastes like a comforting beer.

12oz bottle
L: hazy copper colored DIPA; foamy ivory head holds good retention
S: juicy mango, grapefruit, & tangerine; light caramel malt
T: big flavors: mango, tangerine, grapefruit, apricot, caramel, bread crust
F: fuller body, resinous yet smooth, moderate carbonation, dry & bitter finish
O: I think this is really good. If this came out 10 years ago, people would have been losing their minds!

Poured from a 19.2 oz can into a Willi Becher pint glass.
L - Pours a medium amber color with a fluffy white head that dissipates slowly leaving tons of lacing on the glass.
S - Smells of orange peels and hops.
T - Tastes of pine and citrus.
F - Medium body and carbonation.
O - Delicious West Coast IPA.

I would have liked it to be a bit more piney. That said, this is a pretty good beer.

Poured from a can into a tulip glass. Orangish golden yellow color with foamy white head and nice curtain lacing. Citrus and pine smell and taste. Sweet tangerine and vanilla. Very nice full smooth feel. I would like to try it fresh from tap.

Pours a fairly clear amber with fine head.

Smell is fruity and a bit juicy with notes of pine, grapefruit, peach, green tea and caramel.

Taste is fruity with a solid bitterness. Notes of pine, grapefruit, te, peach, caramel and some melon.

Mouthfeel is medium, sticky and well carbonated.

Overall a very nice, modern DIPA.
Really great tasting beer despite not having a floral smell. I bought a 19.2 oz can at the bev store for $3. Can't beat that!

The pour is canary yellow colored. The taste is similar to the regular torpedo IPA except it's a little softer & more approachable. In addition to, I'm getting some tangerine, orange, grapefruit, & mild graham cracker note. The 8.2% abv is well hidden. Cheers! A-

19.2 ounce can into tulip glass, canned on 5/19/2022. Pours slightly hazy deep golden amber color with a 2 finger fairly dense and rocky off white head with great retention. Great spotty soapy lacing and moderate streaming carbonation on the glass. Aromas and flavors of huge red grapefruit, orange, peach, pineapple, apricot, passion fruit, mango, honeydew melon, guava, berries, citrus peel/rind, wood, pepper, pine, honey, cracker, toast, herbal, floral, grass. Good size, pine, citrus rind, herbal, woody, spicy bitterness on the finish. Medium carbonation and medium-full body; balanced creamy/bready malt and sticky/resinous hop mouthfeel. Long lingering resin drying finish, with mild astringency. Aggressive for the ABV. Mild increasing warmth of 8.2% after the finish. Amazing Cascade, Centennial, Mosaic profile. Very dank, earthy, and juicy hops with a nice sized malt backbone. This is really everything I'd envision as a modernized version of Torpedo if it was first made in 2021, but they made it an imperial. I will definitely buy again. I always love Centennial and Mosaic.

Poured from 19.2oz can into a dimpled mug. Canned 6/30/22.

Appearance: rich orange hue with maybe the tiniest hint of haze and a thick finger of frothy ivory foam. Color is beautiful and head retention ain't bad.

Smell: malty and quite sweet with a hop aroma that to me is noble, grassy, and earthy. Kind of on the subtle side for the style.

Taste: sweet malt and a big dose of piney, earthy, herbal, grassy hops, along with a bitterness that, while somewhat strong, is not quite enough to compete with the sweetness.

Mouthfeel: medium-rich body with a good level of carbonation and creaminess.

Overall: this beer looks and feels good, but the overall sweetness is too high for me and the character of the hops is not particularly complex or original.

Pours a clear bright orange, nice sudsy head with some lacing. Boogar machine says, caramel malts, some pine and a bit of citrus. Taste buds agree. I was pleasantly by this, I see hazy/juicy/NEIPA I figure I won't care for it, regular Torpedo is a favorite of mine. IMHO this won't replace Torpedo, it's pretty good but I wont buy it again.

Clear amber body; sparse carbonation yet thick, sticky, white head. Malty, spicy nose. Big malt backbone taste with a zesty, spicy hop presence; light alcohol note; earthy sweetness; moderate hop bitterness. Heavy body; mildly coarse on the palate; some alcohol heat.

This is another beer that is probably past its prime. It's not really juicy at this stage, but still is tasty enough and has some great eye appeal. It does ooze double IPA character.

Pouring temperature: 37 °F; canning data: 041422 C

Amber pour with excellent clarity; off white head of mixed bubbles; very good cap retention; heavy ring; bands of soapy lace; no legs. Caramel malt and citrus nose; a whiff of pine as it warms. Semi sweet caramel malt base gives way to bitter citrus and orange marmalade; lemon on the backend. Sticky resin feel, medium light body; moderate carbonation; no warmth from 8.2%; no astringency. Overall a very well balanced WC DIPA with a light bitter citrus linger.
Canned 4/14/22.

568 ml can, from Vinmonopolet, Nettbutikken. ABV is 8.2%. Clear deep golden colour, large to moderate white head. Aroma of malts, grain and orange marmalade. Soft mouthfeel, easy drinking for its strength. Hoppy flavour on a sufficient malty base, but not very sweet. Hints of Seville oranges, grapefruit and pine. Dangerously drinkable.

Is it “Atomic?” Or at least a Torpedo? At it’s ripe old age, I’m not really thinking either. Let’s go with with “light mist” and “.22 caliber.” Like, both could still affect you in certain ways, but there are bigger and bladder things, you feel me? It’s fine and ok. And ok. And fine. But like a first kiss, Raul will not recall it down the line.

Drank from the 19.2 oz can. Aroma is very fresh. Wheatgrass, apple, very light citrus, some pine. Taste is balanced, with grapefruit and light other fruits weaving in and out of a caramel or biscuit malt profile. Some spice and earth in the mix there. Overall, this is a nice balanced drink that I could see myself coming back to.

This is one that I got in a Sierra Nevada mixed box. What a great surprise. If you like the original Torpedo, you'll love the Atomic. Taste is similar to the Torpedo but this one is definitely amped up and I love it. I would truly recommend it to anyone. Enjoy.

Can dated 4/14/22. Golden orange in color, slightly off white , 2 inch head with nice clinging lace. Not much smell.... light pine, dank, earthiness. Taste was of dank hops, caramel , pine, some citrus. Great mouthfeel with some oiliness, balanced with moderate carbonation. A very good example of a ramped up WCIPA. Quality beer

Strait from the can today. An attractive cloudy orange, not sure about lace but confident it would leave traces of lace. 4.25

Aroma mandarin, peach, pine apricot, and grapefruit rind. 4

Taste follows mandarin, peach, pine, apricot, and grapefruit well balanced. 4

Mouthfeel is above average, a tad dry, plenty of life and at 8.2% easy going down with big flavor. 4

Overall nothing special, but a well made and tasty old school DIPA. 4

Can. Tulip glass.
Standard golden-orange, 3/4 finger head, mild murkiness.
Citrus scent.
After the midstream of grapefruit malt,
the East juicy style slides in easy.
Citrus tang epilogue, a defiant note which hovers in sharp contrast to the North East blanket.

Goes well with Banana Bread. Listening to the Melvins.

Pours a slightly cloudy, deep amber coloration with a large, fluffy head. Smells of doughy, caramel malt and resinous, citrus hops, with notes of grapefruit and pine, as well as hints of floral and woody accents. Taste is a great balance of doughy, caramel malt and fruity, resinous, herbal, slightly floral, spicy and woody hops, with citrus notes of grapefruit and lime peel, as well as some pine and hints of cedar wood and nutmeg. Finishes with a medium bitterness and some grapefruit, pine and nutmeg lingering in the aftertaste. Smooth mouthfeel with a medium body and carbonation.

While this may lack the punch and expressive character one might expect of a Double Ipa, it's quite easy drinking for the ABV without a hint of booze to it, while featuring quite an intriguing array of hop characteristics, ranging from fruity and floral over bitter and resinous to more subtle spicy and woody. While it's dominated by that typical West Coast character of citrus and resinous pine, there's a good, East Coast, caramel malt backbone to this as well, while those other accents make for a very interesting drinking experience here.

16oz can poured into a becher.

A: Deep golden color, almost approaching amber. uniform haze is barely opaque. Billowy white head retains extremely well. Very chunky lacing.

S: Bursting with passionfruit and mandarin orange, pineapple, guava, peach. Meyer lemon. Faint whiffs of green grass clippings. Simple grain base is doughy with a slight toasty grain character. It is so pronounced and tropical, it isn't even funny. This is one of the most memorable noses I've sniffed all year in the IPA world, and that says a LOT.

T: Orange juice, pineapple, hints of mango and peach. Squeeze of meyer lemon and some pithiness. Tart passion fruit for an instant. There's an almost creamy pina colada impression too. Some green oiliness and perhaps the faintest hint of sweet onion buried far in the background. Quick brush of alcohol. Doughy grain base, slight toastiness. Bitterness is fairly minimal. Peaches and cream sort of finish with some green-ness.

M: Medium-full body. Even creamy and full/fluffy feel from stem to stern. Cloud-like. Well carbonated and airy, without being sharp. There's plenty of lift, but the easy and creamy texture is never broke. Very slight hop tannin grip.

O: In a sea of hazy IPAs, this is a true standout. Get it in a blind tasting with all the hype-bombs and watch it mop the floor with the field. It's so well-focused, with a simple and straightforward grain bill that adds awesome texture and backbone, and the hopping is truly unique. Ridiculously fresh and tropical to the point you could swear it was made with actual fruit. There's no hop burn, no muddiness, and it drinks so easily and sits lightly in the stomach. This is hazy IPA at its absolute pinnacle.
The first crushable NEDIPA!!! Experimental hops do the magic. Great brew; Chapeau

Here's another one. A pseudo IPA likely without much of an essential ingredient, barley malt. How can you tell? First, it's the big foamy mess on top of the liquid contents emptied from a pint can into a clear glass liter mug. The ridiculous mess recedes quickly, unevenly, unattractively and with slight lacing. Usually, this also means a brew lacking body and complexity, but we shall taste. The aroma is weak, with just a little wet hoppiness present. It rises above a dirty amber colored beer. To drink, the body is way too light for something in this category. But, there is enough depth to the sweet background to compliment a nice hop presence that seems more earthy than the self described fruit references. The ABV is included only as a positive taste inclusion.This is one more example of a not so bad IPA that would only be improved with more barley malt.

Man, I love Zero Gravity, one of the best New England breweries and one that delivers consistently tasty IPAs, pale ales, and lagers at a lower than usual price. I have the mix pack in my fridge right now. This new one pours almost a glowing orange, hazy but not thick. Smells a bit earthy and slightly fruity. Taste is pungent hops, bringing some sharp oniony grass but also some citrus fruit as well. Easy to drink for 8%.

Really enjoyed this one. Tasted pretty green to me. From what I remember it's close to Other Half's All Green Everything. Aroma and flavors are both complex and keep the beer interesting throughout. Definitely a new favorite from Zero Gravity.

Not sure if I expected more or the last Märzen beer I had (Spaten) altered my taste a bit.
Poured very nice looking golden amber but the head was nearly mia. Odd for an Oktoberfest beer.
The aroma was good, bready malts, a touch of sweetness, maybe caramel, and no discernible hops.
The taste followed, very pleasant bready malts that’s slightly sweet in an indiscernible way. Pretty traditional Märzen style, and good.
The feel was subdued just a bit, maybe the lack of head was an indication of loss of carbonation. But it was still really quaffable.
OA, glad to try this, it’s currently the highest rated Märzen style I’ve had but not my favorite.
Boozy taste is a little strong. But pretty good as far as American Oktoberfests go.
The standard setter for the style. A dark, rich octoberfest beer bursting with flavor. A must try for any fans of marzen beers. Readily available and approachable. Cheers

12 ounce bottle poured into a tulip glass. Enjoy by 12/5/22, so plenty fresh.

L---Crystal clear, rich amber color. Medium, off-white head faded quickly to a ring and left sheets of lacing.

S---Bread, light caramel.

T---Bread. caramel. But strong bread mostly.

F---Medium bodied. Slightly creamy.

O---A nice one. Could have come from Germany.

Poured into shaker pint. Amber so pure you expect to see prehistoric insects in it. Cream-colored head that doesn't stick around.

Nose is very light maltiness.

Taste on the other hand hits all the right notes. Malty, toasty, sweet, and caramel. Dinner table bread in a glass.

Dryish mouth, light finishing coat on the tongue and throat.

In a style that floods the package stores by late August, Great Lakes' version is about as good as American Märzen gets.
Delicious take on the Oktoberfest-marzen style! Sweet and malty!
Sweeter than most Oktoberfest beers

Haven't had too many beers of this style, but Great Lakes set the bar high for Marzens I have in the future. Doesn't lack in any category. It improves as it warms and finishes smooth and easy. 6 pk was $10.99 + tax. Recommend and I will be purchasing again.

This is also solid and totally respectable. I think so far from what I've had from this area I like this one, Fat Heads and Thirsty Dogs the most. I think they're all about the same but this one has a real "goes down easy" feel to it. But overall a good standard Marzen

1.5 x 12-oz Bottles
Best By: 17 Nov, 2021
Consumed on: 24 May, 2022
Glass: 0.5 L Fest Mug
Serving Temp: 51.2 F


Look:
Deep and bright golden-hued copper that becomes dark gold when held to a light. 2-finger off-white creamy head slowly dissolves to a very thin but consistent cover. Lacing along the glass is excellent.

Smell:
The nose is somewhat restrained. Lightly toasted grains and sweet bready malts. Biscuity. There is a very, very slight note of grass.

Taste:
Early notes of toasted caramel and bread dough give way to a noticeable but not overpowering hop bite and a moderate earthy bitterness. There is a nice balance. As the beer warms slightly, some vinous notes appear. Things finish dry, with the alcohol making an appearance at the very end and in the aftertaste.

Feel:
Crisp and dry. Body is medium, with a lean to the light side.

Overall:
This is not completely on-style for an Oktoberfest/Marzen, but it is a fine beer nonetheless. I view this beer as more of a Heller/Amber Bock (perhaps even a Maibock) and in that respect it is quite good. A good beer for a cool fall day or spring night. YMMV.

12 oz bottle, best by 11/17/21.
Samuel Adams Ugly Sweater Run Pint Glass.

Burnt sienna/orange color with a half finger of head that runs out the back door with its hair on fire. No head left after 10 seconds.

Aroma of moldy grain and wet leaves, with hints of caramel, pumpkin, and faint citrus.

This beer is pretty full-flavored. Hoppy but not too hoppy, malty but not too malty. It opens with smoked caramel notes and hints of pumpernickel bread. Halfway through, the hop bite comes in and brings a robust medicinal bitterness a la Ricola but it's not gross and fits in nicely. It finishes on orange peel, smoked apricot, and spicy notes. The 6.5% is already hitting me.

Feel is crisp, moderately oily, semi-smooth, and brings a wave of alcohol heat on the back end.

Overall, this could be marketed as an imperial Oktoberfest, as it's quite the pumper. This is a very tasty beer and an excellent example of the style. I would absolutely buy this again if I were in the mood for an Oktoberfest. This would go really good with spicy mustard and doughy pretzels. Wow.

$1.66 / Binny's

Frankly surprised by this beer being listed as Outstanding. It's a marginal marzen. It looks the part--amber, off-white foamy head. But the flavors, though malt forward, are weak and lacking in substance. There is a bit of Noble hop bounce that emerges late, but still a bland experience.

2022 Review:

Appearance: Pours a beautiful, deep, but bright amber color with a small off white head. SRM of 13. (4.25)

Aroma: Moderate aromas of bread and caramel. Not anything impressive, but definitely picks up as it warms. (3.75+)

Flavor: Strong and bready flavors of bread, rich amber malt, caramel. Lots of toasted notes mix with the bread malt and caramel. Some floral notes and also some red notes as listed below. Rich bread malts, earthy, red, yet flavorful and sweet. (4.25)

Compared to 3 Sheeps Oktoberfest 9/5/22: Pours lighter, Milder aromas. Less toasted caramel and bread, earthy Munihc malt. More smooth bread and pale malts. Lighter and more pale.

Compared to 3 Floyd's Munsterfest 9/14/22: Pours slightly darker, milder aromas. More earthy, sweet honey. Less

Compared to Revolution Oktoberfest 9/14/22: Pours slightly darker, stronger aromas. More earthy, sweet honey. Slightly more spice. Less floral and toasty though. Slightly sweeter. Overall, very similar.

Feel: Heavier-bodied. Sweeter, yeast well-carbonated, rounded, and smooth. Balanced. (4.25)
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
2021 Review:
Appearance: Pours a beautiful, deep, but bright amber color with a small off white head. SRM of 13. (4.25)

Aroma: Moderate aromas of bread, grass, and earthy Munich malt with some flower and possibly caramel and bread spice. Hints of cherry and citrus hops too. (4.00)

Flavor: Bready and rich. A definite nice hint of earthy German flower and farm. Finishes very bready and with rich caramel. There is a rye, cherry and red apple hop flavor here too. Tastes like rich baking bread on a German farm on a rainy day. (4.25)

Feel: Medium-bodied. Well carbonated. Extremely balanced, and finishes clean and slightly sweet on the palate. (4.25)

Compared to Surly Oktoberfest: It's pours a darker amber with an off-white head. More bready and caramel malt flavors. Less spice and rye. Finishes smoother and sweeter. Less bitter.

Compared to Central Waters' Oktoberfest 9/5/20: Pours a lighter color with a lighter head. More dry bread and grass. Less dark bread, caramel, vanilla. Less sweet overall. Leans much more traditional festbier than American Marzen.

Compared to Founders Oktoberfest 9/20/20: Pours a similar color. Similar mild aromas. More red apple, cherry, and spiciness/tartness on the flavor. Less bready. More roasty, Americanizized and less roasty. More traditional.
10/31/20: Pours an identical color. More flower, citrus, cherry on the aroma/flavor. Less smooth caramel and honey. More red fruit and bitterness. Also more toasty. Nearly identical. (see below for 2021 comparison)

Compared to Odell's Oktoberfest 9/22/20: Pours a slightly lighter color. More bready aromas. Less spiced caramel and cherry liquor. Smoother, less spice and bite. Winner: Great Lakes.

Compared to Breckenridge Oktoberfest 9/27/20: Pours a slightly lighter color, but with a stronger head. More caramel, cherry, and alcohol aromas. Less grass, honey, and citrus. Sweeter, and more full overall.

Compared to Left Hand Oktoberfest 11/25/20: Pours a slightly lighter color with a similar head. More earthy honey and fruity. Less

Compared to Bells Oktoberfest 9/24/21: Pours a darker color. More cloying cherry hops and rich caramel. Less toasty and balanced.

Compared to Founders Oktoberfest 10/8/21: Pours a slightly lighter color. More citrus and spice. Less sweet caramel malts and phenolic flavors. A more balanced Oktoberfest overall. Winner: Great Lakes

Compared to Sam Adams Oktoberfest 12/30/21: Pours a lighter color. Hoppier aromas. More German noble hops and bread notes. Less rich caramel, cherry, and spice. More hoppy, bready, and Oktoberfest-like.

Overall: A very balanced, full, and American Marzen style. At first it drinks pretty standard and rounded. Nice flavors with some hints of flower and cherry spice. Wait until it warms. Caramel and slight chocolate malt shine as the beer warms. Exactly what I'm looking for in an Oktoberfest Marzen. Not overpowering but captures the right flavors. It's still slightly heavier bodied and stronger than a traditional festbier, but one of the best American versions of the style. This one is good, and It's bread spice in a glass. Strong, yet balanced and appropriate. Fantastic stuff here. (Final Rating: 4.23)
*Compare to any strong, yet balanced Marzen*

No idea what the deal was. Served on draft, looked okay but smelled and tasted like an underattenuated mess. I hope it was just a bad keg but I don't have any reason to believe the keg was off. Disappointing.

Pours a clear amber from the bottle, brief head, no retention. Nose is brown bread, light baking spice, sweet malts - classic profile. Taste is spicy, some alcohol, not much in the way of malts, and a bit dry on the finish. Very little carb and a rather hot finish. Overall, was a bit of a let down given the praise it has received.

Poured into a pint glass, a light, loosely carbonated two finger head forms, but begins to subside immediately. The color of this beer is beautiful.. it's golden amber inherently looks like autumn leaves.. apropo for an Oktoberfest beer! The nose is restrained, but good.. sweet grains with mild hops and malt notes. Adequate lacing does survive for 20 minutes. The taste of this Great Lakes brew, to me, is the styiistic definition of Octoberfest -Maarzen style. I have tried many other Octoberfests, first with Sam Adams, 30 years ago. This one gets everything right.. It is sweet, hops-malt balanced, with an earthy grain taste and fine mouth feel. More importantly, it does not bear the excesses of so many competitors.. no excessive hops skunkiness, no dryness, no lingering dirt aftertaste! It is a beautifully crafted, fully realized example of what an Octoberfest-Marzen should be! I'm sure I will continue to try other Octoberfests, but I expect to keep coming back to my fave by Great Lakes, every year!

Dark in color and aroma, with a dark amber hue and no head and consistent toasted caramel note in the nose. The flavor is clean and malty with a toasty bread note and a bit of funky yeast late in the finish that gives some earthy and grassy complexity to this otherwise standard interpretation. A little late hopping and a crisp, medium finish improve the final product as well.

Outstanding Oktoberfest bier! It is a Marzen style with a dark amber color. Pours with a light head. It has a slightly roasted malt flavor which distinguishes it from other Oktoberfest beers. Perfectly balanced. Very easy drinking, as it should be!

Disclaimer: I am using Oktoberfest to refer to any of the many styles brewed for Oktoberfest. I understand that Oktoberfest is not a style in and of itself.

Let me start this by start this by saying that, despite enjoying many Bavarian beers (and if I’m not a glutton for Bavarian food, I don’t know who is), I’m not sure that Oktoberfest-style beers have ever been my thing. I can drink dunkels for hours. -But give me 3 Oktoberfests instead? And I’ll probably drink no more than 2, and likely one 1. It’s not that I dislike them (as a group), just sometimes the Marzen’s are too pale, and in general they don’t seem to tickle me the way that something like a Dunkel would. That said, combine them with certain food styles, and they dramatically improve the drinking experience (for me, anyway).

Tonight is a new beer to me.

Great Lakes - Oktoberfest

6.5 %ABV, 20 IBUs

The beer is listed as a “Marzen style lager” on the can and on BA.

No canned on Date, but the can lists 10/25/2021, which I assume is a BBD, which I assume is a 90-day from Canned date, not a 45-day date, making this canned on 7/25/2021, putting this just shy of 2 months from canning. Picked up at a Kroger as part of a mix-6 pack of just Oktoberfests for this tasting. (Unfortunately I drank 4 before the tasting ever started, so…)

The beer was removed from a 45ish degree temp fridge after having been refrigerated for approximately 2 weeks. Beer poured into a classic Haufbrauhaus dimpled mug.

First Impression: Beer pours light in color – much closer to the straw-like yellows of a Pilsner than the golden-amber I normally expect from other Oktoberfests. No immediate aromatics.

Appearance: Pretty enough, but nothing special, although a little surprised at its’ light color. An appropriate amount of head for the style when first poured, which dissipated to nothing (with no lacing) almost immediately. Not swearing I am rating appearance correctly here, as appearance always feels quite subjective. 3.5

Smell: This beer is not extremely aromatic. My first test for any Oktoberfest beer is does it give me that quintisential “beer smell” and “beer taste”. What do I mean? It tastes like bier, bruh. I know this isn’t descriptive, but in my mind this is always what I think beer tastes and smells like. I’m tried to smell and describe this for 5-7 minutes now, and nothing is coming to me. It’s just non-descript except as “bier”. Think I say this every year. 4.0

Taste: A distinctively ‘bier’ taste that is not a pale as I might have expected for being called a marzen. Interestingly, this doesn’t strike me as being true to style, although I am no expert. I get some hints of banana and clove that I typically only find in dubbels, tripels, and quads. Maybe even a little bit of bubbelgum. It’s not on the front end, but the back, but also not much really left in the aftertaste. It’s right at the moment you swallow. (That’s what she said.) 3.75

Mouthfeel: Nothing unique or special. It feels (get it) true to style. If anything, it’s almost slightly too viscous for a marzen, as it is encroaching on dubbel territory. 4.25

Overall: This is fine. I’m not sure I like it that much, but I do appreciate that it’s a good beer. I also understand, truly, why so many people like it, and why there are so many fans here on BA. That said, again, I don’t think it’s really right for me. I won’t be buying a 6-pack or multiples each year, but I very well may buy a single most years. 4.25

BA Review Score: 3.95
In retrospect, I think a score of 3.95 is pretty fair. I think it’s close to or right around a solid B. I’d be hard pressed to give it any higher than a B unless I am comparing it to other beers. Of the 5 total Oktoberfests I have had this year so far, this isn’t the worst, but it’s also not my favorite. I’d probably say it’s right in the middle. This beer did make me go fry up a Knockwurst and a Bier bratwurst, though. Spicy bratwurst mustard ready.

Poured from a 16 ounce can dated 6/27/22 into a snifter.

Look- Pale gold, very hazy, opaque, fine white head, below average head retention, average lacing.

Smell- Clementine, ripe melon, pineapple.

Taste- Clementine, ripe melon, grapefruit, moderately astringent.

Feel- Medium body, substantially below average carbonation, mild bitterness, moderately creamy, moderately astringent.

Overall- Very pleasant bouquet and flavors. Astringency was a major detractor, but the ripe melon flavors did offset some of the astringency.

I am trying this beer off the tapper at The Daily Growler in Powell, Ohio as part of a six sample flight. It poured a hazy yellow with white head that is leaving some lace. The scent had fresh tangerine and orange notes. The taste was nicely balanced and easy to drink with fruit peel spice of apricot, guava, and stone fruit. The mouthfeel was medium in body with good carbonation. Overall it is a solid beer.

Appearance: Pours a nearly completely hazy (10% clarity) medium to light orange color with a mild white head. SRM of 7. (3.75)

Aroma: Strong aromas of candied pineapple and mango upfront. Some over-ripe orange and cantaloupe melon. An almost pain-like sweet candied pineapple and mango.

Flavor: Strong and candied flavors of lemon, candied pineapple, sweet mango. Some lightly astringency citrus and pineapple notes, almost a burn. The finish is sweet with some hopburn.

Feel: Medium-bodied. Moderate carbonation. Leaves a hop burn and sweetness on the palate.

Compared to Equilibrium Mast Theory 8/6/22: Pours a lighter color, milder head. More sweet candied pineapple, orange, and paint. Less creamy mango, papaya, guava, creamsicle.

Overall: Not the best offering from Drekker. This one has appreciable hop burn. Overripe orange, pineapple, and cantaloupe flavors. Paint-like. A lingering hop burn. Finish was sweet and low carbonation. Not up to par with their usual products. (Rating:

Canned 8/25/21; drank 9/19/21 @ the Yarchives.

Cloudy orange/yellow appearance.

A rough pour yielded a huge white head; frothy lace.

Pineapple, mild fresh ganja & faint strawberry notes in the nose.

Medium mouthfeel.

Pineapple & mild pine flavors up front; dry grass & mild ganja notes on the finish.

A nice balance of fruity & dank; not mind-blowing, but very good.

Canned on 01/31/2021. Sample from the brewery.

Malts: Pale Two Row, Oats, Carafoam, Spelt, Chit
Hops: Sabro, Mosiac, Citra
Yeast: House IPA Yeast

Murky, milky, straw, pale orange-yellow with a thick, creamy lace. Tropical and coconut in the nose with some floral notes. Medium-bodied, a bit chewy, and incredibly creamy, soft, and smooth. Fruity and juicy with a big smack of lemon-line followed by pineapple, tangerine, honeydew melon, and overripe strawberries. A bit spicy and boozy. Some coconut suggestions too. Slightly toasty malts with an underlying doughiness. Grassy, a bit astringent, and bitter with an herbal and resiny linger and heavy dose of hop burn.

Other than burping up hops and wreaking my esophagus for the next few hours, this a damn good hazy DIPA.
Tasted in a Spiegelau IPA glass from a one pint can on March 15, 2021.

Pours a hazy straw color with a fresh head and drizzled lacing. Smell is juicy tropical hops and house yeast.Taste has citrus,lemon/lime pineapple and mango. Mouth feel mis soft and juicy with hops ABV well hidden. A great DIPA.

Pours a hazy light orange with soapy head.

Smell is juicy with notes of lime, pineapple, coconut and a bit of sweetness.

Taste is juicy and soft, with a bit of booziness. Notes of lime, coconut, pineapple, oranges and a soft bitterness.

Mouthfeel is medium, soft, pillowy and well carbonated.

Overall, another really nice DIPA from South Dakota.
Pours an opaque hazy gold. Hints of limes, oranges, and mangoes with pine on the back end. Smooth mouth feel and slight alcohol warmth on the finish. I really like this one.

A: The beer is very hazy to cloudy light pale yellow in color and has a moderate amount of visible carbonation. It poured with a quarter finger high white head that died down, leaving a thin layer of bubbles on the surface and a narrow collar around the edge of the glass.
S: Moderate aromas of coconut are present in the nose.
T: The taste has flavors of coconut along with hints of lime and mango.
M: It feels medium-bodied and a bit juicy on the palate with a moderate amount of carbonation.
O: This IPA has lots of aromas and flavors of coconuts and does a very good job at masking any traces of alcohol from the taste.

Serving type: can

Light yellowish haze with a small thin head, super leaves some lacing. Nothing overwhelming to the smell but good citrus notes. Super smooth soft mouthfeel full of citrus notes and a slight bitter cold bite with a hint of coconut in the finish. An excellent IPA overall

Drekker Hater Blockers DIPA, 8% ABV. Pours a bright hazy gold with a two-finger white head that left lots of lacing. Nose is pine, mango, and citrus, taste follows with moderate bitterness. Excellent mouthfeel, overall excellent.

L: Poured from a tallboy can to a snifter glass. Had a yellowish color and an extremely cloudy consistency. There was a quarter inch of foamy, somewhat long-lasting head. Pretty good lacing.

S: A sweet and fruity aroma of citrus fruit, hops, tropical fruit, coconut, and malt

T: Tasted of a decent shot of tropical fruit (mango, in particular), some coconut (more than expected; a good addition), a moderate amount of hops (less than usual for a DIPA), light malt (mostly in the finish - it gets drowned out by the fruit), and a lot of citrus (tangerine). A sweet, lively, and fruity flavor. More like an NE IPA in character, but still tasty.

F: A well-carbonated beer with a smooth and creamy finish. Medium-bodied.

O: A well done, light, and easy to like beer. Drinkable.

Can. White head with lace. Hazy sunset orange color.

Mango, melon, orange, and honeydew. Very soft and creamy. Has a faint hop burn in the finish, which I expect to go away in a week. Otherwise, I really dig this one. For a non cream hazy, this is cream of the crop.

Edit: a few weeks later and a lot less hop burn. This is great.

Oh damn this is good. Soooo much dark roasted coffee up front. I also get baker's chocolate, a nice bourbon tingle, and a lingering fudginess. Probably the most coffee forward beer I've had. Absolutely loving this one!

I had this on draft 9/14/22 @ the Beer Temple.

Black appearance.

Small tan head; almost no lace.

MASSIVE dark roast coffee bean, mild vanilla & booze heat notes in the nose.

Thick, creamy mouthfeel.

HUUUUGE dark roast coffee bean flavors up front; chocolate syrup & mild booze heat notes on the finish.

If you're a dark roast junkie this might be manna for your soul; for me it was way too much, and only good for a few ounces.

Oh MY! This monster from the 12 oz bottle pours a murky blackish brown
with a nice head of brown foam that settles to a thin ring with light lacing.....
and with a swirl.....she's got great legs! Nose of rich coffee, vanilla, cream, char,
brulee, dark cocoa, and inviting bourbon with touches of dark fruits and tobacco.
Flavors nail it with dark bakers chocolate, dark roasted coffee in abundance, mellow
bourbon, heavy char, brulee, dark fruits of blueberry and with warmth dark tart cherry.
Tobacco and oak make a play with warmth as well as sherry notes all vying for a pole position
over the driving force of rich roasted coffee. Nice mouth feel; full body, smooth, very coating,
rich, warming from the booze note, faint carbonation, and finishing with a lovely bitter malt
note that lingers long.

Overall----stout lovers, take note, THIS ONE ROCKS!

Cheers

The body pours as black as night. No head. Not much carbonation. Doesn't matter. Doesn't need it. Aged over a year in Willet bourbon barrels, this beer is the big cousin to Lagunitas Willettized stout.

Nose and taste are all about the barrel. Blending wonderfully with the bourbon is a delightful coffee flavor from the addition of Dark Matter coffee. My memory believes this stout is CBS without the chocolate notes.

Mouthfeel is good but not as heavy as one might expect given the ABV.

This is definitely a great stout and I'm glad I like it considering I've been less than impressed with some of their other beers in other styles. This is no frills and exactly what it says it is. It's thick and syrupy due to the abv and the coffee flavor is akin to Big Bad Baptist for example as it's pretty biting. Was worth getting a 4 pack

Got this from @Jzeilinger and Thank You for it.
The bottle pour is into a clear glass goblet and a thick and mostly black color liquid emerges. A dark tan colored head forms and then very quickly disappears leaving no trace of having been there.

The aroma is mostly coffee that has been fresh roasted along with a touch of bourbon. I thought I also caught some vanilla and oak.

The beer tasted like roasted dark coffee with hints of chocolate, vanilla, and bourbon, but mostly coffee.

Overall, I find it to be really good, and a strong coffee-dominated Stout. The high ABV is also a nice touch. Would I recommend this Stout? You betcha!!

Drank from a 12fl oz (355ml) bottle purchased at Craft Beer Cellar, Belmont, MA
Bottled 10-25-21
Served in a tulip

Fantastic label design. 3 Floyds always impresses in this department. As for the beer, it poured a deep brown/black hue and thinner than anticipated. A small cap of saddle brown bubbles topped the body, but it quickly dissolved. There was zero head retention and no lacing whatsoever. An oily sheen floated on top of the liquid.

The aroma was solid initially and improved with time. Rich and malty. Nice melding of roasted and caramel malt notes. Darker roast coffee also came through strong. Good dose of brown sugar sweetness too. There was a punchy booziness, but not much bourbon specifically. As the beer warmed, the nose became sweeter, punchier and more rounded. Some dark chocolate and vanilla notes also came forth.

The flavor profile was solid but not amazing. Malty and robust up front. Loads of roasted malt character. Hint of char. Roasty coffee notes were apparent but definitely not as strong as in the nose. Big boozy notes kicked in soon and intensified as the beer moved along the palate. Brown sugar was also noticeable. Touch of chocolate. More roast, char and booze on the back end and in the finish.

The mouthfeel was rather disappointing. It was somewhat oily and slick but quite thin for the style. The liquid contained a fine, subtle effervescence that seemed appropriate for a beer of this magnitude.

Crushing Mass was an enjoyable coffee stout, but the bourbon barrel presence was unfortunately quite subtle and the mouthfeel much thinner than anticipated. Perhaps the most impressive aspect of this beer was that the alcohol was so well buried.

Brief Review:

O: Ever since GI stopped doing BCBCS, I've been starving for a good BA coffee stout. Prairie's Mocha Noir blew me away last year, and here comes a new one from Three Floyds. This one's pretty decent. It's a little harsh up front, pretty boozy at 15.1%. Coffee is pretty acidic and very forward. It's nice and balanced on the finish though, ends more more drinkable than you think. Mouthfeel medium+, could be better. Overall could use a little more balance, maybe even a touch of sweetness from something.

Recommendation: Great coffee BA stout from Three Floyd's here, great to see them churning out some awesome one-offs again that are more affordable and available.
Awesome beer, forgot I had this in the cellar, but what a nice surprise. Fantastic representation.

Pours a fizzy tan creamy 1/2 finger brown head with good retention, pitch black beer with long inky black legs

Nose surprisingly strong amount of coffee, fresh nutty mild earthy fair roasted coffee, rich smooth coffee and not anywhere near acrid or burnt, fair roast, dark chocolate, little cocoa, vanilla, some baking spices and cookie dough notes, vanilla oak, some whiskey as well

Taste rich dark malts, heavy inky oily beer, dark chocolate, cocoa, fair roast and more coffee, not as strong as the nose but some fresh nutty coffee, with low roast and not burnt, more baking spices, a bit of baker's chocolate cookie dough, some bitterness from roast and mild spicy hop, a bit of hot alcohol but not too much, a bit syrupy, a little vanilla barrel and a bit of char late, mild sticky finish, a touch of bourbon in the middle

Mouth is heavy full rich, a bit syrupy, med frothy carb, fair hot alcohol

Overall pretty nice beer in general, not much barrel character, but nice coffee, probably didn't need to have so much alcohol but still good

Pours a dark brown to black color with beige edges and a half finger of tan head that swiftly dissipates. The nose has bold notes of bourbon upfront with a decent roastiness behind it.

The flavor also features bourbon combined with a modest sweetness and an astringent roasty quality on the finish. The mouthfeel is modestly sticky.

The alcohol never gets "too much" but it comes close as one moves down the glass.

I think that this will make for a good aging project. I'll be looking to pick up more for that exact purpose.

Oily, sweet, and aggressive imperial stout. French roast coffee dominates the aromas and flavors, with notes of licorice, tobacco leaf, bourbon barrel, herbal hop, and char. Some meaty roastiness to the aroma. Almost spicy mouthfeel (rye malt?)

71/100

I'm shocked at quality and lack of hype on this. It's a creamy coffee, with roasty and chocolate notes all the way. No green pepper here. Descent barrel presence yet smooth for 15% ABV. Medium-thick feel. Where did this come from, 3Floyds!?

Pours dark brown with a matte finish and a half finger at most of creamy-looking dark khaki head. It quickly settles into a thin crown that leaves modest lacing.

Coffee up front in the nose with a little chocolate and slight fruity notes (cherry mostly).

The bourbon element is much more forward in the taste with flashes of amaretto, almond, toffee and cherry. Chocolate and strong coffee shows mid-palate. Lightly acerbic coffee bitterness lingers in the aftertaste. The massive ABV is completely hidden.

Relatively full bodied and slick feel with some slow-building, but sharp carbonation.

A nicely made little BBA coffee jawn. Reminds of SMS.

Pours pitch black colt with a 2 finger thick brown foamy head that was packed with bubbles of all sizes, dissipating on the fast side while leaving basically zero lacing. Not unexpected for a BBA brew that sat for a year in Willet bourbon barrels. Wow, the nose is a coffee stout on steroids with fresh ground coffee, burnt coffee grinds, a bag full of coffee and espresso beans, charred wood, smoked grains, molasses, dark chocolate, cocoa powder, vanilla, oaky notes and bourbon. It’s got that Starbucks mocha Frappuccino smell but like it’s was poured over some of the best coffee beans you’ve ever inhaled. I could get into this first thing every morning.

The taste is really good, but a drop off from the aroma. The alcohol heat and thinness of the stout body take away from it a little bit, but the flavor is also really tasty. It’s chock full of fresh ground coffee, burnt coffee grinds, vanilla, coffee beans, espresso, charred wood, smoked grains, molasses, dark chocolate, soy sauce, cocoa powder, bakers chocolate, hot fudge, cacao nibs, bourbon and/or dark rum, more bitter dark chocolate and faint piney hops as it finishes. This brew is not for everyone, but I’m a huge coffee stout fanboy so this is exactly what the doctor ordered.

Grolsch 'Premium Pilsner' @ 5.0% , served from a 500 ml can
A-pour is a light gold from the can to a clear gold in the glass with a medium size white head leaving a streaky lace along the stein
S-herbal , grassy
T-clean Euro pale lager
MF-ok carbonation , medium body
Ov-glad it's a one & done , not a good beer
prost LampertLand

appearance: very clear. pale gold, like a dark straw color. 1.5cm(approx) foamy white head that quickly sinks down to a very thin ring. no lacing, and the ring disappears fairly soon after beginning to drink.

smell: clean and grassy. minor funk (very very slight). slight overtones of hay. a light touch of malt.

taste: on initial sip, slight bitterness with more hay and some gentle tones of honey. as it lingers, bready malt appears along with some of that funk from the nose. long semi-dry finish with a flourish of bright but bitter hops.

feel: nice smooth carbonation. body feels heavier than you would expect, but medium-light at the same time. easily drinkable, goes down smooth.

overall: pretty good pale lager. more interesting than some other macro brews, but not quite up to craft standards. locally it was purchased at $10.99 for a 4x pack of 450mL glass swing-top bottles. not the cheapest for what you get but still an overall nice drinking experience. i would recommend this to a friend.

Grolsch was made for cigar smokers. It holds up really well to the muting properties of cigar smoking. Hardly a beer fares better under the scrutiny of the cigar’s influence on the palate, yet remains subtle and refined.

April 2002: Rerate: More flavour than the other Dutch macrobrew lagers, still I'm far from ecstatic. Clearly on the bitter (hoppy) side (too much bitterness for me), some sweetness too. Not as easily drinkable as Dommelsch. I had it on tap (in Holland) as well as can (have sampled the original bottle earlier), it didn't improve much from tap, unlike most beers.

So I deleted my last review and now I review again, as I think I just tasted my new favourite pilsner ever, Radeberger. An hour ago, this probably was. So I am going to review this again now to directly compare against it. From a corked bottle. If you try Grolsch from a can or an alternative bottle without a cork, it simply doesn't compare. I think the corked bottles are brewed in Holland, where as the others are brewed under licence, locally.

Fairly deep and dark for a pilsner...medium head with a combination of small and large bubbles.

Amazing aroma when you open the plastic cork...but actually the aroma from my pilsner glass is kind of frothy and a bit uninspiring. Especially after the Radeberger...

The flavour is nothing compared with Radeberger. That is now my favourite pilsner for sure. Now Grolsch really does taste like a mass market produced beer. I think the reason I gave it such a good review before, was linked to the rather terrible beers that I drank just before I drank it.

Hops are well balanced...kind of lightly Czech style. A little watery and uninspiring overall. Not much in the way of mouth feel, though there is some background bitterness that kind of lingers and comes to at the end. It tastes like it might have been pasteurised for a bit too long...but I guess for mass markets it needs to be.

One hour ago I really loved this, now after tasting it and reviewing while fairly sober, not so much ; )
Swingtop bottle. Nice beer easily drank. Far superior to Heineken.
Skunky

Pale golden / straw in color, and quite well filtered for excellent clarity. Rather good and “scrubbing” carbonation is evident (and is equally evident across the palate).

Nose is neutral and “lager” like, with a better than average, upfront Noble hop character. Slightly sour/sharp… Pils like, and somewhere between a Pils and a Helles if I had to place it, but clearly more character to my mind than that of it’s obviously more successful competitor, Heineken. On the other hand, the malt character is on not as evident. Perhaps a result of the use of corn or another (in the “classic” sense of the word adjunct) adjunct? All signs would point to “Yes.”

Sweet and very slightly sour/acidic/sharp across the palate on the first sip. Good aromatic character (the really carbonation helps, here), and an almost herbal quality beneath its sweeter malt base. Tastes at once both richer -and- lighter in body: a contrast and a conflict. Even though it is not as “hoppy” as anything in the c.f. “Craft Beer era”, the hop bitterness does linger quite nicely throughout the drink.

Good mouthfeel, and the carbonation although ample, is much gentler than it first seems to be.

The taste for me is where this brand, Grolsch, has always shined over others of its very broad style of Euro Pale Lager. This is of course, judging from both memory (many previous encounters in many packaging and draught formats over the past thirty plus years), and re-reviewing a fresh, flip-top bottle — Best By: March 14 2023.

My rating is doubtless high, but for what it is Grolsch is a classic example of its style, and a longtime personal favorite.
Quite nice, although seems to be only 4% in the UK. Has a lovely spry scent and a refreshing taste. Goes well with lunch.

Poured from a 12 oz bottle with the funky top that's kind of cool. Pours dark yellow with a thin amount of head. Biscuity, bread like taste with decent carbonation. Has a stale tastes that reminds me of beer drankin' while deployed in the Navy; not bad.

Poured from swing-top bottle into a Grolsch logo mug. (I mean, why not?) Pale Amber color, with a couple of fingers of brilliant white head. Decent retention, with some pretty lacing. Aromas and flavors are muted a bit at fridge temp, but open up as the beer warms. Grainy and grassy, with a hint of peppery spice and lots of pleasant bitterness. Finish is clean and crisp, with no lingering off-flavors and no skunkiness. So is it a Pilsner or a Euro Pale Lager? Either way, it's pretty good.

Attractive clear gold body with a large white head that left good lacing. Subtle aroma; malts impart a biscuit-like quality that pair well with the noble hops. No off notes, nothing skunky. A grainy, crisp, clean texture to the taste. There is a little sweetness and a bit of spiciness but no noticeable fruit. Pleasantly bitter with a well carbonated mouthfeel. One of my favorites of this style.

Drinking one of these takes me right back to my well-spent youth. I always preferred this to its other macro equivalents, Heineken and Stella Artois. Slightly more complex, a bit more breadiness but also a suggestion of a hop bite at the end. And, the coolest bottle! Yeah, I'm being a bit generous with my score, but this is a whole lot better than Heineken, and definitely better than Stella, so there you go.

Beautiful thick bottle, really really cool. Typical clear Pilsner look with a frothy white head. Smells like barley, unbaked bread, and other non sweet bakery goods, with I hate to say this, but a touch of weed. Simple taste, but clearly there is quality hops used which I can appreciate. Classic European Pilsner taste with its own thing going on coming from the hops. Refreshing but not exactly a summer type beer, like the lager of Guinness for myself (meaning, refreshing, but.. not a warm weather beer per say). Normal watery mouth feel, leaves a small aftertaste, especially at the back of your tongue. As you keep drinking the taste gets more casual, and being a Pilsner it’s not too complex, but you can still enjoy that different hoppy character that we see differently in European Pilsners, but that’s all you really get.
Short Verdict: better than ok, not great, but still enjoyable. Though I did drink it out of a old style beer bottle which could have enhanced it.
Superb little number. I have found it goes well with beef, lamb, chicken and a fried brekkie.
Crisp classic. A touch single dimensional. Although the hop is the star of the show. Less hoppy alternative to Urquell. Solid brew. Definitely be back for more.

Nose: skunky hopps, fresh cut grass and basic barley aroma.

In the glass: golden/ light amber looks tasty, if only it was

Palate: sour bitterness met with mellow cereals, very bland with the only characteristic making itself known being the hops.

Finish: bitterness met with a harsh sweetness, like poorly malted barley.

Don't waste your time with this one. There are plenty of better beers, this is like a worse version of Heineken

Pours a translucent honey golden color, with a fast receding head. Smell is sweet caramel malt, grains,distinctive yeast that only Grolsch has. Taste is slightly bitter(no funk), with a delicious wash of quality caramel malts. A floral note is evident.Feels almost perfect . Carbonation is good, all the malt to hop ratios seem perfect. Even though this brand has been passed around almost as much as my old girlfriend it still has the same qualitative taste. Many, many stories where the Grolsh was involved. The cap today resembles ceramic but I believe it is plastic. 30 Years ago in NYC that real ceramic cap was a perfect stone for spleefers- Still really good,underrated-

10 oz pour on tap at Frisco Taphouse in Crofton. This has to be the perfect pilsner. Aroma and flavor feature crisp, off-dry bready malt, floral/spicy hops, and fresh-cut grass. Mouthfeel is crisp, clean, and smooth, as drinkable as can be. Delicious.

Bottles picked up at the brewery, dated 15AUG22. Can’t emphasize enough how delicious this is. Had it on draft and then bought a few bottles and it got better each time. So crisp and refreshing with a hint of hops and infinitely drinkable.

Pour a dirty straw, slightly cloudy, bubbly quick disappearing head.

Nose is strongly herbal and floral, subtle Pilsner malt sweetness.

Taste is again heavy herbal and almost verges of having weed like qualities to me, verging on skunk. Minor sweetness.

Light body, soft on the tongue, not that dry or crisp with a low bitterness.

Different beer to be honest if I drank this blind I would not say it was a pils, it’s a little overly hoppy and not dry and crisp like a pils. Almost reminds me of a super light hoppy blonde.

500 mL bottle. Clear golden. Smells of grass, bread, and lightly spicy hops. Taste has a zip of lemony citrus up front followed by a strong bready malt flavor. Grassy and spicy hops in the finish. Medium light. This is outstanding. Maine is quickly rising in my list of favorite breweries.

Purchased at the brewery in Brunswick, Maine.

Crystal clear with a light gold color. The moderate head remains throughout the tasting with minor lumps and a continuous cascade of upward bubbles from the base of the glass. Minor spots on the glass remain after each sip.

Clean, refreshing soft malt start. It's a bit like a Helles, but the floral hop is distinctive, making this a beautiful example of the style.

The taste is a touch less soft on the tongue. There's a small berry-like presence. The body is neutral to full, richer than most pilsners. The carbonation is high as expected. The hop is still bittering but on the subtle side. Overall, a great example closer to the Czech version of pilsners.

Slow poured at Delaware Supply in Albany, NY.

This one pours a clear golden yellow color, with a big fluffy head and lots of lacing.
