This smells like grainy malt, spicy hops, lemon rind, orange zest, and pith.

This is a little bit more hop forward than the typical pilsner, but that doesn't bother me too much, as it's definitely not overhopped. The malt character is really nice, with a light graininess, some breadiness, and a restrained sweetness. The hop character is spicy, herbal, slightly lemony, with a hint of citrus.

This is light bodied, clean, slightly creamy, and very, very drinkable.

This is an absolutely excellent first stab at a lager. MBC is obviously known much more for IPAs, but they clearly have impeccable brewing talents elsewhere, as well.

16.9 oz bottle into a pilsner glass.

Pours a clear straw color with a huge fluffy white head. Bubbles for dayz. Excellent head retention with a ton of cobweb lacing. Gorgeous looking beer.

The aroma is exceptionally grainy, bringing notes of cereal grains and fresh wheat bread. There's plenty of citrusy notes as well, namely lemon zest and orange rind. Grassy, herbal, and spicy. Nicely hopped.

The flavor follows the nose: Very grainy and bready to start, followed by some citrus and grassy notes. Lots of cracked pepper-like spice, with plenty of noble hop presence. Very clean.

The feel is light bodied with lively carbonation. Crisp, dry, and highly refreshing.

Overall, this is a great German pilsner. It's bright, crisp and very clean, and exceptionally drinkable. Plenty of sweet malts balanced out by an assertive hop presence.

Prince Percy Pils

Pours a brilliant pale straw yellow - nearly crystal-clear, and topped with three fingers of rocky white foam with good retention. Significant pacing and visible effervescence.

Nose: Very rustic, grainy pilsner malt. Almost saison-like, with wholesome, grainy, hearty notes of rye, wheat, barley, and crackers. Very dry aroma. Lots if floral notes, some hop spiciness, tons of grass, hay, farmhouse, fresh rain, and a lemon-lime note. Extremely bright, zippy, and fruity for a pilsner.

Palate: Greets the palate nearly bone dry with lots of grain - almost like pale malt, and a really nicely hoppy profile with fresh grass, lemon, lime, orange, grapefruit pith, as well as a European spiciness and a kiss of resinous bitterness. There's a very lively minerality to this, similar to Suarez or Hill Farmstead. Thr finish sees a reduction in lemon-lime, and an increase in grapefruit pith, grass, spicy hop resins, and raw grains.

Mouthfeel/Body: As with most MBC beers, this is light, crisp, snappy, vibrant, bright, and and refreshing as possible. No malty sweetness or weight to weigh it down, but plenty of flavour to keep it full. Effervescence is incredibly lively and fizzy which really suits this well. Drying, slightly resinous finish.

Overall: I could go on and on about this, but all I really need to say is - this is the single greatest pilsner I've ever had. It's perfect. It's perfectly balanced, perfectly hopped, perfectly carbed, and just... Perfect! This is a world-class beer, so questions asked. If you enjoy pilsners, you need to have this. You'll understand.

Translucent golden hue. Great smell, with a nice grassy “bite” to it. Tasted like MBC ale (such as Peeper) meets Pilsner. Nice, lingering feel.
Didn’t taste like a classic, straightforward Pilsner to me, but more MBC ale meets Pilsner; not a complaint, just an observation. I find all MBC beers to be well-balanced, and this is no exception. Again, not a classic Pilsner, but very enjoyable nonetheless.

L -- Clear pale straw body with three fingers of solid white head that laces and retains fairly well
S -- Fresh pilsner malts, dry white wine, earthy dried floral, hint of soapiness
T -- Fresh cut grass, herbaceous earthiness, drying pale malt character
F -- Light mouthfeel, medium+ carb. A little watery around the edges
O -- Nice lager, but pricey

81/100

Bottled on 5/29/20

Pours a clear and effervescent pale golden straw body topped with multiple fingers of tight, eggshell-white foam; good head retention leaves a steady finger of cap, with massive, foamy mounds eventually comprising the collar and chunky, thick strands of lacing covering the glass.

Aromas of crisp, crackery malt evolve to fresh black bread crusts, and a building, grassy hop presence upfront; floral tones, and semi-sweet cracked pepper mark the mid-palate's transition to highlighting underlying suggestions of sulfur, grapefruit and stone fruits developing on the close.

Taste opens with peppery bread dough and fresh grass as a floral mid-palate peaks; rounded fresh bread with hints of lemon, peach essence, and grapefruit on the back end offer nuance to an otherwise clean, toasty finish.

Mouthfeel brings a soft, light body with a deftly rounded moderate-high carbonation; effortless palate, delicately fluffy peak into a mildly gritty back end sporting an even milder, bitter finish.

Ample complexity drawn from a straightforward pilsner profile in large part due to a calculated dosing of hops, this is an overall satisfying, unencumbered American-made take on the style with near-universal drinkability courtesy of a delicate touch throughout.

Pale gold body; lively carbonation; thick and sculpted white head. Bright, light, and herbal aroma; soft sweetness. Very clean flavor; subdued and alluring cereal grain base; gently toasted grain; light mineral taste; nice hop bitterness crescendo building midway through the sip and past the finish. Light body; crisp; smooth with a gentle warmth; soft dryness throughout.

There is nothing like a well-crafted pilsner. This beer offers the experience and delivers it.
Picked-up two cans at Tree House in Sandwich for about twelve dollars. My two hundred and seventy first brew from these guys. Not great liked less than Oasis, overpriced.

Canned on 9/1/22; consumed on 9/17/22

Pours a turbid, burnt orange body capped with just over a finger of white foam; decent head retention leaves a half-finger of rich cap, large, frothy collar, and limited array of chunky, webby lacing lining the walls of the glass.

Aromas of orange juice open to peach creamsicle, meandering to a syrupy mango peak; resins edge the back end of the bouquet as vague tones of gritty, grassy subtext linger.

Taste highlights orange zest upfront, with an oncoming each/mango sorbet dominant in the face of toasty coconut cream undertones; a slightly dank, grassy edge comes through toward the finish.

Mouthfeel is medium-thick and sports a subtle prickle of carbonation phasing to taut yet creamy textures through the mid-palate, leaving a slight, residual grit lingering in contrast to glossier, semi-juicy resins into the finish.

An overtly tropical sheen coats juicy resins into bright, pulpy IPA-shake vibes; fruit is effectively integrated, sweetness is not excessive, and coconut subtleties provide softer nuance to the whole.

Pours an opaque murky straw color with a half finger of head. The nose has coconut and fruit juice notes. The flavor is sweet and fruity with a semi-dry finish. The body is hearty for the style.

I'm not sure what TH was going for here. But, this one is a rare swing & miss.

Pours hazy, orange gold in color with one half inch head. Taste is tangerine, coconut, tropical punch Life Savers and mango. Heavy body, moderate carbonation, slightly bitter. Not my favorite King variant. Solid ipa but I am losing the base beer. Lots of tropical flavor but a pass for me. I think I would have been fine if they would have called this Tropical Storm or something but KJ has certain expectations.

Notes from 7/2/2022.
Poured from a bottle into a Rastal nucleated Teku glass.
The body is dark reddish-brown with almost a finger of beige head. Retention is average.
The intensity of aroma is medium-low. There are notes of mostly sweet malt, milk chocolate and caramel malt. I detect a slight hop aroma.
The intensity of taste is medium-high. Wow! That's good! The flavor has a deep malty, chocolaty, caramel flavor with a mild hop finish. It's sweeter than other Doppelbocks I've had.
The feel is thick, fairly creamy, the carbonation is medium-low, the astringency is medium-low giving it a long dry finish.
Overall, I prefer that it's sweeter which is more to my liking than Celebrator. Although, I consider Celebrator a obviously superior Doppelbock. I will probably purchase this one more often.

Bottle purchased at Costco

Appearance: clear reddish amber, medium off white head
Aroma: molasses, prunes, roasty
Taste: brown bread, cola, not sweet
Mouthfeel: med.-light body, light carbonation
Overall: light feel belies ABV-watch out!

1.5 x 0.33L Bottles
Bottle Best By: 2022-aug
Glassware: 0.5 L Stange
Temp at Pour: 55.8 F / 13.2 C


Look:
Light and clear mahogany that leans to the red side. Initial 1-finger beige head that dissipates to a very thing coating. Some lacing, but not a lot.

Smell:
Sweet and malty. Dark fruits, toffee, and some lightly toasted caramel. Notes of honey and light brown sugar. A faint earthy tone can be detected.

Taste:
Definitely sweet, but not as sweet as the nose. Dark fruits and toasted caramel. Hints of nuts. There is an noticeable underlying earthiness that is lightly bitter. I also pick up faint hints of dry chocolate here and there.

Feel:
Smooth and slick. Somewhat syrupy. The body is on the full side of medium.

Overall:
A solid doppelbock that is on the sweet side. In some respects, it reminds me of an Old Ale.

Poured from a 11.2oz bottle into a pint glass. Most definitely an old bottle.

The look is a bit lighter than expected, a light brown to amber, with a very light haze. On the pour very little head formed, I am unsure why. What did form completely disappeared over a few minutes until zero head remained. Honestly a beer without any bubbles floating on top is a little offputting.

The aroma brings us back to normal here, although I can smell a bit of age, it's not skunked or anything, just perhaps more fermentation notes. Some caramel malts peek through. Perhaps even some dry fruit notes.

The taste follows the smell but much more malty. The fermentation flavor is there alongside the dry fruits. But right behind that is a malt explosion. It's not a very sweet beer and a wave of dryness and bitterness hit at the same time but it rounds out the beer well.

Feel is largely dry, but somehow it seems like a head forms nicely with each sip only in your mouth where you can't see it. I'm not sure what happened here exactly.

Overall a nice tasty doppelbock. Would be better fresh I'm sure but some beers are just hard to get fresh so that does factor into the score a bit. Malty as a Doppelbock should be.

Finally picked this up in a variety pack, always wanting to try more dopplebocks when I can as they are infrequently stocked here. This one drinks very light for its abv, a tad thin. Some decent flavors of sweet malty goodness. Going to enjoy all 4, but won't likely seek this out again if it required purchasing 8 other beers I'm not jazzed about. If sold separately, this is a pretty darn good dopplebock.

Pours a ruddy brown, hazy copper with a thigh two inch thick head that dissipates over a few minutes. Aromas are mild but pleasant, mostly sweet malt, caramel, a little bit nutty. I only get very mild fruity notes myself.

Interesting and straightforward, but subtle and complex tastes. The thing that distinguishes this from other Doppelbocks I’ve had is a bit of this savouriness in the middle. It’s a little funky in spots like a lambic or saison, and a little sweet, nutty and savoury like a thick bodied very sweet beer. Almost a cheesy like thickness and aftertaste. I’ve tasted this in a few other German beers so I’m not sure what it is. I’m still new to all this, so I’m sure I’ll discover it as I go on, but for now I just don’t know what it is.

Malt forward with mild bitterness, very doughy, yeasty flavours that are particularly sweet. Roasted caramel malt notes abound, and strong toffee. No fusel alcohol notes here. There is a very mild dried fruit flavour of dried raisins and figs. Not as strong as Aventinus (regular or Eisbock) which particularly features these types of fruity notes. In comparison to that and other doppelbocks, Salvator is more sweet, sticky, and sticks to the bready desserts. I do notice some enjoyable banana flavour here as well, especially as it warms. As with many complex beers, a lot of notes are strengthened by it warming up, particularly the dark fruit notes.

Very much medium bodied, slightly on the heavier side, the feel is thick and creamy, and just a tad oily. Feels like you can chew on the doughy malt. Mildly carbonated, which really allows the flavours to rest on your palate, giving it a nice long evolution of tastes with a lasting finish. Very creamy sip, it gently foams on the back of your tongue on the way down. As I noted above, the alcohol/abv% is not noticeable.

Paulaner brews are definitely ones that pick styles and a few good flavours and aim to hit the bullseye on them. So they’re not as complex as some others out there, but excellent benchmarks of whatever style they choose to brew. Salvator is a very interesting Doppelbock. If your favourite thing in the world is sweet, malty beers, your rating will likely be higher than mine. If you like more hop notes, or bocks that are mostly fruity, more dry and less sweet, you will likely rank this lower.

Salvator has a lot of great flavours that are melded together quite well, subtly complex, with a unique sweet savouriness. This makes it feel less clean and crisp than the slightly more boozy, less sweet, more dry examples of doppelbocks. But what it doesn’t have in those arenas, it makes up for in its creamy, less biting drinkability, malty sweet tastiness.

Picked this up over the holidays at Gary's in Wayne, as I hadn't had anything from Paulaner in years. Love their beers and the ability to get them in these parts, and this was a great example of a Doppelbock as it was true to form, well-rounded, and easy to drink. In other words, it was fitting on a chilly winter's night such as this!

This had a lovely, almond hue to it with a frothy and full tan head that settled beautifully and evenly. Loads of bread, caramel, and chocolate in the nose as the taste contained some plum and fig along with a bit of toffee, dark nuts, and apple. Slick, moderately cloying, and nicely carbonated, this felt great on the palate as it went down nicely with a hidden alcoholic presence. Smoke, banana, and raisins lingered in the aftertaste as the warmth settled in once I finished this off.

Loved this beer and it's underlying potency as it was plenty strong but wasn't overt in it's heft. Without even realizing it, the "Enjoy best before" date on the corner of the label was 2/22 as this tasted great and held up well since it's bottling. The complexity of this emerged as it warmed up as this has me wanting more examples of the style - most of which would not measure up to a benchmark such as this.
Personal notes only: Needn't buy again. Has a bit of that Lambic Ale flavor I don't care for. Maybe it's the higher alcohol. Very caramel malty, but there are a lot of other options.
Bottle from John’s poured into pint glass. Boozy caramel, touch of funk.

Pours a dark red/copper colour. Nice thick frothy white head that sticks around noticably long.

Smells like chocolate,caramel, toasty, and definitely really sweet. Can't tell if the sweetness is from the chocolate smell or if there is something else there, almost fruity sweetness.

Taste is great. The caramel really comes out along with the dark chocolate, has a toasty and spiciness too it as well. It hides the high ABV extremely well. If someone told me this was 5% I would believe them.

This is my first doppelbock and I must say, I'm extremely impressed. Hits all the notes I wanted it to, some sweet, some toast, medium bodied, very drinkable. Delicious.

11.2oz stubby bottle

Smells like alcoholic cocoa puffs. Taste is hearty, like I'm drinking a dissolved coffee table, but surprisingly drinkable. Creamy and slightly slick with oil, it drinks heavy, warming you with a slight burn in your belly

I would love to smash a big messy plate of kraut and sausage with a mug or three of this

Haven't had this in a while - and never rated it.

Very beautiful pour - nice brown caramel color and a bit of head.
No noticeable smell.
Very delicious. Creamy. Smooth mouthfeel. Not too much sweetness.

Excellent beer.

12 oz bottle into a Founders snifter. Top popped and everything seemed to leap out!
Immediate Scotch aroma fills the space. Lively fizz that lays down quickly.
Taste is Scotch & soda, caramel sweetness, barrel dryness, quick finish.
Feel is old ale heft, low to medium carb.
Overall, supurb sipper.,.

Pours a dark brownish color with a small tan colored head that didn't last long. The smell was of malt, caramel and a strong alcohol. The taste was that of malt with some caramel and the influence of the scotch barrels for a warm alcohol finish. A really good beer.
Super hardcore and outrageous scotch and oak barrels combine nicely with the base scotch ale. It’s oaky, a bit roasty, with caramel sweetness, some tobacco and dark fruit. Bombastic but nice.

Poured from 12oz bottle into Chimay goblet.

L - Dark brown pour, with a light cream colored foam.

S - Vanilla, caramel, barrel.

T - Caramel, malt, vanilla, peat, black coffee. Starts sweet and works its way into a nice smooth bitterness.

F - Not heavy, but has a nice weight on the tongue. Creamy and dry at the same time.

The barrel cures the weak points of the original Dirty Bastard and turns it into an outstanding Wee Heavy.
My first scotch ale style beer. Simply great. Another great Founders beer.
Initially loved dirty bastard (the original) but just too much 'oak' for beer. Still a great beer with singular flavors and aromas but not my taste.
Ones of my favorites so I'm not very objective. Love the bourbon that comes through. This years version is a little thin but still very very good.

I tried this brew a couple of years ago and remembered that I really liked. Today is the first time I have seen it back in stock at my local beer store so of course I had to try it again. I'm a fan of dark bourbon beers and this one ranks right up at the top. The initial pour unveils a dark amber ale with a short lived frothy head. The smell is sweet with an obvious bourbon scent. The first taste is remarkably smooth and rich, sweetness on the tongue with a mild pleasant bitterness arriving at the end which left me craving for my next sip. Ahhhhh, so yummy! This is a first class sipping beer that you should keep on hand for your favorite house guests...if your the generous type.

Bottled on 09.27.21 - 2nd try on this one, which drives this very review - found the barrel taste too strong & fresh-coopered first time, but impressions seem to be diminished this round...)

Pour into 5oz snifter leaves an appealing bubbly tan head reducing to cloudy mists on the surface with a bubbly creamy little ring surrounding the fill line. Color such a lovely translucent deep burgundy. Nose is barrel woods, sweet molasses, perhaps a nuance of tangy fruitiness in there too. Taste is a lovely bittersweet, a little tang & fizz on the tongue. Swallow is bittersweet, not overly sticky.

I can see why appreciators like aging this one. It's a sweet lil' treat.
Superb scotch ale

Fairly dark body, browinish burnt copper color with a decent light tan head. Very pretty aroma: caramel, vanilla & bourbon. Sweet with just of hint of bitter. Very tasty: caramel, brown sugar, spices, bourbon, scotch, ripe dark fruit, vanilla & oak barrel flavors. Medium feel, good carbonation & a fair amount of alcohol heat in the mouth & stomach. Excellent scotch ale.

This sample was bottled 9/28/12. Poured into a 16oz nonic, a tan off white head forms and quickly dissipates leaving a light cap of foam on top. The color is a slightly translucent reddish brown. The smell is of boozy roasted malts, bourbon and candied dried fruit. The taste is slightly sweet, boozy malt, with notes of dried fruit and bourbon. The mouthfeel is medium bodied and slightly slick. Given the age of my sample I assume the carbonation has toned down from the original packaging, the mouthfeel is smooth. Overall, this is an excellent beer that I would definitely buy again.

When compared to KBS it is a step lower. BUT - that does not make it undesirable. If you are a connoisseur of ales you will love it. If not - the pilsner people and BudNiks will notice the bloaty feeling and over-handed sweetness and put it down around a stale Oh Henry. Newbies will be hypnotized - the Seasoned will say "meh."

This is a fantastic dark beer, especially considering you don't have to go to a boutique micro-brew in order to get it. It's available at my local grocery store! The flavors are complex without feeling artificial or over-powering. The bourbon barrel aging is evident. It forms a very nice, almost nitro-style head. IMHO, this is the best offering Founders puts out...which is saying a lot since they make some outstanding beers.

11/7/21 from a 12 oz bottle 4 pack.... Birthday present from DW.

Nose: maple, pecan and bourbon barrel.
Taste: " " and brown sugar. Warms you up real nice! Nice and smooth front and back end. Wee heavy!

Notes from Thanksgiving Day 2019. Bottled on 6/26/2019.
12 oz bottle into a small snifter glass.
L: deep dark brown
S: bourbon, candied caramel, spicy peppery wood.
T: oak, bourbon, smoke, nuts, dried up fruit, figs, raisins, pectin, fruit cake, pecan pie. Not too sweet.
F: medium bodied and kind of sticky. Balanced and fairly smooth.
O: Deep, full flavored barrel beer with a hearty soul. There is light alcohol. It is excellent.
Very smooth, malty ale. The dark fruit and caramel notes seem to be the most prominent for me. Highly drinkable for an 11%.

Poured from a 12 ounce bottle dated 8/26/21 into a snifter.

Look- Black, frothy medium brown head, opaque, above average head retention and lacing.

Smell- Coffee, vanilla, bourbon, cinnamon.

Taste- Bourbon, coffee, vanilla, cocoa nibs, slight cinnamon at finish.

Feel- Medium body, creamy, smooth, average carbonation, moderately bitter (from coffee/cocoa nibs), moderately mouth warming, mildly mouth coating.

Overall- Very enjoyable drinking experience. Body was thinner than expected, but great flavors and bouquet. This beer has aged nicely.

This was a single I found at the local beer store. I've been wanting to try this one for awhile and now here it is.
The pour was into a clear glass and produced a very dark brown liquid with a light tan head. The smell was of chocolate, cinnamon, and vanilla. Taste was the same. All in all, a good one. Definitely will look for again.

i finally get around to trying one of these KBS variants, i was torn between the espresso and this one, seems like i probably made the wrong choice, this is darn good though, so incredibly chocolatey, like drinking a bar of dark chocolate, the vanilla give its a nice sweetness, while the cinnamon kind of takes a back seat, although there is a little cinnamon spice to it, rich espresso coffee flavour, black bread, molasses, and liquorice also, bourbon, boozy enough, high bitterness on the finish, full bodied but you would expect it to be fuller again, low carbonation, a sipper of course, a great beer but not an improvement on the original.

Poured from the 12oz bottle into a pint glass. The beer is a pure dark opaque brown color with no light coming through. Head is 2 fingers, creamy/frothy and dark brown.

Smell is dominated by dark bittersweet chocolate and a Graham crackers cinnamon character that is slightly sugary and yet honey like. It is like a chocolate pie with a cinnamon Graham cracker crust. There is a dark bitterness underneath hat could be the coffee but it seems like more of a chocolate note.

Taste is very chocolatey, dark bittersweet chocolate that is lightened just a smidge by a light creamy vanilla character. Cinnamon is evident throughout but not really in your face, just a presence like in a pie. The finish has a light boozy touch to it reminding me that it is a bourbon barrel aged stout. This could get a bit cloying but it strikes just the right balance before going off the rails.

This is one of my less favorite variants of KBS, but it is till fantastic.
Nice bottle, spice rack flavour.

Draft
L-very dark brown, opaque, minimal tan head with faint lacing
S-dominated by the spices
T-delicious flavor that delivers on the vanilla in the opening and the cinnamon in the finish with no hint or bite from the abv. There is a rich bready malt throughout as well
F-full bodied with a lingering thickness.
O-a great entry in its series that I found enjoyable

KBS - Cinnamon Vanilla Cocoa pours black, with a small, long lasting, tan head. Aroma is filled with cinnamon. Flavor is filled with mostly cinnamon, a hint of creamy vanilla at the end. Good body and feel. Overall, its good, lots of cinnamon, and a good robust stout base.

This beer leaves everyone thinking about what they'd change about it. This one has too much going on, just isn't balanced right. It's definitely too sweet, vanilla can come across really sweet. The mouthfeel is unpleasant, needs to be thicker, I can feel it separating into layers, the bottom of which is just corn syrup and water.

I feel like they were making a KBS for people that don't want a bourbon beer and just made it too sweet. I'm always prepared to slow sip a high abv beer but small sips just tasted even sweeter and less complex.

In the end this was difficult to finish, and expensive. Not the beer for me. The smell was great poured, but the taste was better from the bottle.

Edit to add: I generally love Founders.

A 12 fl. oz. bottle, bottled on 3rd September 2021. Poured into a snifter glass.

Appearance: Pitch black with a one finger brown head that had good retention and left nice lacing.

Aroma: Cinnamon, vanilla, chocolate, coffee, with notes of raisin and bourbon.

Taste: Light to moderate bitterness, dark chocolate, cocoa nibs, black coffee, some sweet notes, cinnamon, vanilla, dark fruit, raisin, bourbon.

Mouthfeel: Smooth, creamy, velvety, full to medium bodied with soft carbonation.

Overall: Great aroma, and taste was nice, but the cinnamon was perhaps a bit strong. It was sweet, but there was a good bitterness that balanced it, such that it wasn’t overly sweet. A good variant, however I do prefer the original KBS more.

I smell it all. The normal KBS coffee notes and a nice hit of chocolaty vanilla but it's the cinnamon that is most tantalizing.

Maybe my pallet isn't quite sophisticated enough but the initial taste is like a little sweeter KBS. It has the coffee and cocoa and is really delicious but outside of the added sweetness it's just KBS.

It's thin for a stout because that is a signature quality of Founders and it has a very mild fizz. The really special aspect of this beer is finish. It's a little bitter but the vanilla and cinnamon shine through in the end.

This is good but it should be, it's KBS. I really appreciate the added sweetness and the follow through on the promise of vanilla and cinnamon. Overall I give it a 5.7 out of 6. Spectacular!

This isn’t the world beating stuff of KBS legend, but it’s a good imperial stout. Almost like the milk from a bowl of Cinnamon Toast Crunch mixed with a BBA coffee stout. It’s rich and thick… sticking to the feel of Founders imperial stouts and you can’t go wrong with Founders stouts. I remember the first KBS and CBS I had years ago… Just the class of them! To this day I can think of no other barrel aged stout that has given me that sort of feeling. The sheer brilliance and wow factor was revolutionary. To me they’re still the cream of the crop and best in the world. This doesn’t reach those marks but it’s one of those unique takes that’s great to enjoy! I’d recommend this to people looking to delve into the depths of big, dark stouts! It has the sweetest to entice anyone.

Yeah, sure, ok… It’s fine. It represents itself well like Kanye when tranquilized. But I just don’t think it needs all the Pezaz. Regular KBS is Candice Swanepoel; but this one is Candice with augmentation. Sure, she still has it going on, but it wasn’t necessary. It wasn’t necessary.

See ya.

A - Pours pitch black with a fizzy one finger tan head. Light amount of soapy lacing.

S - Aroma is cinnamon, coffee and dark chocolate.

T - The taste dark chocolate, coffee, cinnamon, light vanilla and finishing with warming bourbon.

M - Medium body with medium carbonation. Creamy mouthfeel with a crisp finish.

O - Really solid KBS variant. The cinnamon adds a nice spicy sweetness. Vanilla is really subdued.

From 12 oz bottle marked bottled 09/02/21 2106 6

Pours into my tulip glass a high viscosity fully opaque near black with a creamy brown head. Great retention and fluffy lace.

Scent is bourbon, raisins, chocolate, vanilla, mocha java and a hint on cinnamon. I think I also get toasted coconut.

Taste is chocolate, bourbon, raisins and dark fruit. The cinnamon comes across more strongly on the taste than the nose but is not overwhelming. Vanilla. Rich dark roast coffee. Chocolate covered cherries. Dark cocoa. A hint of char and roast. Sweet but not overly sweet.

Mouth is oily and weighty.

Drinkability is good for a 12% brew. Alcohol is not noticeable and my glass emptied quickly enough that I could imagine having a second.

Typical of the KBS series this is a fantastic Imperial Stout featuring rich chocolate coffee and bourbon notes. The cinnamon doesn't really add much and I think I prefer the other variations in the line but either way this is a great stout.

A lot of pumpkin spice on the nose - and little else.

Flavor is less dominated by pumpkin spice, although it's still quite prominent. The chocolate definitely comes through on the palate, however, as does a bit of subtle heat.

This is a very nice and creative beer if you're looking to get your pumpkin fix in.

Raul wasn’t expecting the stars, but he also wasn’t thinking hotel carpet. Not that it’s terrible, but it’s not much. And I’m not talking the crazy 8 Motel that rents out rooms by the half hour, and has mirrors on the ceiling in which the owner once pointed at and told me, “Dat for honey! Dat for honey!” (No joke, can’t make this stuff up. Anyway, think like a renovated Holiday Inn in Fresno - the carpet might be fresh, but walking into your room at 2 AM, you are not. Nothing else needs to be said.

A: The beer is jet black in color. It poured with a quarter finger high tan head that quickly died down, leaving a thin collar of beige bubbles around the edge and some lacing on the surface and the sides of the glass.
S: Moderate aromas of chocolate, spices and pumpkin are present in the nose.
T: The taste follows the smell but the flavors of spices are more subdued and the pumpkins are a bit stronger.
M: It feels medium-bodied on the palate and has a moderate amount of carbonation. There is a bit of dryness in the finish.
O: This taste of this stout has a nice balance between the flavors of chocolate, spices and pumpkin.

Serving type: can

A thanks to the creator of the canquest, woodychandler, for this beer. Poured from a 16 oz. can. Has a black color with a 1 inch head. Smell is bursting with pumpkin, spices. Taste is pumpkin, nutmeg, roasted malts, some ginger. Feels medium/full bodied in the mouth and overall this is a solid beer.

16oz can poured into a goblet

A- pours black in color with a one-finger creamy light khaki head that has great retention

S- an array of spices on the nose, with cinnamon leading the way, followed by notes of nutmeg, allspice, as well as some clove and ginger. Undertones of the base beer gives some roasted barley, chocolate, black licorice and char, hint of raw pumpkin

T- sweet and malty up front with some chocolaty malt, immediate followed by spice notes of cinnamon, nutmeg and ginger. Mid-palate brings out some roasted notes from the base beer, adding a bit of char. The finish gives some spice notes, as well as pumpkin and more roasted malt

M- medium body with moderate carbonation leads to a foamy mouthfeel that turns slightly creamy into the finish

O- the pumpkin and spices work well with the base beer, providing a nice sipper that hides the abv well

Poured from a can into a tulip glass
Appearance – The beer pours a dark brown color with a one finger head of tan colored foam. The head fades rather fast leaving but a trace of lace on the sides of the glass.
Smell – The aroma of the brew is big of a cinnamon and nutmeg along with lots of pumpkin and cocoa. Along with these smells comes notes of roasted malt and a bit of a Crème Brulé like smell.
Taste – The taste begins with a roasted malt backbone flavor matched with a light roasted pumpkin flavor and lots of cinnamon and nutmeg. From the start there is a cocoa flavor, which with the roasted pumpkin get stronger as the taste moves forward. All the while flavors of caramel and molasses, which were light upfront, grow more potent in nature, adding more sweetness to the brew. At the end a touch of crème and a surge of the pumpkin, leaves on with a nice rich, roasty, spiced chocolate pumpkin taste to linger on the tongue.
Mouthfeel – The body of the brew is slightly thicker and chewier with a carbonation level that was on the low side. For the stout nature and the big roasted and pumpkin flavors of the brew, the feel is good and makes for a nice slow sipper.
Overall – A rather nice pumpkin stout. The Mexican chocolate spice nature matches the pumpkin flavors well and creates a nice overall balance. Rather fun!

A pint bottle poured into a draught glass. Look has an impressive head of brown foam that slowly compresses down; a deep, dark brown body lies beneath the depth of foam. Pumpkin puree is dominate on the nose along with clove and a bit of sweeter malt. Taste brings out the rich chocolate (but the spicy chili-like sensation is buried) up front while the pumpkin puree and clove-y spiced flavor is heavy on the backside. At times the puree has an almost syrup-y like quality on the tongue that sometimes fights a bit of ABV sensation (not entirely surprising at 7% ABV). Feel is heavy and creamy with the chocolate making a surprising resurgence in the aftertaste. An interesting offering but would have preferred the puree dialed back a notch and the chili-spice increased a few notches.

Look: deep brown, small head
Smell: nutmeg, slight cinnamon, chocolate, pumpkin, malt
Taste: slight spice, pumpkin, little chocolat
Feel: medium full body
Overall: decent, I was expecting more though. Fairly simple on the taste, well done for sure, but only 1 and a half note (as opposed to 'single note') - if that makes sense

Pours clear, thin, and dark with abundant head. Chocolate malt aroma. Flavor is chocolate malt and pumpkin spice - I get the cinnamon and light clove, lots of brown sugar, some pumpkin. Thin body, carbonation adds to a creamy texture. Overall a tasty dark pumpkin beer, glad I tried it.

10/5/21
16 oz can dated 7/19/21
4 rating

16oz can stamped 07/19/21 (about 10 weeks old) poured into a nonic pint glass at fridge temp 7% ABV. The beer pours bright medium brown in color with sticky light brown head. The head recedes to a thin cap and leaves rings of lacing around the glass. The aroma is pumpkin, pumpkin spice and pepper. The taste is semisweet roasty malt with pumpkin and sweeter pie spice before the chocolate and pepper heat finish things off. Mild bitterness. The mouthfeel is medium bodied with average carbonation and a mostly dry finish. Overall, good although I prefer the original Chocolate Sombrero.

Was a pretty decent blend of Two styles a Mexican Chocolate stout and a pumpkin ale. I think I liked the base beer more since it came off as more sweet this one being roasty with some chocolate vanilla and a good punch of cinnamon/nutmeg. Not a huge fan of pumpkin stouts to be honest they are often dry and over spiced but this one walks the line pretty well. If your looking for actual chili kick don't expect to find it well covered by any pumpkin spices.

Overall not my favorite by this company could be epic as a BBA beer but it was a decent find when I was in Erie PA looking for new beers to try!

Look – Pitch black body with two fingers of almond-colored head

Aroma – Well, not sure what to say here. I get a big load of nothing. There are some malty notes and deeply-hidden chocolate presence, but other than that, it smells devoid of anything. Weird.

Taste – Again, not a whole hell of a lot going on here in the taste either. Maybe some chili pepper skin, but no heat to speak of. The base stout itself is rather enjoyable with subtle chocolate and even black cherry and licorice. However, there’s really nothing “Mexican Hot Chocolate” or “Pumpkin about this at all.

Mouthfeel – Full-bodied. No alcohol presence and is a rather smooth and velvety ride.

Overall – As a standard stout, it is really good. That being said I was promised Mexican Hot Chocolate and Pumpkin, and I got neither. It kind of paints me into a corner in terms of rating as I do enjoy this beer, but it did not deliver on what was promised. If you want a pumpkin beer, go somewhere else. If you want a good stout, then grab a can.

From a 16 oz. can dated 07/19/21. Sampled Sept. 23, 2021.

Handsome appearance of dark brown to near black and a boisterous tan frothy head.

The aroma emits chocolate, nutmeg, cinnamon, clove, roasted dark malts, but little in the way of pumpkin squash.

Smooth medium mouthfeel.

The taste is sweet and roasted dark chocolate with a bite of cinnamon and nutmeg and a slightly dry ending.

Poured into a 16 oz Snulip glass canned on 7/19/21. Pours a very dark near black with a 2 finger sticky light brown head that leaves thin streaks of lace with excellent retention. 4.25

Aroma pumpkin, cocoa, chilly pepper, coffee, and nutmeg. 4

Taste follows pumpkin, peppers, cocoa, coffee, and nutmeg the spice is mild and it is loaded with flavor. 4.25

Mouthfeel is above medium, maybe a little dry, plenty of carbonation but slightly creamy as it warms, and at 7% it goes down rather easy. 4.25

Overall this is another really nice version of this classic stout. If you like pumpkin beers a must try. 4.25

Canned on 7/19/21. 16oz can poured into a tulip. Pours a very dark brown; fluffy and creamy khaki head that falls leaving great retention and sticky lacing. The aromas have a subtle blend of spices. Some cinnamon and peppermint. Some chocolate and cocoa. Malts are there. More cinnamon and peppermint. Subtle pepper skin flavors, but this one isn't spicy at all. Some smoke in the mix. More chocolate and cocoa blending with the spices. Moderate to low bitterness. Mild sweetness. Solid malt backbone. Alcohol basically goes unnoticed. Mouthfeel is full-bodied with moderate carbonation. It's fluffy, creamy, smooth and easy to drink.

This is an alright "Mexican-style Chocolate Stout". It's not a bold or extreme example of the style, but it has a nice balance to it. The pumpkin purée is a nice touch. Not bad.

Poured hard from a tall can into a snifter glass, forming a few fingers of tan head that eventually faded to very heavy lacing. Dark but translucent brown color, typical of pumpkin stouts. Smells of roasty pumpkin and a hint of spices. Taste is definitely a pumpkin stout similar to Warlock, but it has a little bit more complexity with a little bit of chocolate at the end. Spices aren't super pronounced, maybe a bit more as it warms. Light to medium bodied with heavy carbonation, more intense than I prefer for sure. Overall a good pumpkin stout, but not as much of the Mexican hot chocolate aspect as the name/description implies.

LOOK: Pours a deep mahogany brown with an outstanding tan head that maintains good retention and plenty of side glass lace.
AROMA: Roasted malts and yeast, cloves. Sweet caramel, maple syrup.
TASTE: Cloves linger in the aftertaste. Not a fan of that.
Looking for a malty Brown Ale but the Belgain characteristics were quite prominent, so not what I was hoping for.

Pours a dark mahogany with rich cherry accents, huge 4" fluffy tan head with exceptional retention and lacing. Nose is roasted malt, light smoke, charred wood, a caramel. Taste is interesting with notes of caramel, baking soda, raisin, and a small amount of raw sugar on the finish. Bit of warming alcohol lingers after the finish. Mouthfeel is ultra soft and smooth with only a hint of carbonation. Overall a nice, drinkable beer, though the sugary finish is a little off-putting.

I had this beer with some excellent mussels in Arlington, VA. Surprised this was my first opportunity to review it.

The beer was poured from a bottle into a shaker pint glass. Dark clear brown color with a nice creamy beige head and great curtain lacing. Smell and taste of dark fruit and caramel. Apricots and dates with a nice malty background. Very tasty and excellent with the food.

Pours a nice dark mahogany brown with a half finger of dense foam that quickly returns into a spotty cap

Strong yeasty and caramel malt notes are forward on the nose, mildly toasty. Figs and raisins, dried dark fruit. Bananas as well as spices such as clove and allspice.

Taste follows the nose pretty well. The yeasty notes are lightly doughy, pleasantly toasty caramel malt, the lower abv% (in comparison to other strong dark Belgian ales) gives it less of a rum/alcohol tinged inflection on the notes, which does let the lightly peppery and spicy esters and fruits have more of a fresh character. Mild bananas, banana bread, cloves, maybe even bakers chocolate, and plums and fresh figs.

Medium-light bodied, moderate carbonation, gently tickles the sides of the mouth and tongue. Average length finish that tends to the dryer side, relatively sweet, the spicy yeasty and bready notes most relevant on the finish.

Leffe is the slightly cheaper, super available popular Belgian ale you can find everywhere. It’s an excellent dip into these kinds of beers. Hard for me to ever dislike any kind of beer that is malty and yeast forward. Question is, how to judge this beer? Against all others in the Belgian category, or against beers in general? These notes are practically explosive compared to macro brews, likely to blow your mind the first time you pick up this 6 pack instead of Bud. But it’s a little light and mild in flavour profile compared to other dark strong ales from Belgium. Overall, it’s quite a fine beer, balanced, not overtly complex but it’s very crisp and enjoyable.

Clear chestnut brown, dense light khaki head, great retention and lacing
Dried fruit, green banana, and toasted bread aroma
Slightly tart, green banana, caramel, and dried fruit flavors
Medium light bodied and appropriate carbonation
Pretty good, I think it would be better with food than on its own

This beer is highly underrated.
11.2oz bottle into a small snifter. Poured at 60F or 16C.
L: Pours deep ruby brown/dark mahogany, good carbonation w/a 1.25" light khaki semi-creamy head w/very good retention. Light sticky banding & lacing.
S: Port wine, cork, caramelized malts, roasted malts, light vinegar, banana, light clove, a hint of chocolate that lingers.
T: Minerals, red wine oak cask, dark fruit, banana, caramelized malts, light toffee, light chocolate, light sugary sweetness, moderately rich overall & floral.
F: Crisp, lightly acidic then a quite smooth medium bodied mouth feel w/an elegant medium length delicately dry finish.
O: A beautiful tasting rich in flavor semi-sweet brown ale that has sentimentally ardent and almighty depth. It is gently warming and complex but not overly so. It is outstanding in it's style.

Pours a deep, dark mahogany coloration with a large, creamy, lasting head. Smells of bready, caramel malt and estery fruit and spice notes of banana, apple and clove, as well as just a hint of toffee and chocolate. Taste follows the nose, with a good balance of bready, caramel malt and fruity and estery yeast notes of banana apple and clove, as well as hints of chocolate and toffee. Finishes with a medium sweetness and some caramel malt and estery fruit and spice lingering in the aftertaste. Smooth mouthfeel with a medium body and carbonation.

I think it's interesting how this basically tastes exactly like Leffe Blonde with darker malts. The general flavor profile really is incredibly similar here, with the yeast profile being very recognizeable, just with more bready, slightly toasted malts and hints of chocolate. I still like it a lot better than the Blonde though, because those dark malts really make a difference here.

Copper with a 2" tan head, which lasts. Heavy glass clinging lacing.

Aroma is coffee, roast malt, caramel.

Taste is caramel, toffee, roast malt, coffee.

Medium body, lively carbonation. Semidry finish.

One of the best brown ales I've had.
This is passable as a brown ale, the taste isn't quite up to snuff as some others and the texture is alright.

Dark tan coloured beer with offwhite head which becomes mottled after a while. Strong yeasty, slighty chalky smell. First up I notice it's carbonated, then sweet, feels slightly syrupy on the tongue. Tastes of sugar with fairly subtle hops gradually asserting themselves to some sort of Kendal mint cake effect. Definitely a sipper and this is a 750ml bottle, so it lasts a matter of hours.

My first beer of this style. Poured from a 11.2 oz bottle into a Chimay goblet. This beer has a brown dense color with a big frothy off-white head. Head retention is excellent and there is lots of filmy lacing on the sides of the goblet. Aroma is sweet caramel malt and some Belgian yeast. The taste is similar but also includes a bit of dark fruit (plums figs etc.) The flavor is somewhat complex and very inviting. Mouthfeel is rich, malty and smooth. A very easy-drinking beer. I would gladly try this one again.

Bottle dated 10/09/22. IDK if that is Oct 9 or Sep 10. Never mind …

The aroma is a bit subdued. Spicy. Peppery. Clove. A bit of a banana bread aroma.

The beer is dark from the front, clear ruby with a back-light, with ample small bubbles of carbonation. It is topped with a thick, tan-to-off-white, head with excellent retention. Thick lacing remains on the opposite side of the chalice as I take a sip.

The taste is much richer than the subtle aroma would lead you to expect. Rich and malty. Banana bread, toffee, pepper and clove. Sweet caramel controlled by the spicy, slightly bitter middle and finish, resulting in a finish on the sweet side. While it would be classified by me as a sweet beer, that is overstating. It is nicely balanced and enjoyable.

The mouth feel is smooth with a creamy remainder on the tongue and throat, broken up by the carbonation.

Overall, quite delightful.

Poured into a wide fluted glass similar to the Leffe Branded glassware. The beer pours a dark brown that is slightly translucent when held up to the light. The head that forms is fluffy off white/brown. It settles to a cap that leaves a nice lace as the glass empties. The smell is light but full of dried fruit and a hint of booze. The taste follows the smell, rich with dried fruit and little warming booze. The feel is good, and the carbonation is just right. The mouthfeel is a little slick, but not in a bad way. Overall, I like this beer. I only bought a single for a tasting, but would gladly purchase a 6 or 12 in the future. I think the big beer connection and easy availability works against this very good beer's ratings (I wrote the last sentence before I posted my review and saw that I gave Leffe Brune a slightly lower than than average rating, oh well).

Sampling a cellar temp 11.2 fl oz bottle poured into my snifter. Freshest before 10/09/2022 on the label. Cheers to a clear date code that I dont need a ring, black light, calculator to figure out!
the beer pours a clear mahogany color with rich ruby highlights on the sides of the glass when held to the light. Several active streams of carbonation rise to the surface. A large pillowy khaki colored head of 4.5 cm foams up even with a very gentle pour. This foam recedes slowly and leaves some dense lattice as I swirl the glass. the foam never fully fades and is a very sturdy surface covering throughout.
Aroma is malt forward with some toffee and a bit of brown sugar, but also a rich dose of cloves and other spice notes. Maybe cinnamon mixed in there. No hop presence and the nose is appealing to me.
First sip reveals a medium body with soft tingly carbonation. Texture is a little slick and the beer drinks easy.
Flavor starts with a bit of caramel which then rolls to spicy yeast character. I get cloves again but here anice flavor comes through, which was undetected on the nose. No hop presence again and the booze is well hidden. This is a nice approachable beer with a good amount of complexity in its yeast profile, without being over the top. Glad I picked this up for the online brown ales tasting. Would drink this again, and may strive to have some on hand on the regular!

11.2 ounce glass poured into a tulip glass. Best before 10/9/22, so pretty fresh.

L---Clear brown color. Massive light brown head had very good retention and left beautiful lacing.

S---Banana, caramel and some light spice.

T---Banana, bread, & caramel.

F---Medium+ bodied with good carbonation.

O---A tasty beer, but there's a lot of beers from Belgium that I'd have first.

"Freshest before 9/10/22"; drank 10/11/21 @ the Yarchives.

Semi-opaque brown/orange appearance.

A slow pour yielded a huge khaki head (careful pouring!); strong, frothy tree-rung lace.

Banana bread, clove & faint caramel notes in the nose.

Creamy, medium mouthfeel.

Banana bread, mild clove & faint brown sugar flavors. I fucking love this; fall in a glass.

330ml bottle into a pint glass. Best by 6/12/21, so a few months late on this one.

Looks splendid in the glass. Deep, deep auburn colored body. Decent off white head persists in good form throughout, leaving scattered lacing

Kind of a caramel aroma without the sweetness.

On tasting, sweeter than the nose would suggest. The balance is a little more bitter than roasty.

Mouth between medium and full, finish a light to medium bitter roast.

Overall, an okay beer. Appreciate the effort at balance. Haven't had many Belgian brown ales, this was just okay.

Yellow golden haze, fluffy white head, nice lacing. There's a nice maltiness to the nose, smooth like oats or wheat almost, but can says brewed with "pale malt", so not sure if that implies all barley... either way, nose also has some candy mango, some sweet starfruit, orange peel, smells great! Taste follows, sweet orange creamsicle juice, still getting that underlying (nice) malty bready backbone, a little dry hoppiness on the finish, and a bit of booze as well. While the smell is the best facet of this one to me, this whole beer is good.

Traded for this the other night as I had no idea what beer this was until I looked on their website. Indeed, this isn't marked on the label as it was quite artistic on the outside and enjoyable out of a glass as this was plenty sweet and fruity with a nice underlying slickness tying everything in together.

Like so many of their more popular offerings, this was hazy, golden, and topped off with plenty of fluffy and long-lasting head. Loads of soapy lacing remained down the side of my pint glass as a thick ring remained near the top with the semblance of rings below it easily covering up a majority of the remaining space. Lots of candied orange, orange blossom, crystalline sugar, and purely dank hops were in the nose as the taste wonderfully followed suit. A nice amount of nectar, passion fruit, exotic tropical fruit, deep forest, and a hint of weed emerged in the taste once this fully warmed up as this had a nice complexity to it without any particular aspect being overpowering. The carbonation was light as this wasn't slick nor sticky, but was nicely balanced when all was said and done.

The amount of alcohol in this was spot-on as I felt a slight warming kick in after I finished this off, but it was never a distraction nor a detraction during any point of my time reviewing this. Dated 8/13 with "KEEP CALM DRINK BEER" written above it, this was worth keeping calm with as this was a textbook New England IPA with lots going for it. Aside from a few bits of bitter sediment that had to be swirled out of the bottom of the liquid, this was subtly wonderful and the reason why I keep drinking Tree House's offerings after all of these years!

Canned 9/28/21. Poured at 53°. Two fingers mousse-like foam with rocks; ok cap retention; solid ring with soapy lace; black with ruby see through with some clarity; medium minus legs on swirl. Strong raspberries jam nose. Taste is slightly tart raspberries; chocolate; no bourbon nor vanilla; a little oak as beer warms. Medium minus body; medium minus carbonation; no warmth from 11.8% abv; thin feel. Overall, a one trick pony - raspberries; very little base and virtually no barrel; very tasty if you like raspberries (I do) but if it weren’t for some chocolate notes, I could be drinking a fruited ale instead of a BBA impy stout…

Look: very dark, imp stout. Big mocha head on the pour that mostly settles down. Some ruby highlights when held to light.
Smell: rich, chocolate raspberries. Hints of vanilla, bourbon, oak.
Taste: like the nose. Truth in advertising!

Opaque reddish black body; fizzy; no head. Big raspberry nose, fresh. Raspberry and mild stout taste; sweet and tart; subliminal chocolate quality. Heavy body; slick; moderate tangy note.

One of the more interesting and uniquely tasty offerings from the brewery's 'Deth By' series. A big beer, heavy yet very approachable in the mid-summer season.

Pouring temperature: 46.8 ℉; canning data: FILLED SEP/28/2021
Nice raspberry taste with chocolate and malt. The barrel is subdued, which I enjoy. The addition of raspberries doesn’t make it better, but it does make it different and a fun variant to try.

Pours a plum-tinted dark brown with two fingers of mocha-colored head that quickly fizz away into a thin cap that leaves decent lacing.

Massive raspberry in the nose, with a hint of cocoa beneath.

Raspberry-forward taste as well, with some dull brown malt and light earthy bitterness. Raspberry juice in the aftertaste.

Medium bodied and slightly creamy with modest carbonation.

Very one dimensional with not much of the base showing.

12oz can
filled SEP/28/2021
L: dark brown body with raspberry hues at the edges when held to light; foamy tan head with some pinky hues fades quickly
S: heavy dose of raspberry & rich chocolate
T: tart raspberries, chocolate, roasted barley, oak; but the bourbon takes a back seat to the raspberry
F: full body, super smooth, no trace of the 11% ABV, ample carbonation, pretty balanced flavor with tart raspberry & chocolate lingering
O: I love raspberries & chocolate! This was great!

Look - Black and thick with a great tan head and sticky lacing
Smell - chocolate raspberries and booze
Taste - quite a bit of raspberries with a nice chocolate backbone but like all deth's, great barrel. Pretty boozy but less than some
Feel - medium full body, a little lighter some others from what I thought. lighter carbonation
Overall - really tasty raspberry barrel aged stout

2021 version from an 8 ounce pour from the Open Bottle. Seems like all four beers in their special underperformed tonight. Kind of weak. Dark appearance with a bit of rosè tint. A berry scent and a berry taste with an extremely mild roasty stout background. Feel is like the taste-subtle. In feel, finish, and booze. I love Revolution’s barrel program. After drinking this one from a tap, I really want to try it canned. I bet it would be better.

This one pours a dark black color, with a small head, and a little bit of lacing.

This smells like jammy raspberry, tobacco, roasted malt, dark chocolate, and bourbon.

The raspberry is added in a gentle and subtle way here, adding some pleasant jammy character. The beer remains dry in the end, with bitter barrel character and clean roast, along with caramelly and slightly fruity bourbon.

This is medium bodied, with a nice warmth, and a smooth drinkability overall.

Revolution is very nearly batting one thousand. This is yet another excellent release.

12oz can poured into Deep Woods Series stemless glass.

canned on date of 9/28/21.

Appearance: Black bodied beer with big and tall medium brown head. head pours easily 3 fingers tall. spotty lacing. head drops down to ring around the glass.

Smell: All raspberries; really jammy raspberries. Raspberry flesh and seed. Is this a fruited lambic? Maybe a very faint hint of bourbon and chocolate; I might be stretching a bit though because I want to be optimistic.

Taste: Jammy raspberry flesh and raspberry seeds. So much raspberry! All I taste is Raspberry. Deth Tar is missing in action here. Maybe a faint hinting of chocolate and bourbon. Finish is tart & jammy raspberries. It still tastes good, but boy do I really want some stout in this raspberry stout.

Mouthfeel: medium bodied stout. moderate carbonation levels. Really creamy texture to the body of this stout. Not boozy at all. Very drinkable.

Overall: This is hard to pass for a stout. SO much raspberry it obliterates any trace of Deth Tar. The Raspberry is spot on and delicious. It tastes really authentic like a raspberry should. Revolution really missed the balance of stout and fruit here. I keep wanting more Deth Tar from this beer with every sip. Haymarket brewing Clare's Thirsty Ale absolutely decimates Deth by Raspberries. This is a one and done for me, glad I did not buy a 4 pack of this stout.

Canned 9/28/21; drank 10/17/21 @ the Yarchives.

Black/brown appearance.

A rough pour yielded a huge dark tan head; decent lace.

Raspberry sorbet, milk chocolate & faint bourbon heat notes in the nose.

Medium mouthfeel.

Raspberry sorbet & milk chocolate flavors up front; tart raspberry, mild oak & faint booze heat notes on the finish.

Balanced, in that it gives both the sweet and the tart elements of raspberry room to shine; thin enough to quaff but you shouldn't. An interesting, tasty fruited stout. I'd have another...

16 oz can.

Pours a hazy pale gold color with a large, very effervescent white head. The head has pretty good retention. Leaves some splotchy lacing.

The aroma brings notes of tangerine, grapefruit, and orange juice. There's some very faint banana lingering in the back.

The flavor has a lot of zesty citrus, bubblegum yeast, and the absolute foggiest idea of banana. Like someone dropped a banana near the tank but not actually in it. Disappointing.

The feel is typical Tree House. Creamy and very soft. Surprisingly dry on the finish.

Overall, this is a good NEIPA, but also a disappointing one. There's, at least according to the can, banana puree in this beer? Could have fooled me. I probably wouldn't even pick up that flavor in a blind taste test. Sometimes added fruits can overpower the base beer, but in this case, it's like they forgot to actually put the fruit in that they advertised on the can.

Hazy yellow brown gold, very fluffy white head, pretty good lacing on the glass. Smell is fruity, creamy, green banana. There's a dryness to the smell that I wasn't expecting. Taste is tropical fruits with a backbone of banana bread if you made the banana bread with fully green bananas, it has that dry banana almost bitter feel to it... like a plantain chip. Honestly, I wouldn't have bought this if it hadn't come in a mix pack, but I'm not disappointed. It's an interesting rif on their usual flavors to me.

Pours ultra hazy, pale gold in color with one quarter inch head. Taste is big citrus, tangerine and light banana. Medium body and carbonation, bitter. I really expected more banana in this and therefore it is disappointing. I was hoping for a more unique beer. Not bad but nowhere near the other Nectarous beers.

Canned 8/25

L: Pours a clear amber. 2 finger off white head with good retention.

S: Caramel, toasted grains

T: Follow the nose. Toasted bread, caramel malt

F: Light, crisp mouthfeel

O: Would drink again, but wouldn’t seek out.

Pours a dark, clear amber color. Thin off-white head forms on the beer without much in the way of head retention.

Aroma has notes of toasted bread, caramel, toffee - very malt forward. There are lighter notes of spicy hops coming through as well.

Taste follows the nose with notes of toasted bready malts, caramel, toffee, with some spicy hops on the back end. Its got the caramel and toffee notes, but its not at all sweet.

Feel is light, crisp, easy drinking. Moderate carbonation. Very dry finish.

Overall a solid oktoberfest from P3.

Pours a clear, deep copper color with a finger of lightly tan head that goes away quickly. Not as much head retention or lacing as you’d expect.

Aroma is overly-toasted bread, slight green apple, toasted grain, light caramel and brown sugar, prune, earthy hops, spice.

Taste follows the aroma well. Lots of toasted bread, slight green apple, lightly caramel iced brown sugar without getting sweet, plum, earthiness and slight floral from the hops.

Medium body. Appearance made this look a little under-carbonated, but it drinks just fine. Slightly crisp, slightly soft, slick, and slightly gritty on the finish. Smooth and quite drinkable.

This is an outstanding Marzen. Has a hefty and complex malt profile without making the beer heavy. Nicely balanced by the classic hop character. Phase Three’s lager program is vastly overlooked.

No canning date (released on 9/9/20, so presumably canned within a few days of that date); consumed on 11/10/20

Pours a clear, deep copper body capped with two fingers of dense, fluffy, off-white foam; great head retention recedes slowly to a thin veil of semi-creamy cap, a slight, frothy collar, and a temporary array of large, splotchy lacing around the walls of the glass.

Aromas of fresh green apple dominate upfront, with a caramel malt undertone steadily combating the fruitiness; heartier undertones of brown sugar and burnt toast nod toward the otherwise slighted roaster notes as hints of prune give a brightness to the close.

Taste shows a lighter green apple presence against balancing caramel malts mirroring the bouquet; a touch of brown bread, root beer, and brown sugar form over the mid-palate before inviting a light, grassy undertone into the finish.

Mouthfeel brings a light-medium body alongside a moderate carbonation fizzing out into the mid-palate, where a semi-dry/crisp texture develops into a more rounded, oily malt character on the back end; the finish brings a distant heft and even grit with a refreshing peak into the swallow.

A genuinely eccentric and untraditional Märzen that, against all odds, comes together fairly well; prominent apple tones blend steadily with an unexpectedly subdued malt profile for a sweeter take on the style with a distinctly autumnal overtone. Nothing spectacular, bur unique and solidly made.

16oz can
L: crystal clear caramel body; foamy beige head holds good retention
S: malty caramelized toasted grain, earthy & spicy hops
T: rich flavors; big caramel, rye bread crust, toasty grain malt presence; spicy/earthy/herbal hops provide a nice balance
F: medium body, super smooth, appropriate moderate carbonation, semi-dry and slightly sweet finish
O: this was a treat; one of the best American brewed Märzens I’ve experienced

*4th place out of 48 in my Ultimate Oktoberfest 2020
This was one of the better Oktoberfest beers I've had in a while. It was very nice and malty with a bready like flavor. Nice caramel flavor to it also.

Love this oktoberfest, has everything you are looking for in the taste. Dark amber body with a tan head that pours perfectly, then fades in a collar with lacing. Smell features toasted caramel, toast, earth, a touch of hops, and malts. Taste is where the beer shines best, everything from the smell with toffee and roasted nuts added, great depth and crispness. Body is medium, toasted, crisp, and slightly bready.

Later batches have not been as complex, score adjusted appropriately.
Tasted in a Spiegelau lager glass from a one pint can on September 17, 2019. Toasted bread notes with subtle caramel character. Very flat feel to this.

Toppling Goliath Brewing 'Pseudo Sue Pale Ale' @ 5.8% , served from a 473 ml can
A-pour is a light yellow gold from the can to a hazy yellow gold in the glass with a small size white head , dissipating into a fine spotty lace ring , last pour has some floaters
S-a single hop pale ale , Citra = juicy ,
T-NE Pale Ale , Citra hops are so juicy , slight dry bitter swallow
MF-mild carbonation , medium body
Ov-this might have been on the shelf at the store for a while , definitely not a fresh beer , maybe that's why it was on sale
prost LampertLand

Look: Pours a creamy, hazy orange reminiscent of an orange Julius. The brew has thick creamy white head. Very Unique.
Smell: The smell is fresh pineapple, hops, and malt.
Taste: Flavor of pineapple, vanilla and malt with a light sweetness and mild hop bite. Refreshing.
Mouthfeel: Creamy and smooth with hop dryness on the back-end.
Canned 1/31/22, marked best by 5/31/22.
Nice balanced taste, good nose and head. I’ve had this on draft for several weeks now and it’s a go to at my local

From pint can marked PKG01/31/22 13:42:36 BEST BY 05/31/22

Seems almost impossible to get FRESH Toppling Goliath here unfortunately.

Pours into my tulip a peach gold shade with a big fluffy creamy ecru head. Lots of particulates in the beer. Head is long lived and leaves fluffy sheets of lace.

Scent is citrus and tropical fruit. Soapy and floral. Papaya, guava, pineapple.

Taste is muddled tropical fruits. Citrus. Pineapple. Mangoes. Malt presence is constrained to a light pretzel note. There's a minty green note also.

Mouth is creamy with a nice weight to it.

This is a very impressive beer considering it is 3 months past its BB date. I can only imagine how great this must be when fresh.

This is pure, unfiltered, and unimaginably delicious beer. 16oz can poured into a snifter at 50F. Opaque hop slurry looking like a glass of orange juice. Head is white, like soap suds, that just hang around the entire time, leaving mountains of lacing on the sides of the glass. Total hop slam to the nostrils; full on dank citrus. Taste is a spectacularly hoppy mess, with a consistency like orange juice, but with hop pulp instead of orange. Good lord this is amazingly hoppy, and full bodied, with very little alcohol to be found, as it is masked by the hop insanity. This is a pale ale? So says the can. Did they accidentally can a bunch of King Sue in the wrong cans? Nope. Picked up a 4 pack of each, and this Pseudo Sue might as well be a solid single IPA when compared to King Sue. Overall one of the best beers I have ever had.

Pours a thick hazy deep amber with an overflowing foamy head.
Bursting with mango, orange scent, grass with fresh rain.
Taste is a complex mixture of various sweet citruses carried on a malty substrait
So it smells like a hazy, taste like a pale ale.
Medium bodied, quite carbonated., finishes clean.
Not sure how this is a pale ale with its extremely hazy nature....that being said it's a damn fine beer. World class beer.

This second-most popular staple from my hometown brewery is initially something I thought was nothing special, but when I matured, I determined that it has pizazz; not overpowering, but just right. Not the absolute most special, but so extremely satisfying and well-crafted.

16oz can purchased from the fridge as a single for $3.49. PKG on 1/31/2022 with a best buy date of 5/31/2022, so this is just over 3 1/2 months old.

Look: Pours a pale golden color with a lot of floaties that eventually settled. There was a nice, fluffly white head that slowly reduced to a very thin layer. The beer became a lot hazier after pouring the bottom of the can.

Smell: Has a pronounced citra hop aroma - lots of grapefruit peel, orange, grassy, with green bell pepper notes on the back end. Smells peppery also and has subtle cantaloupe notes also.

Taste: The taste definitely follows the nose. Strong grapefruit flavors with a moderate to high bitterness on the finish that lingers but does not overpower the palate. It's very drinkable. I think that the flavor filled out a bit also after pouring the bottom of the can.

Feel: Has light to medium body, nicely carbonated.

Overall: Solid single-hop pale ale. To me, this toes the line between a pale ale and an IPA. Personally, I would probably put this closer to IPA territory than pale ale, but I can see both opinions. Regardless, it's very delicious, highly drinkable, and accessible.

One of the better Pale Ales out there. Has a very nice hazy appearance with light fruity tropical smell. I like the taste of the citra hops, juicy and mango citrusy flavor. It's a little light on the overall flavor punch to me because it's a pale ale at 5.8% but I can see why it's rated so high. Quality brew by Toppling Goliath.
Terrific!

Very hazy apricot color with moderate white head that retains well and produces some nice lacing. The aroma is citrus, pine resin with possible mango, pineapple and passionfruit notes, very juicy.
The taste is pine resin and grapefruit up front, mellowing into mildly sweet light malt with lots of tropical fruit notes - orange, pineapple, mango, passionfruit. The finish is lingering passionfruit with a return of the pine, very interesting and tasty from start to finish.
The body is medium, moderate carbonation, smooth and very drinkable.
Altogether this is one tasty and enjoyable brew that I would place somewhere between a NEIPA and a pale ale but it is outstanding, whatever. I already want more.

Simply put, this is a very nice IPA. It’s single-hop Citra, which is unusual in todays world. It’s hazy, but not extreme. It’s fruity, but not overly fat and sweet. Balance is the right word. I normally don’t line hazy IPAs very much, but this one I actually line a lot. A classic, had several gallons of this over the years, drank it again after taking a 2+ year break - it is still very good, I like it a lot. Did I mention: I’ve got a thing for Iowa. That might have played a role, too.

Pours a hazy gold.

Light and inviting floral and citrus aroma.

It tastes surprisingly juicy on the tongue, with tropical and citrus fruit notes. Mild hop bite and malty sweetness behind.

Medium bodied and well carbonated.

Overall a great beer. It’s less sharp and more balanced than Zombie Dust or similar Citra APAs, but quite flavorful. And light enough to pair with spicy food.

Poured from a can dated one month ago.

Appearance: Cloudy straw orange, fluffy white head, very good retention.

Aroma: Hops forward. Citrus notes of oranges, tangerines. Tropical fruit.

Flavor & aftertaste: Citrusy & tropical fruit hops flavors. Restrained but balancing bitterness. Medium sweetness.

Mouth-feel: Medium to full bodied. Light to moderate carbonation. Medium length finish with trailing bitterness.

Overall: I can see why this is so highly rated and popular. In short, it has a simple hoppy aroma and flavor profile emphasizing citrus & tropical fruit notes from Citra hops. It is moderately sweet with a perfectly balanced bitterness that makes it's presence known but quickly fades into the background. It has a medium body making it light enough to not be filling but beefy enough not to feel thin. I like the carbonation level which releases nicely when poured properly. You almost feel like you about to experience some hop burn, but it never got there. Tough review for me because I expect American Pale Ale to be clear to slightly cloudy visually, so I had to give it lower marks visually. But this is one excellent pale ale that I enjoyed drinking.

Brought forth from a tap into a clear pint glass, it arrived with a modest and enduring off-white head. The color is a relatively bright orange-amber, considering how opaque it is. With it, come all the right smells of an American Pale Ale. Malt, hops both citrusy and piney, join with a hint of yeast and alcohol to make a nicely balanced, if not pungent, treat for the nose. These qualities are passed on to the taste, which agrees completely with the nose. The finish contributes a dry bitterness that augments the solid taste. There's just enough alcohol to add another layer without harming the mouthfeel. For the taste and body, there's surprisingly little glass lacing. Nothing new, but this is one good APA.

Pours a cloudy, strawberry wheat color with a white foamy head that hangs for a bit. Some nice lacing surrounds the glass as I sip.

Smells of citrusy hops and a touch of tropical fruits.

Tastes great! Very refreshing.

Mouthfeel is solid. Light carbonation with a nice viscosity.

Overall a solid brew. Haven’t been able to get this in our area until a few years ago and took a long break from reviews. Picked up a 4 pack to try. Worth the wait.

I love nearly all of the stouts produced by Prairie, and I can add Basic Rebecca to the list. I was told Basic Becky was better...but I'll review it at a later date.

Smell of this one is cinnamon and spice, with a slight pumpkin to it. Poured into a glass, there was minimal head...and I was trying to pour it so that it would produce some froth. It's thicker than normal beer, but not syrupy and very little lacing on the glass.

I tasted it both cold and after it was allowed to warm up, either way the flavors were fairly consistent. I prefer the warmer option, to each their own. It tastes like a spiced cake with definite notes of pumpkin, and then the bourbon barrel boozy flavor kicks in...with a spicy flavor that hangs thru the finish.

I really like this one. I assume it's somewhat seasonal, so if you see it, grab it.

Interesting take on a fall stout. Nose is very aromatic pumpkin and spice. Taste follows accordingly, with a big hit of dark chocolate malt base. Barrel comes through in an undistracting way, lending a dry oak finish. Mostly a one and done for me, but decent to try.

12oz bottle pkg date 7/15/22 into a dimple mug.
L: Pours dark marmalade burnt orange w/a slight haze, 1" creamy semi-rocky light khaki head w/good retention, med-low carbonation, some sticky skeletal lacing & light banding.
S: Caramel malts, honey, orange zest, bready, lightly earthy.
T: Caramelized malts, a short hop bite, a sensation of black tea, cocoa powder, brown bread, earthy hop flavor, light sweetness but not too sticky.
F: Soft, creamy, med-light bodied mouthfeel w/a moderately fast, lightly drying finish. Good fine carbonation.
O: A great tasting, well balanced American Marzen that is not too sweet or too malty. Very nice flavors, smooth, drinks quite easily and may be a tad bit lighter in body than others in this style but overall it is very good.

Pours a light copper with tiny little bubbles feeding a solid two fingers of off-white, vaguely wheat-y head that eventually settles into a mildly lacy ring. I've seen prettier beers but this looks fine. Smells, somehow, like Fall to me. I realize that really doesn't mean anything and isn't terribly helpful, but there you go. It's malt-forward, as expected. There's some vague, sugary candy undertones like cheap caramels or candy corn. Tastes pretty nice. Not as sweet as implied by the nose, but still very malt-forward. Some herbal bitterness from the hops cuts things on the back end. Tasty and well-balanced. Crispy as a cool Fall morning. Very solid all around.

Bottle from the Packie.
Mostly clear deep golden color bordering on amber with a wispy white head that persists. Bready toasty caramel maltiness with hints of spicy floral hops. A bit sweet for the style but most American brewers struggle making this right.

12 ounce bottle poured into a tulip glass. Packaged 7/22/22 with a three month shelflife, so just fine.

L---Crystal clear, medium amber color. Frothy, off-white head faded quickly to a cap and left good lacing.

S---Malty, but with some hops for balance. Bread dough.

T---Toasty malts. Bread and some caramel.

F---Medium bodied with good carbonation.

O---A nice one.

From a 12oz bottle dated 7/22/22 into a pint glass.

Pours a translucent copper color with about one finger of white head. Decent retention and lacing.

Smells strongly of bready malts and corn. Some sweet floral notes in the background.

Taste is fairly sweet and not as strong as the aroma. Some light caramel and bread.

Light sweet aftertaste with a hint of bitterness. Pretty clean drinking. Medium carbonation. Thin bodied.

Overall, this is a nice enough and enjoyable to drink but doesn't seem to have enough oomph for a marzen.

Honestly a little disappointing to me. It looks nice with a good amber color and nice bottle, smells like a good Märzen, but honestly wasn't as tasty as I was hoping. I don't know what it is. It has a simple hearty malt and bready flavor, but but it also has this kind of has this gross almost watered down bottom of the barrel cheap American beer side to it too. Almost like someone took a Märzen and mixed it with a Bud Light. I don't know if it's me, but just that particular six pack got like to warm and in the sun at one point, but it was off. Not entirely gross, just not as good as I was hoping with some gross notes.

This is a 12oz. bottle poured into the Bell's pint glass. The brew is a nice dark looking amber, just a thin cap of tan foam, this beer is clear with light carbonation.
What this marzen lacks in appearance, it makes up in aroma. From the time the cap was popped there has been a pleasant malt, fresh biscuit aroma, slightly sweet.
The flavor is mighty fine also, following the aroma perfectly. The mal is up front, sweet fresh biscuits, caramel, finishing with a nice light bitter touch of hops, with a touch of pepper spice.
The mouthfeel is slightly creamy, the carbonation does not much to the feel.
This one is all over the rating map, it lacks a bit on appearance, smells great, tastes like a marzen, but misses on the nice creamy feel. This is very good but not great.

Look: Hazy orange. One finger of white head that immediately dissipates.

Smell: Sweet malt, spicy and slightly metallic hops.

Taste: Biscuity malt, a little metallic and citrusy hops, sweet and crisp finish with lingering bitterness.

Mouthfeel: Average body, high carbonation.

Overall: A mild, drinkable, unspectacular fall beer.

Poured into a pint glass, producing a pure white head that slowly dissipated into a thin film with nice clinging. Body is an amber gold. Nose is typical of marzen beers...light notes of bread, malts and very light caramel. Taste is better than most domestic marzens I have tried, maltiness with a touch of sweetness and a slight hop presence. The feel/ body has a little more weight to it than some others of this style, which I really liked. Overall, a nice Oktoberfest that I will buy again
Marzen is good!

This is a good one! Poured from 12-ounce bottle into a vintage hollow-stemmed goblet. Clear golden copper color, with a finger of white head that settled rather quickly. Medium bodied, good carbonation (enhanced by nucleation points etched into the bottom of the stem), plenty of malty goodness without being overly sweet, and a finish that is slightly astringent with an understated hop bite and a little tart apple lingering on the palate. I'm no expert, but this is what I look for in an Oktoberfest beer. Don't forget the brats and sauerkraut!
One of the better American oktoberfest beers for sure. Really enjoyed this.

12 oz bottle, poured into a willi becher at ~40 degrees F.

L: Pours a crystal clear honey-amber, and forms a thin layer of white head that vanishes relatively swiftly.
