Clear amber body, cream head. Smell is pretty basic but solid: caramel malts, toast and slight brown bread, faint. Taste is pretty much the same, more caramel forward than anything. Body is malty yet light, crispness lacking, just a generic feel for a oktoberfest. Not bad beer, no glaring weakness just bland

Pours a mostly clear copper color.Smell of baked bread spice and malts,thou light . Taste is same as smell with everything light, it is still tasty would have liked more hops,malt and spice. I miss Surlyfest.

Deep gold with excellent clarity; one finger of white head; good cap retention, solid ring; sudsy lacing; excellent streaming carbonation. Nose is lightly toasted malt; also a very light spicy hop presence. Taste is lightly toasted malt; a scōsh of hop bitterness; more baked bread and very little sweetness. Medium body, moderate minus carbonation; no warmth from 6% abv; very light creaminess in the feel. Overall I liked this fest bier more than the German (HB) just drank; Surly was less sweet and very drinkable.

12-oz.can (Canned on 8/13/20) into a 16-oz. mug. A moderately strong pour yields a finger of creamy light beige foam with long retention and spots of lace. Clear amber-straw color, yellow-gold in sunlight.

Bready malt, toast, dough and cracker greet the nose with very faint floral hops.

Neutral taste with low bitterness, toasted malt shines. Apple, attempting to be sweet is the only taste other than malt and faint hops. Cracker and toasted malt stand out over bread and dough. The finish is quick, crisp and clean and on the dry side. Bitterness builds to average during the lingering aftertaste.

Medium light bodied and perfectly carbonated. Alcohol is very well hidden. Smooth and session-able, balanced and true to style. Not as dark and sweet as Beers labeled Marzens, not as hoppy as many Festbier. Right in the middle.

A: The beer is crystal clear yellowish amber in color and has a light amount of visible carbonation. It poured with a narrow collar of white bubbles and some specks of bubbles on the surface.
S: Light to moderate aromas of toasted malts are present in the smell along with hints of spicy hops.
T: The taste follows the smell and has flavors of toasted malts along with a bit of associated sweetness and faint hints of spicy hops.
M: It feels nearly medium-bodied and very clean on the palate with a moderate amount of carbonation.
O: I liked the aromas and flavors of toasted malts in this Oktoberfest, which seemed a little lighter in body and easier to drink compared to other beers in the style.

Serving type: can

Poured from an unfortunately undated 16oz can

On the pour, this is a beautiful golden ale. Super fine but active carbonation with a huge head that has great structure. It stays rocky and fine for a real long time. Some light lacing forms.

Aroma is basically a weaker version of a big belgian blond with some light spicy and even lighter fruity notes, but there is a nice bright citrusy lemony note. Behind the lemon is a nice sweet herbal smell that's likely a mix of hops and fermentation.

Taste is very nice. More drinkable than traditional duvel but still quite flavorful. Very bright and lemony, but then a nice biscuity maltiness comes in and balances everything very nicely. There is a slight hit of hop bitterness but it fades pretty quick but still does some nice work in making this crisp. This is a pretty sweet beer without the bottle conditioning.

Feel is relatively dry and effervescent. The finish is long and the malt is mouthcoating, but not overwhelming. Surprisingly crisp but also big. This is a pretty dang good year round anytime but session time beer.

Overall I enjoyed this quite a bit. More refreshing and malty than traditional duvel, but not lacking flavor in the slightest. Super beautiful through and through, and everything about this is enjoyable.

Bought a single 16oz can $4.99 Village Bottle Shop
200 days before best by date
Smell of citrus, floral
Clear golden color
Medium-light mouthfeel
Medium carbonation
Taste of citrus, lemons, grapefruit, tart apples
Overall just ok. Doesn't have the stronger flavors that I associate Belgian Ales with. More like a watered down cheaper version.

1 pint can into a pint glass. Date on can is 1/26/21, so over a year old.

Looking very good in the glass. Pale golden yellow body. Small bright white head shrinks to a collar and solid covering leaving rings of lacing.

Aroma is yeasty, grassy, with a faint whiff of hops.

On tasting, overall a very tasty beer. Smooth, sweet, a light bitter hop note. Abv seems higher than listed.

Mouth between medium and full, finish a lasting sweet-bitterness, abv felt. There is a late very mild metallic note which spoils it a bit.

Overall, other than the metallic note, a tasty, enjoyable drink. Happy to have another 3 in the fridge.

16oz can

Looks great, completely clear and bubbly: movie beer. It smells like it tastes, crisp and clean and yeasty, just a little fruit: lemon green apple banana, slight spice and a little bit of some lemony bitter hops; kind of disappointed on the hop taste considering the side of the can boasts about the citra hops they used - it barely comes across and has a slick feeling kinda rancid sweetness that comes across better in the scent. More slick and syrupy as it warms, should be drier. Drink it fast. Expensive as all heck, I tell ya hwhat

Try it if your pockets are deep, but for $16 a 4-pack I want a really good Belgian - this ain't it

Crowler filled 1/15/22; drank 1/16/22 @ the Yarchives.

See-through pale orange/yellow appearance.

A rough pour yielded a huge white head; strong, frothy lace.

Fresh apple & dry yeast notes in the nose.

Medium mouthfeel.

Fresh apple & dry yeast flavors; this is simple, direct and very pleasant. I'd have another...

First off, it pours very very clear. A pretty golden color with a white, thin head. Smells of bread, lemon maybe. Very pleasant. Love the taste. Reminds me of a festbier! Hate that it is pricey. But very worth it!

16 oz can poured into a tulip glass.

Pours a clear pale straw yellow with ample head that recedes to a fine lace. This beer is almost pilsner-like in its appearance. The yeast esters that are present in Duvel are here but much more sublte with citrus hop bitterness coming in the finish.

16oz undated can poured into a tulip shows a pale yellow, clear body with active rising bubbles to a persistent cap of white bubbles and leaves sparse lacing.

Bready and clove aromas lead into a fruity flavor.

Mouthfeel is light, almost thin, with a drying finish.

Overall a clean, light, fruity beer.

L- Mid gold and transparent beer with a short 1F head.

N- Yeast, clove, white bread

T- Smooth sweet malt with a nice yeast lead. Clove/allspice note is light and refreshing. A nice mild bitterness from the hops leaves a bit of spice on the finish. Light cantaloupe / banana vibe but faint and adds to the taste. A tang I associate with Belgian style beer is present and in the background vs some other Belgians I have had.

M- Smooth medium feel with lots of very fine bubbles. A bit of thickness on the back of the throat but clean and not cloying.

O- This is a great beer. The combination of the typical Belgian flavor notes is done on a more subtle level and it works really well for my palate. Superb!

Single Fermented Golden Ale by Duvel comes in a bright golden sunny color with a light froth (served in a "verre ballon"). Subdued, Belgian-signature coriander backdrop. The light malts stay beneath a bright hoppiness that leaves a pleasantly dry aftertaste in the mouth.
In spite of its high 6.8% ABV, this is a great choice for a warm summer day.
Last day of June 2021 at the D&V, in Shorewood, WI.

L: transparent light gold, decently large head with nice lacing.

S: along with its appearance, aroma is the prime attributes of this beer. Crisp, clean, yeasty with a little sweetness and spice.

T: Taste is similar to the nose with a crisp and dry finish. I don’t get the banana and fruitiness I usually associate with the Duvel strong ale, I do get some pepper and yeast.

F: Toward the lighter end of a medium-bodied ale. Carbonation isn’t overwhelming.

O: overall it’s a decent golden ale. It’s subtle, possibly too subtle, and refreshing.

Poured into tulip glass: color is straw, transparent, bright white head with fine bubbles, frothy top and head presents nearly 2 fingers thick.

Smell is cracker malt, crisp noble and light citrus hops, musty yeast but not overpowering.

Taste is light, dry, just the right amount and balance of hops, malt, and yeast; flavors are crackers, biscuit, lemon, grass, musty yeast.

Mouthfeel is moderate carbonation, low sweetness, dryyy finish.

Overall an excellent golden ale - bright, crisp, pleasant malt and yeast notes.

On tap at House of Brews Jensen Beach. Clear golden. Smells of Belgian yeast, light fruitiness, some grain, pungent peppery aroma. Tastes of yeast, pepper, light grain, a bit of a fruity note. Earthy peppery finish. Medium body. Good.
Weak head. Very clear/straw color. Dry, banana, phenol. Best drunk by the stein. The little duvels will sneak up on you.

Light straw color with a small white head after an aggressive pour. Nose is sweet, bubble gum, funky, lemon, hoppy, banana and pear. Taste follows the nose and you pick up some white pepper and cloves, as well. Has a medium mouthfeel and a dry finish. No detection of alcohol and drinks like a five percent. Not bad, but pricey for a 4 pack. Not as good as regular Duvel.

L: light gold, big white head, good lacing
S: bready, a little funky, Belgian yeast
T: follows the nose to a tee, also I get apple/pear
F: good mouthfeel for a light beer
O: nice twist on a classic

500 ml can into a chalice.

Pours a hazy straw color with minimal white head. Leaves some sticky lacing before settling into a thin halo.

Lots of fruity esters and Belgian yeast on the aroma. Banana chips, clove, and peppery spices throughout. Faintly hoppy on the back end. Good aroma for the style.

The flavor is much of the same, lots of yeast and clove and fruity esters. Some dark fruits. Banana bread. Good stuff. Just a faint touch of pepper and hops on the finish.

The body is medium-light, with moderate carbonation. Crisp and nicely dry. About right for the style.

Overall, this is a very good Belgian ale that's highly drinkable but flavorful too. Not a good appearance for the style but otherwise everything is on point. Good beer.

16oz can purchased from the fridge as a single for $4.50. There is a lot code on the bottom of the can, hard to tell if this is a Julian date or not. If so, 127 would correspond to a canning date of 5/6/20. Can also has a best by date of 1/26/21.

Look: Pours a beautiful golden color. No haze at all - completely clear. A nice white head upon the pour, reduced to a thin cling to the rim of the glass. Very tiny bubbles quickly rising to the surface.

Smell: Lots of Belgian yeast character in the nose - spicy/peppery, clovey, and nice lemony/grassy hop aroma. Underlying sweet biscuity malt aroma present also. Given that this is dry hopped with Citra, the citrus aroma is pretty reserved. The noble hop aroma is more dominant.

Taste: This is pretty refreshing, crisp, and dry. It's very drinkable and the 6.8% ABV is hardly noticeable. Up front, notes of clove from the Belgian yeast along with biscuity malt. The beer moves through the palate quickly with moderate carbonation and finishes with peppery spicy and slightly bitter and grassy Noble hop notes. Finish is very dry and crisp, refreshing. The Citra dry-hopping is not so prevalent in the taste to me. I'm getting some mild citrus notes reminiscent of lemon zest lingering on the finish, but I wouldn't mind if they were more agressive. They may also be subdued based on how fresh this beer is, which is hard to know.

Feel: Mouthfeel is relatively light to medium, yet full and appropriate for its weight. It works very well for this type of beer.

Overall: This is a solid Belgian Golden Ale. Given the freshness questions that I mentioned above, it's hard to say how much the Ctira dry-hopping is enhancing this beer. I think that it definitely works well, but personally I think that it is too subtle. I would like to try a fresher can.

On-tap in Idaho Falls; served in a chalice.

A: Beautiful clear pale with a soapy bright white head.

S: Fruity yeast esters, musty Belgian tones, bright citrus and banana aromas, hints of black pepper and coriander spice.

T: Malty sweet banana and light clove, smooth dryness with a musty, phenolic flavor, ghostly grassy character, vanilla.

MF: Creamy medium body, very smooth, slightly dry:

O: A pleasant Belgian pale/strong - has all of the notes you’re looking for in a malty pale with Belgian yeast.

Pours a clear gold with a thick bone white head. Nose is yeast driven. Citrus esters and a cellar must type phenol that's common with Belgians. Flavor is yeast driven and follows the nose with a slight lactic bite. I'm not getting the citra hops. Its effervescent and bone dry. I dig the beer over all... it's not a citra ipa, but is a great Belgian beer that I could drink by the gallon.

Why not try two brown twelve ounce bottles at once? The best way to do this is to empty both bottles into a clear glass liter mug. Here's another one that provides a stark white foam, rather than a proper IPA head. OK, it's far from the worst offender. The brew itself is a light golden amber and it's fairly translucent. There's a mild piney and earthy hop aroma to be had and there's almost no maltiness. The taste is disappointing. Although it's not lopsidedly out of balance between malt and hops, overall it's just lame. From their beginning, Sierra Nevada has offered decidedly hoppy beers with a good malt backing, way before most other American brewers. This has neither. The body is thin and the hops are bland and one dimensional. There's absolutely no hop taste transition that usually occurs in a good IPA. Those usually change from some sort of taste reference that is citrus, pine or fruit, into something either dry or bitter. It doesn't happen here. In a blind taste, this would be below average. Knowing that it came from this brewery, it's demoralizing. Mild demarcation by an otherwise scanty glass lacing can't salvage this one.

From an undated bottle sampled September 14, 2022.

Decent looking beer with it's brass-amber and heady appearance.

I pick up apple, berries, and other fruit sensations immediately with a lower profile white bread note and dank note.

Medium or better mouthfeel.

The taste is primarily sweet and fruity with a mustiness for good measure. Mild to moderate bitter finish.

Another beautiful looking Sierra Nevada beer, SN is very good or better at bring the public amazing looking beers and rightfully so. For the most part their beers are above the industry standard and I have enjoyed their beers for many years now. Having said that, this Cold Torpedo beer does NOT live up to their reputation. The appearance once again is very well done, although the aroma of hops is present is is very weak and seems one dimensional and that follows through with the taste, I very much wish it had been much stronger as the taste/aroma of regular Torpedo brings across. Granted, with all the competition and styles and etc., etc. going on in the market today breweries are trying this that and the other thing to increase or even maintain their piece of the pie, this beer fails to meet SN's standards, but I did drink it all while typing this so its not a bad beer by any stretch, just not up to SN's standards.

Poured from a 12 oz bottle dated 6/03/22 into a Willi Becher pint glass.
L - Pours a lemon yellow color with a white head that dissipates slowly leaving lacing on the glass.
S - Smells of pine and lemons.
T - Tastes bitter with a slight hint of lemon
F - Medium body and carbonation.
O - Interesting take on an IPA. I would drink it again.

12 oz bottle from an Ingles near the NC brewery with a June 2022 bottling date stamped on the back label.

Appearance. Clear amber colored body with high clarity and a good white head.

This innovative brew is notably crisp and clean, although not as fruity as the label description suggests.

The name makes me thing of the episode of the Simpsons where they go to New York. Duff Extra Cold and all that.

Anyway pours a straw yellow that just looks thin with some weak head. Doesn’t look great.

Aroma is of pine forest, butter, oily resin, bit of grass. Decent but simple and a bit muddled.

The oily mouthfeel is much more robust than the aroma or appearance would indicate. Full bodied and rich, pleasantly carbonated.

Tastes of pine, honey, incredibly pleasant floral bouquet, oranges with a teeny bit of pineapple.

Overall the incredible mouthfeel and above average taste more than make up for the lackluster appearance and smell. It’s a good filler for a mix pack but I wouldn’t buy a case of it when the regular torpedo or SNPA is available. Still, worth a try!

12 oz. bottle poured into a snifter glass and from a mix-o-pack. The beer pours a light golden in color with a hint of haze. Bit of wheat 'green' look to it though not sure what the malt bill looks like. Light cap drops some lace and regenerates with a spin. Firmly carbonated.

Aroma is clean and spicy/peppery with some subtle tropical fruit notes. Expands a bit with warming.

Taste is lightly bready with a touch of fruit and finishes with a flash of bitterness which also expands a bit with warming. Overall the jury is still out. My first Cold IPA and not sure where it fits in my universe. Agree with others that the use of the word Torpedo is a bit misleading, beer vs. machine. Still, an easy quaff at 7 percent.

From the Sierra Nevada blog: "We brew our Cold IPA using lager yeast, fermented warmer than usual, to give Cold Torpedo its light and clean backbone. That temperature bump helps reduce the sulfur-like notes that lager yeast can create when kept at its normal range of 42–55 ºF." I guess this temperature bump is the argument to give this style it's own name, but this is not an ale! I would call this an India Pale Lager, which I am a big fan of.

This 12 oz bottle was from a 12 pack mix I picked up at the grocery store and is dated 06/03/22, then consumed on 08/17/22. I have to rate the look lower because they are labeling this as an ale when it's actually a lager, but it has that traditional golden color a lager would have. The smell is fairly mild, a subtle but funky piney aroma. The taste has a light malt flavor, followed by a well balanced bitter aftertaste. The feel is crisp and light, good level of carbonation.

Overall, I actually love this beer, but I hate the name. This is a biased review because I am a fan of hoppy lagers and Sierra Nevada, but I am disappointed in the name choice. It doesn't taste anything like their Torpedo Extra IPA, or any ale for that matter. Probably a bad marketing decision, but at least it tastes good!

Packaged 03/31/22 -- from the SN Hoppy Sampler Pack. Poured into my Libbey Imperial Pint.

How to rate a "Cold" IPA? As an American IPA? Dunno.

L -- Clear, pale gold with a tall, dense white head that leaves good lacing.

S -- Citrus and stone fruit nose with a touch of alcohol. Light white bread aroma back and DMS in the "fresh" form. Pretty light all around.

T -- Citrus fruits and spicy, bitter hops up front. Alcohol hotness and a light breadiness back. Fruit esters in the finish and into the after taste, but after taste is more hot, peppery alcohol with spicy, bitter hops dominant -- even a touch solvent.

M -- Mouthfeel is dry and crisp with a light-medium body.

O -- This brings to mind hoppy malt liquor. Something about the light malt and hot alcohol character reminds me of strong U.K. lagers -- with fruity and spicy hop accents. Probably couldn't drink more than one or two.

Pours a clear bright yellow color, fairly nondescript aroma. Meh, a bit thin in flavor and mouthfeel. Bitter as expected, but not really balanced. It's not a bad beer but it's not something I would seek out. I still think the original Torpedo was the best of the various Torpedos, this one seems more gimmicky to me.

From a 12oz bottle dated 4/20/22 into a pint glass.

Pours a translucent light golden yellow with about two fingers of white head. Great retention, moderate lacing.

Smell is mild. Getting light pine, citrus and bread.

Taste is light. Slightly fruity and sweet. Some pine mixed in. Bitter and slightly dry on the back end.

Thinner mouthfeel. Medium carbonation. Bitter aftertaste.

Not what I was expecting. Not bad, but I think I'd take regular Torpedo any day of the week.

Drinking this one straight out of the bottle and iced cold. Wow!! If you are a lover of Torpedo, Dankful, and Atomic Torpedo you are going to enjoy this one. Hops, hops, and hops. I love this beer as I do with all hoppy beers. Two thumbs up for me about Cold Torpedo.

Pours a clear light amber golden color with a nice head and lacing
Aroma has generous fruit and hop hints
The taste follows the nose with a well balanced fruit and hop flavor
A medium bodied well carbonated beer
A good India Pale Ale

Bottled 3/31/22 from a Publix supermarket.

Pour: Golden clear with a touch of haze but not enough to hinder seeing through the beer. Beautiful white head of foam.

Smell: Like a fruit filled garden that a semi truck full of hops just crashed into. Its beautiful with a hint of lager? Loving it.

Taste: When that hop filled truck crashed crushing that fruit garden the juices ran into a bottle. That bottle was poured into this beer during brewing. Its so drinkable that it would surprise the most snobbiest of beer drinkers.

A+ love it!

A very good beer but a little dishonest with the marketing. If you look at the Sierra Nevada website you can clearly tell that this beer is not an IPA. In fact this beer is not even an ale. It is fermented with lager yeast. It tastes like an IPL or a stronger pilsner. Delicious hoppy flavors and a crisp refreshing lager feel/body. I guess they wanted to capitalize on the allure of the "IPA" marketing label. This beer is 100% hoppy lager and I love it.

COld 12 oz. bottle poured into stange glass. dated from june, so pretty fresh by local (sub)standards. Looks nice, light golden and fairly clear, with a nice white head that has longevity. Aroma is faint but pleasant. My sniffer is toasted from nose hits. Taste is very good. Very nicely balanced, lager-like ale that is hiding the 7%abv, and very drinkable. Nice clean and dry finish. One of the best "new" ipa's lately. Just grabbed the hoppy mix box of 12 ipa's because of the good deal on it, and it's always a safe bet when trying a new Sierra Nevada. Even if you don't like it, you know it was well made. I think this could convert my lager only friends into ipa territory. Recommended

Went ahead and bought the variety 12 pack, because hey, 3 of the beers in there are the greatest ale of all time. Easy to take a chance on a new beer when they package it up with the gold standard (SNPA).

This pours noticeably lighter colored SRM than OG Torpedo. This is straight up yellow. 1/2" white head. Not the best clarity I've seen from Sierra Nevada (below average for them). The hops seem to be similar to regulare Torpedo, that is, for bittering. I think they stuck w the hop bill, something Magnum, maybe Simcoe and C hop(s).

The taste is basically a less malty, less caramel like Torpedo. It does have a crisper snap to the mouth feel. Ample bitterness. Lots of pine if you have never had Torpedo. Some grapefruit rind.

PKGD: 4/20/22 opened and reviewed on 7/13/22

Look: A totally clear.. (did I just say clear??) Gold color. Light, white foam cap covers well and sticks around a bit too.

Nose: slight pine and pineapple, zingy citrus and sweet, spicy golden malt. Subtle, yet interesting aromatics.

Feel & Flavor: A long and slick malty feel, pretty clean overall with an excellent straight ale flavor to balance out the zesty fruits and tanginess of the frigid fermentation. Zesty pineapple and peppery citrus notes are only outshined by the malt complexity.

Overall: I really like IPA'S that have a solid and clean malty backbone, especially when it's a golden malt. The "Ale" forward flavor's make it seriously drinkable for 7% and the hops are mid-level complexity at best but still stands as interesting.

The beer pours to a hazy golden color with a long-lasting head. Aroma is of fruits and pine. Slight tangy taste immediately fades to a clean tasteless finish, leaving only a faint taste of hops behind. A clean and crisp beer that delivers a unique IPA experience.

Picked up a single from the Mills River Gift Shop 5-26-22 for $1.75. Packaged 4-20-22; consumed 7-2-22.

Beer poured a clear gold with a beautiful white head that is leaving lacing behind.

Nose is floral hop forward.

Taste is a nice bready malt base infused with a light touch of Cascade giving a touch of citrus finishing with nice peppery hop bite leading to a crisp smooth and bitter finish; 7/10 on my scale.

Mouthfeel is light to medium bodied and refreshing.

Overall a nice effort from the brewing team, like the lager like vibe!

From the rear label: "PKGD 03/31/22"

Appearance: The body is a medium gold color with a medium haze, making it difficult to see through the glass but items are clearly identified. The head is short, white, and creamy textured. It has good head retention and leaves nice sheets of dense bubbles on the glass.

Aroma: There is a light minty pine aroma that comes through at first, then a light bit of alcohol.

Taste: Pine hits the tongue first, then it picks up a touch of mint with a light candy sweetness. There is a bitter pine and a touch of grapefruit peel towards the middle of the mouth. It doesn't change towards the back of the palate or in the aftertaste. Mostly it has a minty pine character which is nice but also mellow.

Mouthfeel: It is very smooth with an almost slick consistency. It has a nice bitterness which is on the stronger side. It lingers on the palate with a smooth finish.

Overall: It is an interesting beer. The back label states that this "DELIVERS THE FRUIT-FORWARD HOP RUSH YOU'RE AFTER" however it seems more pine and mint focused, with only a touch of grapefruit. It also states that this "FINISHES ULTRA CRISP AND CLEAN" which it does not. It sticks to the palate and lingers. The beer is still good and I would recommend that people try it if they enjoy a lot of pine in their IPA's, but it seems to miss the brewer's intent. It is fairly one-note and has this smooth slickness which just feels odd when compared to the relatively high bitterness. I could still drink it again but I would probably buy regular Torpedo if given the choice.

12 ounce bottle poured in a tulip IPA glass.

Translucent gold color, no haze except for the condensation on the outside of the glass. White soapy cap, 1f, sticky lacing.

Classic ale aromas of fresh dough, light caramel and a little diacetyl. Some mild citrus, berry, and melon.

Caramel malt and citrus hop flavors. Orange, grapefruit peel, and herbal.

Medium bodied with a nice mix of malt smoothness and hop bitterness. Dry finish line.

It goes down easy. Its 7% abv is covered up. The hop flavors are mild, yet it’s bitter.

Bottled 04/08/22

Appearance - Pours with a light haze and is golden orange in color. White, half finger width head that dissipates rather quickly, leaving behind a thin, broken layer of suds with a thin, consistent ring hugging the edge of the glass. Sparse lacing, with a handful of small spots making a virtual sad face.

Smell - Floral hops and a juicy citrus aroma really stand out.

Taste - Follows the nose. Bright citrus, orange and tangerine, and floral hoppiness take the stage here, with a bready malt backbone and a kiss of caramel sweetness. Touch of grapefruit mid-taste. Finish displays a trace of pine and light citrus pith bitterness.

Mouthfeel - Light-to-medium in body with fair carbonation. Slick, smooth drinker before a lightly dry finish.

Overall - Really solid brew. Easier drinking than the standard Torpedo but hopheads would probably prefer the former. It's lighter, brighter profile certainly makes for a friendlier summer drinker. I would by more of this if it came in it's own sixer instead of only being able to get it in their 12 pack mixer.
Slightly hazy appearance. Flavor is a little more fruit-forward and not as bitter as their standard Torpedo.
Pretty decent ipa. Balanced with a sneaky 7% abv. Medium body, floral and citrus hops. Pours like a typical hazy.

Appearance: Pours a completely hazy (5% clarity) light and pale yellow color with a creamy looking body. A strong, creamy white head. SRM of 6. (4.50)

Aroma: Strong and dank aromas of tropical melon, berries, some nectarine with a dank foresty malt underneath. Slightly sweet aromas.

Flavor: Strong dank and juicy flavors of tangerine, dank berries, melon. Blackberries, blueberries. Some phenolic notes. A sweet finish. Dank, and somewhat bitter pine off the finish.

Feel: Medium-bodied. Moderate carbonation. Finish is crisp and somewhat bitter.

Compared to Modist Midwest Mindset 8/29/22: Pours a lighter, hazier color. Milder aromas. More dank berry, melon, tangerine. Less citrus rind, flower, herbs, mango, pineapple. Sweeter, danker, and more hop burn.

Overall: Certainly showcases the DDH Mosaic here. Dank berries and melon. Some appreciable bitterness here, whether from the hops or the hop burn I am not sure. Sort of cleans the palate of the sweetness. A bit too bitter and hop burn for my liking, but the appearance is there and the body wants to be there, but consumed by hop burn and/or bitterness. (Rating: 4.07)

A: The beer is very hazy yellow in color - too hazy to see if there is any visible carbonation. It poured with a quarter finger high white head that quickly settled down, leaving just a narrow collar around the edge of the glass.
S: Moderate aromas of lime citrus and gooseberry are present in the nose along with notes of lychee and hints of mango.
T: The taste has flavors of lime and lychee along with notes of mango. Little to no bitterness is perceptible.
M: It feels medium-bodied and juicy on the palate with a moderate amount of carbonation.
O: This beer had a nice balance between the aromas and flavors of citrusy and tropical fruits.

Serving type: can
16oz can from Tavour. Looks like a glass of orange juice. Starts out smelling like one too. Citrus peel, fruity hops. Taste is citric, zesty with a dry feel. Starts juicy, ends hoppy.

So got this in a craft variety pack for the holidays and cracked into this North Dakota NEIPA. Being a New Englander, I have high expectations for this style but the beer definitely is solid. Classic NEIPA tropical haze and thickness, with a slight head that fades. Smells a little funky and not sure why but tastes super tropical and pulpy like an OJ. Not bad from Fargo, ND, but I’ll stick to Vermont and the rest of New England.

Really enjoyed ectogasm and was excited to try this one, but found it to be a step too far. Starting with the feel, where the orignal was pillowy, smooth yet had a good hope finish, this one is broken up by the imbalance with the hops, making the body feel watery with jagged hop textures as the only diversity. This undermines the taste with the flavors besides hop bitterness, citrus pith and lemon being taken out of the equation almost immediately, but the hops are flavorful and full. Nose is all hops, airy and bitter with huge citrus and lighter melon tones. Looks great though, hazy bright yellow with a full white head and light lacing. Balance is just off here

Hazy lighter golden almost milkshake like look with a thin white head, this brew looks quite nice. An immediate almost orange juice like scent just jumps out of this can when cracked. Juicy and well balanced with a gentle lingering grapefruit juice like bitterness on the end. Slight alcohol felt on this one. On the thinner side of medium in feel. Nice beer here.

Pours a standard mimosa color with a smaller white head that dissipates after a minute. It smells like sweet orange peels and slightly tropical pineapple notes with a hint of mango and pine on the finish. The taste has a candied orange peel flavor up front and has a sweet tropical middle and a slightly sweeter piney mango finish. This one is one of the smoothest beers I've ever had and it's a genuine pleasure to drink. Overall very good.

Pours a hazy light orange with fine, soapy head.

Smell is juicy and very hoppy with notes of grass, mango, pineapple and peach.

Taste is juicy with a lot of hops and a bit of hop burn. Notes of mango, pineapple, citrus, grass and some chalkiness. Moderate bitterness with a distinct grapefruit vibe, and a very dry finish.

Mouthfeel is medium, soft and pillowy, well carbonated.

Overall, a great NE IPA, really proving what DDH is all about.

16 oz can, was swayed by the salesman on this one.

Pours a milky smooth creamy pale blonde with a creamy head of 2 fingers, leaving tons of lace behind as it recedes to a thick ring.

In the aroma, Citra and Mosaic come forward with gooseberries and some slight cattiness. Some damp dirty laundry accompanies this somewhat, detracting from some of the cleaner hop aromas.

Flavor is not impressive at all and brings Arm & Hammer, grapefruit, lemon peel, soap, and slight popsickle stick. I checked the can again, and it does indeed say it's double-dry-hopped. Yet it tastes like some half-assed session beer. There is absolutely no way this is 7%. It's practically water.

Feel is juicy and creamy and acidic, on point. Good carbonation, moderate alcohol presence. But none of this matters because the flavor profile is non-existent.

Overall, no lie, this had to be the worst - or at least most boring - Citra/Mosaic IPA I've ever had. Did they brew this beer, cut it in half with carbonated water, and THEN release it?

Either I'm getting the turd out of every 4 pack or other people are smoking crack. Seriously - Drekker sucks, after half a dozen beers from them I have not found a single one worth finishing. This was laundry water. Expensive laundry water.

$4.79 / can

Having Drekker Multiple Ectogasms DDH DIPA, 7% ABV. Pours thick and hazy orange with a one finger white head that left no lacing. Nose is light tropical fruit and citrus. Taste is slight grapefruit and moderate pine 2x4, with slight sweetness and moderate bitterness. Decent mouthfeel, overall excellent. To me, not as good as a single Ectogasm.
Tasted in a Spiegelau IPA glass from a one pint can on February 3, 2019. Double dry hopped version of Ectogasm brewed with Citra and Mosaic hops. Hazy with citrus and tropical fruit notes.

Poured from 16oz can into glass. No canning date information found, but this drop is about two weeks old.
Totally cloudy, pale gold colored body. One to two finger bright white head. Leaves behind some spots and lines of lacing.
Big aroma of dank, catty, tropical fruit, citrus fruit, and vegetal hops.
First flavor is citrus orange and mango, with the backend being more dank, resiny, grapefruit rind, and vegetal. Kind of dry, and taste dyes off rather quickly. High level of hop product, that leads to a slight throat burn, but there is no bitterness.
Medium to full mouth feel. Good carbonation. Again the hops really fill the mouth.
Hop heavy beer that is free from bitterness but has abundant dank. Very interesting what brewers are doing to satisfy the murky, dank filled IPA demand.

Appearance: Cloudy gold body, large white head, sparce lacing.
Aroma: Yeasty, With the usual phenols of banana and clove tagging along.
Taste: Soft, rounded, some graininess, along with a repeat of the traits of the aroma. Minimally hopped.
Mouthfeel: Creamy, medium bodied, softly carbonated.
Overall: Refreshing. Good bargain.

0.33 L bottle
Best By: April, 2022
Glassware: 0.5 L Weizen Vase
Temp at Pour: mid 40s F


Look:
Golden yellow that is hazy and somewhat opaque (I can see the shadows of my fingers through the glass). Initial 2-finger pillowy off-white head that fades quickly to a thick ring and inconsistent cover. A bit underwhelming for a Hefeweizen.

Smell:
Bananas and bubblegum with some citrus notes. Grainy wheat malt. Minimal spices

Taste:
Ripe bananas and sweet citrus notes with very noticeable wheat grains. Cloves and allspice come through towards the end along with some flowery notes. As the beer warms some tartness becomes evident.

Feel:
Smooth and somewhat creamy. Body leans to the lighter side of medium.

Overall:
An interesting beer. This is a grainer variant of a Hefeweizen that has a higher ABV than most others and more inline with Oktoberfest beers. Though unspectacular, it is inoffensive and hits the classic Hefeweizen notes. It is eminently drinkable. It would be a find beer to introduce someone to the Hefeweizen styles.

Gem clear and gold until the yeast floods in. A big, voluminous, white meringue fills the bulb of a Pretentious Glass Company weizen glass. The head slowly settles to a thin blanket, leaving spotty lace beyond a spool of hair-thin glass.

The aroma has a nice, doughy/banana bread quality. It does, however, become muddy, with dusty straw as the head settles. Warmth reveals the expected clove.

It is sweet, front to back, with faint bitterness building into and through the finish. The banana flavor is very muted, though present. This is definitely a wheat beer, however, I suspect it was not as fresh as I had hoped. The bottle says "Best By April 2022". I drank it in November of 2021.

The medium body and soft, Jersey cotton texture give it a fluffy sensation. Alcohol is light, as expected, however, the carbonation should not be light and fizzy as it is here.

This is a decent drinking beer, even if this bottle is a bit too aged. It would work well in the early evening, or just with light conversation.

On tap at Melkebaren, Sandnes. Hazy deep golden colour, moderate white head. Moderate aroma of cloves and other spices, hints of banana. The flavour is moderately spicy with just a hint of banana, moderate but noticeable hops. Has more going on than the "ordinary" Erdinger Hefe-Weissbier.
Great beer. One of the best octoberfest beers I have had. Different than most because of the wheat, but not a hef in my mind. Great look and smell.

Golden yellow with a 1.5" white head, which lasts. Moderate lacing.

Aroma of biscuit malt, bread, yeast.

Taste is crackers, wheat, caramel, slight citrus, slight banana.

Light body, lively carbonation. Dry finish.

Another great German beer.

A very nice Fest style beer using wheat.
A bit different than the "norm" Fest style, but definitely a great quality brew.

Poured straw color with bright white head, very dense head and good lacing.
The aroma was yeast and cloves and spices. Quite nice.
The taste was better than I expected as I tend to not like wheat beers much but the spices and nutty flavors blended nicely with the bitterness for an enjoyable drink, I was definitely disappointed when it ended.
The feel was a bit thin, but it certainly didn’t make it bad, just easier to drink quickly.
OA, well, still at least 4 “official” festival beers to try so will not label it with a position yet.
Bottle with a best by of 04-2022. A good wheat beer but a bit "thin", especially in carbonation and mouthfeel. An enjoyable drink but not sure I'd buy it again.

Poured from a can into a pint glass
Appearance – The beer pours a hazed orange color with a one finger head of puffy white foam. The head has a good level of retention, slowly fading over time to leave a light level of foamy lace on the sides of the glass.
Smell – The aroma is big of a grainy and wheaty smell mixed with lots of orange and banana and spice of clove. Along with these smells comes a bit of toast and hay. Overall, very nice.
Taste – The taste begins with a sweeter wheaty and grainy taste with the sweeter being mostly of an orange and caramel taste. As the taste advances flavors of clove and coriander spice as well as banana comes to the flavor profile. At the same time a touch of herb and grass hit the tastebuds, all while a yeasty flavor comes in and some of the grain leaves, leaving one with a nice, somewhat sweeter but very pleasant weisbier flavor to linger on the tongue.
Mouthfeel – The body of the brew is medium in thickness and creaminess with a carbonation level that is slightly higher. Overall, the feel is great for the style and makes for a very nice easy drinker.
Overall – A rather nice weisbier with a great flavor and a great drinkability.

12 oz bottle, poured into a nucleated teku at ~40 degrees F.

L: Pours an opaque burnished-straw gold, and forms a massively fluffy head of white foam with ridiculous retention and lacing.

S: Banana and bubblegum, wafting on the breeze along a wheaten plain. A tinge of spice, and a hint of breadiness to the banana.

T: Definitely a hefeweizen. Clove, banana, and bubblegum hit right up front, and roll into the background by the finish to allow a biscuitlike bready quality to come forward.

F: Creamy and full, though with a bit of a lighter breakdown by the swallow.

O: Not a bad weissbier.

A wheat version of an Octoberfest style. Appearance is a golden cloudy color with banana, clove, taste. I find this more of a Hefeweizen than an Octoberfest and that is why it is categorized as a Hefeweizen, instead of an Octoberfest beer.

A- This pours out of the bottle, which I may say has great artwork and color, a cloudy golden hue, but only after some careful swirling of the 'nutrients' at the bottom of the bottle with a bit of the liquid, otherwise this would be a light yellowy golden color that is rather clear! The carbonation seems to be fairly aggressive in nature, and the head is white, and shows up as a small circular glob right in the middle of the glass at the top of the brew, with many columns of fizz bursting around it. There is modest lacing that graces the inside of my glass, but over time becomes more of an oily looking residue that doesn't stick at all. Overall this does have some characteristics of a Hefe, and looks decent enough.

S- The aromas are of medium banana bread, cloves, nutmeg, yeast, and sweet caramel malts. There are perhaps some muted grassy grainy wheat aromas, but definitely stay put in the background. I also detect some, again, muted hints of hop presence. Overall the smell is mild, which for a Hefe is probably not ideal, but for an Oktoberfest style, is great.....a blend of both styles here.....

T- Much of the aforementioned aromas carry over into the flavors. Muted banana, baking spices (clove and nutmeg), creamy yeast, bread and/or biscuit, and a dry finish that is of grain/wheat kernel. I find that the overall malt profile is fairly robust, and is noticeable from start to finish. I find that it is also reasonably clean on the finish. I like it!

M/O- As my eyes suggested, this one is definitely heavily carbonated, which is what I like to enjoy for an Oktoberfest. The body is medium and I find it to be highly drinkable (it helped that I found these 5 packs that came with a sweet glass for $13.99!) Think this does well with a meat pizza, as I had with this, as it cuts the oily pepperoni well, and it works well as a palate cleanser. An overall mild Hefe that doubles as a flavorful Oktoberfest....I can enjoy more than a pint in a sitting and see this as a great hot weather refresher!

Pours clear,gold in color with one third inch head. Taste is wheat and yeast. Light bodied, high carbonation slightly sweet. Tastes more wheaty than like an Oktoberfest. Not bad but several other German Oktoberfests I would go to first.
Bruce Holmes 12/2020
A Good Hefe beer but not your traditional Octoberfest beer, big drop off after having a Sierra Nevada Octoberfest last night. Glad I only bought 1 bottle in a mix/match 6pack

I really like this beer. Reminds me of an ale with hefe flavors and hefe feel. Looks like a hefe, smells like an ale, taste like an ale with hefe notes, feels like a hefe, the overall result I like a lot. Not too strong that you can't enjoy a few and still make it to work the next day. But it is supposed to be an Oktoberfest beer, and I don't really pick up on any of that except a little in the after taste. But, whatever. It is good. Need more before it is gone...
Maybe a bit sweet for a rye stout but the rye is still very evident regardless.

On tap at Revolution Brewpub

Man, I did not realize how highly regarded this one was when I order it. Not quite in the BA top 250, but sitting close under at #372 at the moment, and #97 for the style. Let’s find out if this no frills approach works out for Revolution

Pours completely pitch black with a finger of creamy light tan head that fades to a ring and leaves minimal lacing

Oh man, this is very sweet and boozy in the nose. I don’t know why, but I was expecting something with more bite. Still, I like it. I’m picking up on aromas of toasted coconut, sweet vanilla, oak, chocolate fudge, molasses, brown sugar, light raisin, marzipan, and light rye

Likewise in taste it is quite sweet, without much punch to keep it truly balanced. On the front end of the sip I’m tasting molasses, sweet bourbon, toasted oak, honey, spicy rye, caramel, light coconut, black cherry, and brown sugar. The swallow brings notes of brown sugar, molasses, spicy rye, sweet bourbon, caramel, toasted coconut, oak, and milk chocolate

A full body pairs with gentle tingling carbonation, resulting in a boozy sweet beer. Finishes neutral with a bold sweetness

From the Revolution Stouts I’ve had, I’ve noticed that many lean more into Barleywine territory. I don’t mind that, but in this one it’s perhaps a bit too sweet. Still, it’s enjoyable other than the feel being hurt a bit

12oz can, dated 07.07.2022, poured into a 12oz lowball glass.

The beer pours a deep jet black color, thick and viscous, motor oil sludge with a tan khaki head that has moderate retention and spots of lacing. The aroma is nice, bursting with licorice, dark chocolate, strap molasses, charred oak, toffee bourbon, spicing, coconut and vanilla. The flavors are very good, black licorice, anise, molasses, charred oak, rye bread, toffee, brown sugar, caramel, vanilla, coconut and lingering stone fruits. The mouthfeel is great, coating, thick, heavy and full body, creamy and smooth with a warming finish.

Verdict: An excellent rye stout from Revolution and Binny's. Definitely showcases the barrels well while maintaining a distinct rye character and an exceptional balance of flavors. No adjuncts necessary, just a world-class beer.

Pours a lovely, shiny pitch black color. Oily and viscous. Thin, weak mocha colored head. Not much in the way of a head retention.

Aroma has notes of chocolate, bourbon, spicy rye, oak, leather and vanilla.

Taste follows the nose with rich notes of maple, spicy rye, vanilla, leather, oak, pepper and caramel.

Feel is thick, creamy, smooth, and rich. Medium carbonation. Spicy finish.

Overall a lovely barrel aged stout from revolution

A thick oily Pours witha a small tan head that gone in a few seconds, no lacing, but it does leave an oily film. Snot factory says, chocolate, vanilla and booze. Taste buds get that, some dark fruit shows up in the flavor. This is just an awesome brew all the way around. This is finishes a bit to sweet.

Dark deep black/brown. Flavors bounce off your nose,boozy sweet stonefruit, dark rich chocolate. Taste is similar to nose, boozy sweet rye, chocolate, sweet stonefruit. Full flavor lingering mouthfeel.

poured from a 12oz can into a stemless wine glass. pours a dense, shiny black with a finger of dark brown foam. chocolate and bourbon-soaked oak dominate the nose. it’s not the most complex stout but you can tell you’re in for a barrel-forward treat. the rye plays a little more in the taste and there’s a touch of dark fruits but it’s quite a bit of chocolate and even more barrel. thick, full mouthfeel. very silky and smooth. this is a nice sipper but it’s also kind of drinkable and approachable too. damn tasty.

Batch 2 (2022 year) from can.

Phenomenal, just like batch one when fresh. Dark brown appearance with a good bit of foam forming upon aggressive pour. Smells and taste of plenty of chocolate, sweet bourbon and rice spices. This beer should be allowed to warm closer toward room temperature, as it really opens up on those notes then. Medium feel, which is great because it makes it approachable and not like you're eating dinner out of a bottle.

If batch 1 is any indication though, this should be drank on the fresher side and not 'aged'.

12 oz. can. Black, slightly transparent at the edges. Smells of bourbon, chocolate, brown sugar, stronf rye spice. Tastes of chocolate, booze, bourbon, oak, rye spice. Finishes with a lot of rye. Medium heavy, pretty sweet, quite boozy. Tasty, but excessively boozy, which makes it very tough to drink.

Thanks to Jinx989 for this 12 oz. can as I continue to try to cram as much Revolution Deep Woods stuff into my body as possible. More success!

The pour is coffee dark with a short, quick-moving head. The nose is hefty rye, bourbon, with a backboard of chocolate.

Thundertaker is a stout to be dissected; it’s like a beer layer cake. And it took a good 45 minutes to open up. I initially thought this was kind of dull. It’s not. Rye finally rises & the bourbon settles in right between my eyes. Behind is chocolate, loads of sweet molasses, brazen spiciness that leans towards mélange, with a touch of brown leather on the finish. Thick & spicy. I am going to hide the other can from my wife.

Not the mind-blowing rye I was seeking but this is bloody excellent.

Canned on 9/10/2020; consumed on 8/18/21

Pours a glossy, inky black body capped with over two fingers of soapy, pale mocha foam; great head retention leaves a quickly fading cap, a razor-thin, frothy collar, and no lacing whatsoever holding to the walls of the glass.

Aroma brings rye spice to the forefront as the malt profile expands upon big, fudgy chocolate tones into shaved almonds with a bourbon imbued epicenter imparting an undercurrent of oak and vanilla, while culminating in a chocolate pudding toast crescendo through the close.

Taste opens with burnt brownie crust as spikes of spicy rye malt form caramel brittle and vanilla-tinged fudge into the mid-palate, where decadent layers of melted dark chocolate and tinges of molasses being sensations of chocolate pudding crusts, while subtle bourbon and oak coat the increasingly decadent malt finish.

Mouthfeel offers a medium-full body with minimal carbonation, slick, semi-creamy textures evolving and glistening over the mid-palate to deliver a prickly warmth; trending toward a stickier characteristic which never quite materializes, instead highlighting a softer char into a subtle dryness on the back end.

Rich expression of malt decadence blatantly attempts to compensate for the immediate affront of rye spice, seeking a tenuous balance, occasional clashing, and ultimately settling well to satisfy both the sweeter tooth and barrel-forward leanings.

12 ounce can into a snifter. Canned 9/10/20, had 12/3/20.

Pours an opaque dark brown, thick looking, with a brief quarter inch head and light foamy lacing. Aromas of bourbon, rye, chocolate, malt, tobacco, oak, some char, molasses, some vanilla as it warms, light raisins and leather. Smells fantastic. The flavor is more bourbon forward and wow, is it good. Then rye, chocolate, malt, oak, tobacco, raisins, vanilla as it warms, light molasses, a little char. Has a definite spicy flavor. Tastes about as good as it smells. Silky smooth, a solid full body, well carbonated.

This is my favorite stout of the Deep Wood series, no doubt. Incredible barrels, a heavenly aroma, a cornucopia of aromas and flavors. The rye malt is a knockout, too. That extra five months in the barrel from the original planned release certainly did no harm. Revolution just continues to amaze.

Poured from a can, the beer pours the expected blackish brown color. Head retention and lacing aren't this beer's strong suit, but even so, the beer looks quite rich and viscous. When I first tasted this beer (fresh out of the fridge), I wasn't hugely impressed, as I picked up an overwhelming amount of molasses on the nose and palate. However, as the beer warmed and opened up, there was noticeable dark chocolate, milk chocolate, vanilla, light coffee and some light bourbon/rye whiskey. The flavor profile replicated the nose pretty closely in this rich, fairly sweet stout, with the beer displaying a soft, creamy, full mouthfeel. Not that it matters I think, but while I did pick up some rye on the nose, there wasn't much of that on the palate. Either way, I don't think the rye flavor adds a whole lot to this beer. Alcohol is pretty well integrated into the flavor profile, though you can tell the alcohol is up there a bit (I mean after all, the abv IS 14.6%). So this is definitely a sipper (I think I spent close to 3 hours savoring this beer, watching 3 episodes of star trek voyager).

This is the first beer I've had from this brewery, and to say the least I was quite impressed. This is very well done.

Deep near-obsidian almost-black. Oily. Small head fizzes up fizzes down and is gone.

Nose is more subdued than I'd expect, to be honest. Dark roasted malts, burnt coffee, dark dark chocolate... boozy, but not as much as you'd expect given it's massive ABV. Enjoyable flavours, but relatively muted.

Oily and spicy with spicy carbonation. Warm alcohol finish. Again, definitely very very boozy, but not as much so as 14.6% might suggest.

Sweet first off. Rich and oily. Dark plum, fudgy dark dark chocolate brownies, some espresso bitterness to go with the chocolate bitterness. Sweet, oily, rich, decadent. Less of the hard spicy rye than I got on the nose.

Another decadent IL-area stout from @FBarber's box of goodies. Thanks Frank!

This was fantastic from beginning to end. Look was above average, smell was above average with lots of bourbon, but the taste was where the magic really happened. I got lots of barrel char in this to accompany the rye spice, deeply layered malts, and sweet bourbon finish. Smooth as silk with a touch of alcohol burn.

Obsidian black with a short dark mocha head that fizzles out fairly quickly to a thin brown caviar chain, leaving a surface that appears somewhat oily and gloppy. A tilt will develop solid legs fully sweeping around the perimeter of the glass.

Delectable aromas of charred oak and dark chocolate give way to hints of toasted marshmallow and fainter hints of hickory smoked almond.

While a little lighter up front, first taste is fudge cut by a light sting of peppery bourbon and savory charred oak. It then thickens and smooths mid-palate to a more viscous consistency where a prickly carbonation arises before the semi-dry, lightly sticky swallow brings up a touch of heat.

Caramel glides in on the second sip, as do lighter notes of root beer and roasted nuts. Even though it thickens mid-palate, it honestly goes down so quickly as it transitions to a cola feel towards the swallow that it's hard to contemplate, but after one sip I'm exhaling char and fudge for days.

It's not QUITE as good as BCBS, but it's close. As I say this, I think to compare my ratings, and it's even closer than I expected, being only .01 off!

Pours a deep black with minimal head and no lacing.

The smell is very sweet dark fruits, char, whiskey, maple, and vanilla.

The taste is barrel heavy, sweet, vanilla, maple, char, leather, and some dark fruits.

The mouthfeel is low carbonation, medium/thick body, and very smooth.

Overall this is excellent, tons of great flavors, nice feel, awesome barrel. Really well done beer.
More of a barleywine then a stout, one of revs best, and that's saying a lot.

This one pours a very dark black color, with a small head, and not much lacing.

This smells like molasses, rye candy, dark bittersweet maple syrup, oak spice, tobacco, heavy roast, cocoa powder, and vanilla.

This is easily one of the best just straight up barrel aged stouts that I've ever had. So much interesting and complex flavor is wrung from the barrel aging process here. There's a killer and intriguing sweetness here - mainly feels like maple and molasses, with some sweet powdery chocolate, and vanilla as well. There's also spicy and heavy oak character, with a wonderful bourbon heat to it. The cool sweetness from the beer might come from the barrel, might come from the malt. The rye spice with the sweetness is just great.

This is medium bodied, creamy, and with no real booziness to it. There's some warmth, but no outward astringency. It's very drinkable.

This is just a perfect example of an amazing beer being made especially for an amazing barrel. Revolution should be extremely proud of this effort.

Pitch black body with a finger of brown foam. Aromas of semi-sweet chocolate backed up by rich and dark bourbon, oak, rye, char, earth, tobacco, molasses, and raisin. Taste is much the same, a touch of leather here and there, but less of the dark fruit flavors, booze is showcased in a powerful yet balanced way. Feel is warm, smooth, chewy, thick, and heavy with the barrel character really showing itself. Best rye ba stout of the year so far! The wife loved it

One of the best pure barrel beers I can remember having. Boozy up front that moves to vanilla as it warms. Nice body, toes the line well of having substance but not being overtly thick. A real treat of a stout with no added flavor.

16oz can from Tavour. Black pour, fizzy beige head fades to flat. Aroma is chocolate, cinnamon, light coffee. Taste brings more chocolate, vanilla, coffee, honey, cinnamon. Coffee bitterness lingers. Slick, not too heavy, ABV is masked well.

poured from a 16oz can into a TG MD snifter. pours a semi see through brown but gathers in the glass a light black with virtually no head. a thin collar of mocha brown foam presides around the rim of the glass. roasted malts, light toffee and chocolate and a kiss of cinnamon on the nose. as it warms there’s a slight alcohol sting. taste is chocolate, caramel, light coffee and cinnamon. i don’t get a lot of coffee but it’s still a nice flavor combination. incredibly full mouthfeel that finishes thick and sticky. drinks like an imperial stout. another enjoyable pressed entry. this one was actually less sweet then i thought it was going to be. lots of caramel, toffee and a bit of cinnamon. really good.

Appearance: Pours a mostly clear, medium, deep orange color with a mild off-white head. SRM of 11. (3.75)

Aroma: Relatively moderate aromas of bread malt, crusty cereal malt. Some caramel evolves as it warms, but largely pale.

Flavor: Moderate flavors of bread malt and pale malt. Strong bready flavors and a smooth malty finish. Some deeper caramel evolves from the bread as it warms. Not too sweet.

Feel: Medium to heavier bodied. Properly carbonated and a full mouthfeel and bread malt lingers off the finish.

Overall: A pretty decent Marzen here. Very bready. Not spiced or amber malt from an altbier like I would expect. I would describe this as a bready Marzen. Relatively pale, but a strong bready flavor and nice mouthfeel. Not too sweet and full. It's not bad as bad as the ratings suggest. Bready and enjoyable. (Rating: 3.83)

Appearance:
Orange-light copper, Thin head, moderate lace, clear and polished. Altbiers should be darker, more of a mahogany hue.

Aroma:
lightly toasted sweet biscuity malt, minimal hops. no esters.

Flavor:
Mild Munich malt character, some alcohol, weak hops. Some slight fruitiness.

Mouthfeel:
Light. Low-ish CO2, no astringency or harsh MF

Overall:
It's been years -- several years-- since I had a real German Altbier (Frankenheim and such) and this is not like that. Tastes more like a milder, fruitier US-made Marzen or American Bock.

From Widmer Brothers is Ok to Festival Ale. It's actually an altbier, which isn't actually a märzen or festbier, which feels like cheating being in an Oktoberfest pack. It pours a hazy copper with a thin white head. Sweet malt aroma is clear as day. The sweetness is not as immediately present on the taste. Initially, I had a metallic flavor before it settles into the sweetness I smelled. Most of the mouthfeel is inoffensive. It's not bad, but I wouldn't put this in a marketed Oktoberfest pack.

12oz can

Pours two fingers of tan head into my can-style glass. Retention is average and the head mostly fades within a few minutes. Lacing is pretty good. Body is a dark burnt orange, high clarity, with a moderate amount of bubbles coming up. Looks pretty nice.

Nose is biscuity, with some faint fruity esters, slightly sweet. Not a super big nose, but it smells pretty decent.

Flavor is ok, a little malty, some biscuit. Fruity esters do start to show up as the beer warms, but overall the aroma has a hard time coming through to the flavor.

Carbonation is on the lighter side, I agitated it a decent amount though. Body is medium. Just slightly bitter. Touch of sweetness, well attenuated though. Pretty straight forward mouthfeel.

Drinkability is very nice.

Definitely seems more like a Marzen than a Altbier, like some past versions have been apparently marketed. Overall not terrible, probably better than the rep it gets. Still, the flavor certainly leaves a little to be desired, not a whole lot going on there.

12oz can PKGD ON JUN21 22 poured into a becher glass at fridge temp 5.5% 26 IBU. The beer pours mostly bright light amber with off white head. The head recedes to a pencil thin ring and island. The aroma is mild with toasted malt. The taste is toasted malt with mild orchard fruit and and a little funky tang. Mild to negligible bitterness. The mouthfeel is thin to medium bodied with just less than average carbonation and a semi dry finish. Overall, not great.

Dull orange pour, 1/2" off white head. Average retention. Aroma was mild sweetened malt grain stuff.

Taste was smooth, hopping low, mild nuttiness. A little bit of caramel mouthfeel.

Slow smooth ride on this one, nothing jumping, nothing off flavored.

My first beer in Support of New Beer Sunday (Week 573) will be another from the Bottle Backlog here at Chez Woody. I am actually starting to make real, noticeable progress; bottles are getting recycled; caps are being saved for art projects; 4- & 6-pack carriers are being emptied & returned. It is a glorious time!

From the bottle: "Loosen your lederhosen. Our full-bodied Okto Festival Ale is inspired by Bavarian Oktoberfest. [undersigned] Kurt [&] Rob"; "We pay fitting tribute with its distinctive malt flavors, mild floral character and crisp, clean finish. Prost! to the land of Prost!"

A Pop! of the cap & the Festival was underway! I utilized a gentle pour in deference to its relative age and then gave it a vigorous swirl in the glass. This produced a finger of foamy, tawny head with decent retention that slowly fell to wisps. Color was Deep Amber/Light Copper to Copper (SRM = > 13, < 17) with NE-quality clarity. Nose was oddly vegetal, like cooked cabbage, underlain by a biscuit maltiness. I read the style description for an Altbier, but even with the style's quirks and oddities, this does not seem right. Mouthfeel was medium to-full, not quite creamy. The taste was MUCH better than the nose had led me to expect! It was actually quite sweet, very much of caramel or crème brulee. Again, I am not sure that such is stylistically correct, nor would I ever mistake this for an Oktoberfest/Marzen. The sweetness made it more like a dessert beer for me. It was drinkable, certainly, and the finish was only semi-sweet, perhaps as a testament to the yeast having thoroughly done its job. The caramel flavor lingered well after the finish. For me, one was plenty.

rated on RateBeer as an amber, here listed as an alt, but they were probably trying pull of a marzen. What a mess! Bland and unmemorable, watery, generic tasting. Very faint aroma and flavors, no finish.

Poured on Oct. 12th, bottled on July 24th. What's up with this one, Widmer? Pours a weak cloudy pale red with no head to speak of. Weak, indistinct aroma. It has an odd taste for a lager and a soapy aftertaste. We've enjoyed others, so maybe we got a skunked one.

Enjoyed on tap. Served in a lager glass. Pours a clear orange/brown with a thin head that faded fast and elft some spotty lacing.
The aroma is malt-forward with lots of bread and biscuit on the nose with a little floral and spice hiding in there as well.
Taste is pretty good. Malt forward, sweet and bready with some floral notes and a pleasant finishing bitterness.
Mouthfeel is fairly thin but almost smooth.
Overall, refreshing enough but lacking anything really distinctive.

Poured 12oz bottle into snifter glass. 5.3% abv

Appearance- Pours a dark copper orange with a two finger head of a faintly brown tint, quick to dissipate. Moderatly hazy.

Smell- Caramel, baked bread, orange citrus.

Taste- Toasty malt, semi sweet. Chewy nut flavor mixes in with a subtle citric hop flavor of orange coming through as well. Finish is sharp and comes on fast, finishing more malty than hoppy by far.

Mouthfeel- Medium in body with medium carbonation as well. Smooth.

Overall- Kind of like an Oktoberfest but not really as this is an Altbier. Definitely mixes up the Fall seasonal thing. Not a sweet malts and a very crisp clean flavor profile. Well suited for the season.

A brilliant orange gold pour builds a 1” persistent cream colored foam collar while unleashing rich bread and spicy bread crust aromas. This is a malt driven beer with rich bread and bread crust flavors and a light finishing hop earthy bitterness. There is an initial sweetness that dries out on the finish. Clean and smooth, the beer has a medium body and slightly below average carbonation. A very good Alt style beer brewed with an Oktoberfest grain bill and a clean ale yeast.
Look is a bit clearer than most Octoberfests. Above average Marzen smell.

From a can into a pint glass. Pour has a vibrant, slowly receding head of light biege foam that tops a fantastic amber brown body that is generally clear but with uniform particulate throughout. Scent has the pretty typical nuttiness of a brown ale with sweeter notes of toffee and hazelnut rounding it out (and almost wholly avoiding the sometimes bitter scents of a brown ale). Taste is an incredibly well balanced blend of subtle nuttiness and hazelnut with a just a smidge of bitterness peeking out. Feel is very smooth with a pleasant aftertaste that follows the taste well. An all around excellent fall beer that is very, very drinkable.

This one I really like.

Poured a deep reddish auburn with a tan head that didn't last that long, but overall it still looked good in the glass.

Aroma and taste lived up to the hazelnut hype, and even the nectar part, as the feel was a bit thick and went down with a great deal of satisfaction.

This one had a nice complexity between hops, malt and hazelnut. I will absolutely buy it again. It was also nice to have an English brown ale, as this style is not very common in South tx

First, this is a well carbonated beverage. But it doesn't produce a ridiculous amount of beer head. In fact, the lightly biege head is very modest, although somewhat enduring. The brew itself is a solid brown color that's opaque, but far from murky. The aroma is malty and the described hazelnut addition is definitely subdued. That aspect isn't even in the initial taste. But then, as the brew lingers toward its finish, the hazelnut explodes. This is a truly unique drinking experience and a good one, should you like hazelnuts. As a brown ale there's no expectation of hoppiness and this is true to that style. That this can convert a mild malt character into one with such a hazelnut infusion is admirable. This may be another limited audience brew, but it's a great choice for anyone that likes their brown ales with a hazelnut flavoring. This best part, it adds a nutty aspect without any additional sweetness.
An exceptional brown ale. A must try for fans of brown ales.
Loved it. Smooth, chewy. No bitterness.

Pours a deep amber hue with a robust tan head.
Some mild hop scents. Not much aroma.
Good malty, roasty tones.low bitterness.
Nutty and I get a bit of caramel too.hazelnut is there also.
Smooth with low carbonation.
Good offering from rogue, drink with bread pudding.

Poured moderately hard from a can into a snifter glass, forming a couple fingers of tan head. Head soon faded to nothing. Translucent orangey-brown color. Smell is definitely hazelnut, but not super strong. Taste is some hazelnut and roasty undertones. Tasty and mild. Pretty strong carbonation and light bodied. Not bad overall, an easy drinking hazelnut porter.

Very slightly hazy mahogany brown color with a nice moderate tan head that retrains well but produces very little lacing.
The aroma is warm fresh bread, slightly sweet malt and just a hint of nuttiness.
The taste is light sweet malt, biscuits, a touch of brown sugar and nicely light hazelnut with just enough floral hops for a nicely balanced overall flavor, nothing overpowering or too understated
The body is light/medium and very smooth with mild carbonation.
Overall, just a really pleasant brown ale, very nice.

Nutty: my favorite.

L- On the pour I got a 1finger head, as I drink there is light lacing. It is a deep reddish brown and the beer is almost hazy which is interesting, hopefully normal, but kinda cool.

S- the hazelnut flavor definitely comes through and it compliments the yeast they used nicely. Not a lot of hops on the nose, but that's kinda the point.

T- A warm (feeling/tasting) malty tidal wave of flavor dissipates into a pretty subtle hazelnut flavor with very light bitterness that also reminds me of a nut, not a lot of hops again.

F- the feel is mostly consistent and overall enjoyable but if you think about it there is a slick lens that comes right before a dryness but that's quite easy to move past

O- the flavor profile carrys this beer into nut brown ale stardom, as the hops from american craft brewing remove some of the nutty qualities from this english style. Sam smith still beats them out, but this is much more accessible and attractive to modern audiences.
Nuts. Nuts. Nuts. Good. Better. Best. Nuts! (& a fine nectar 'tis!)

Of all things, picked up a bottle of this delicious nectar at a liquor store in Clovis NM (hilltop liquor store).

The beer pours the expected blackish brown color, with very good head retention and lacing. The nose is fairly typical for a Firestone anniversary ale, showcasing considerable brown sugar, vanilla, light molasses, milk chocolate, caramel, toffee and light bourbon. The flavor profile replicates the nose pretty closely in this rich, moderately sweet beer. The cacaphony of different flavors blend together very, very well in this rather luscious beer. Mouthfeel is fairly full, and the finish is long, soft, creamy and rather decadent. Alcohol is very well integrated into the flavor profile, though you can tell the abv is up there a bit. Drinkability is pretty good considering, and this beer makes an absolutely delightful after dinner aperitif.

Excellent beer from the folks at FW. Have had most of their anniversary beers, and this is clearly one of the better ones (IMHO). Impressive.

12 oz bottle. Pours dark brown with tall, creamy, long-lasting, brown head and nice lacing. Aroma is of rum, sherry, caramel malt, vanilla, chocolate and dark fruit. Body is full, creamy and smooth. Taste is of caramel malt, sherry, brown sugar, wood, spices, vanilla, chocolate, bourbon and dark fruit. Complexity of flavor is increasing as beer warms up. Finish is long and dry. Outstanding brew.

I'd been looking with great envy at how West coast BAs regard the output of this brewery until my daughter came through with a Christmas present. Today was Father's day so why not.

Whoever does the blending of this really knows their craft because this is very refreshing in taste and mouthfeel. It doesn't feel complex so much as very easy to drink; probably dangerously so if I wasn't planning on remaining relatively stationary. I wish I had additional bottles to age because I think cellaring might do very interesting things but that's for some lucky soul to discover on his/her own. I'm just glad I had this. Sláinte.

After a few of these it’s time to crack my knuckles & type some words about it. 12 oz. bottle with a classy, severe label of blue & pale gold.

The pour is just light of stout, with some dark brown & cerise creeping around the edges. For all the components, the nose is surprisingly light: booze & chocolate. More coming, I hope.

Firestone Walker XXV enters the lower echelon of a fabled line of anniversary brews. Impressions I’ve had of this beer are confirmed: it’s thin & muddled. For all the marvelous beers dunked herein, what results is light barrel, mostly brandy, faint chocolate, light tequila (growing as it warms), leather, & a finish of oak. Splitting the bottle with my lovely wife, as I have in the past, seems like a good idea now.

Flipping back, this is the weakest of the series since XVII. A pretty good beer. Disappointing.
great rich tasting ale slight malt taste very hoppy

Bottle Date: 2021
Palate Contaminants: none

Dark brown color with tan head. Not much of that, though, so not much lacing.

Sticky dark fruit on the nose, and there's a savory depth to it. A little raisin, a little prune, and a little fig. There's also some creamer/lactic scent going on, as well as vanilla and clove. Very pleasant.

It's even heavier on the fruit in the taste, and I'd especially say the raisin is dialed up. Distinct sweetness, although it's not overpowering. The next main flavor is coffee, and it goes along with moderate-light bitterness. The sweetness seems to link to brown sugar late.

Weight is heavy; it sits on the back of my tongue. Carbonation is fine and well integrated. Alcohol taste isn't much present, although one can feel the ABV eventually. Unsurprisingly, the aftertaste is coffee and raisins.

Picked up a 12 oz bottle while visiting PHX 3-11-22 for $9.99. Also brought back a Crowler to share with friends. Consumed for review 5-17-22.

Beer poured dark brown with an okay tan head.

Nose is quite nice, bourbon, leather, vanilla, and tequila are very pungent.

Taste is superb, a large malt base comprised of five different beers allows the bourbon, vanilla, tequila, and dark fruits to express nicely with the usual amount of hopping still remaining, along with the barrel presence, to balance the finish.

Mouthfeel is medium bodied and very smooth.

Overall another delightful Anniversary brew...will need to work on obtaining some every year!

Appearance: Pours espresso colored with a thin beige head that fades to a ringlet; dots of lacing

Smell: Other than the blend of various barrel aromatics (Bourbon and Brandy, with a hint of Tequila) the caramel is significant along with a spice cake character

Taste: Caramel and spice cake forward with the barrel blend emerging; even though the Bourbon barrels predominate it is the Brandy barrel which directs the flavor profile; the Tequila arrives in the rear; sticky, sweet and complex finish that is reminiscent of a Dr Pepper

Mouthfeel: Full bodied with moderate carbonation; some warmth in the gullet

Overall: Just another great beer from the barrel aging pros

Growler into pint glass. Pours an inky black with essentially no head. Initial impression is surprisingly easy-drinking, with notes of blackstrap molasses, caramel, roasted malts, booze, and a touch of bitterness. Mouthfeel is medium, thick and smooth yet dinitely not cloying. Finish is slightly boozy, but so well balanced that it is an asset rather than an issue. Overall, this is one of the most enjoyable Strong Ales in my admittedly limited experience. Try it - you won't be disappointed!

I am becoming a huge Firestone Walker fan. Everything I have tried has been excellent. This is my first Anniversary Ale. So much going on with the blended taste but quite enjoyable. Not too boozy. A nice sitting at home sipper. Deep rich black color. Easy drinking. I will have to find some more.
12oz bottle from Brewers Haven. Black pour, thin ring of beige head. Sweet aroma, malty, boozy. Taste is malty, sweet, raisins, chocolate. Creamy, slick, warm. As usual, perfect blending.

Pours black with two and a half fingers of dense khaki-colored foam. A deep foam ring forms around the top of the beer for a long while after the pour. Aroma is heavy roasty and toasty malts with thick caramel and earthy malts behind. Interstitial space is full of barrel, whiskey, brown sugar, dark fruits, and some faint notes of fudge. It has a sweet start, but is undercut by spicy whiskey, although in harmony, this works to create a beautiful balance. Flavor profile is roasty, toasty, and earthy malts. Dark fruits, caramel, and molasses develop a smooth sweetness, which is balanced out by late whiskey and barrel. The latter offers up some heavy, strong notes, without being hot. Some sticky, resiny hops sit in between the sugary notes, adding a little bitterness for balance. Mouth feel is thick with a near soft effervescence, carrying just enough silt to keep it from being plush. Instead, this silt works to elevate the texture out of forgettable. Overall, incredibly rich in depth and notes. It drinks smooth, without coming off complex, and yet there are layers to peel away in every sip.

Served in a 15.5oz Spiegelau tulip from a 12oz bottle.

Bottled 2021. Poured at 52°. Dark brown/black with ruby hues; creamy tan head with a few rocks; ok cap retention, solid ring; some sudsy lace; thin legs. Tequila and oak nose; boozy exhale. Sweet caramel and sugary raisins; some sharp tequila immediately follows; oaky vanilla and chocolate as beer warms. Medium plus body, silky feel; burn on tip of tongue; warmth from 11.5% abv; light carbonation; dry wooden finish. Overall, this blend of multiple barrels, including Tequila Barrel Merkin (28%) is sharp and spirits forward; the rest is nice, but the tequila continues to linger as I finish this review; good, but not what I want…

I have had the last few years of this series, and they’ve all been great (still have to rate 24, however). Wanted to rate this one fresh. Very barrel forward. Dark brown, foamy head, lasting lacing. Notes of dark fruit, molasses, and brandy on the nose. Barrels are quite assertive on the taste. Dark fruit presence again, slightly sweet. It’s thinner than I expected, have to see if it rounds as it warms. Very boozy. I think with some age, this is going to be an excellent beer.

I very much want to find a couple of more copies and cellar them as 25 needs some time to blend its blend.
25 is only my second in this series (I'm always late to parties.) But this whole process of collaboratively blending with winemakers that is described on the sheet in the box is as elaborate as I can imagine for a brewer and very Californiana.

I will do this brew justice and finish this review after I've aged and mellowed 25. Great potential.

A surprisingly thin pour, damn near black, small khaki head fades quickly, leaving a bit of lace. Snot locker got some dark fruit and some booze, just to much for my old nose to discern. Unfortunately, my taste buds were beaten up here. Thin. I thought this was going to be ridiculously sweet, it wasn't.

Bottle pour- Dark as can be with short khaki head leaving scattered lacing and a ring of bubbles. Nose highlights the barrels. Taste follows with a mix , although the tequila seems noticeable.Boozy barrel wood lingers into the finish.
